text.0: The tail of the A runs down to the last line of this page; this letter is in red and blue paint, and is six lines high (see photo). Alle-myghty god in trinite, Sothfaste god in persones thre, Fadir, sone, and holi gost, In whom is witte and myghtes most, Be at this tale begynny[n]g And also at the endyng! So ende oure tale and so bygynne, The ioye of heuene al for to wynne, Aftir oure lyff at oure laste ende, To ioye of heuene alle for to wende! Many speken of men that romaunces rede Erasure of two or three letters between that and romaunces , and of one letter after rede . That were sumtyme doughti in dede, The while that god hem lyff lente, That now ben dede and hennes wente: Off Bevis, Gy, and of Gauwayn, Off kyng Richard, & of Owayn, Off Tristram, and of Percyuale, Off Rouland Ris, and Aglauale, Off Archeroun, and of Octouian, Off Charles, & of Cassibaldan, Off Hauelok, Horne, & of Wade;— In Romaunces that of hem ben made That gestoures often dos of hem gestes At Mangeres and at grete ffestes. Here dedis ben in remembraunce In many fair Romaunce; But of the worthiest wyght in wede That euere by-strod any stede, Spekes no man, ne in romaunce redes Off his batayle ne of his dedis. Off that batayle spekes no man, There alle prowes of knyghtes be-gan; That was for-sothe of the batayle That at Troye was saunfayle. Off swyche a fyght as ther was one, In al this world was neuere none, Ne neuere schal be til domysday— With-oute drede, I dar wel say;— Ne neuere better men born ware, Then were þan a-sembled thare; Neuere was, ne neuere schal be So many gode men at asemble— I dar wel say, be my ffay,— As were at that batayle of Troy. ¶ This sign is in blue paint, and so they are everywhere else in this MS. For ther were, In that on side, Sixti kynges and dukes of pride, And sythen mo of gret feute, With alle thaire folk and thaire meyne; And ther was the beste bodi in dede That euere &yogh;it wered wede, Sithen the world was made so ferre, That was Ector, in eche a werre, Ne that neuere sclow so many bodies— Fyghtyng In feld with his enemyes— Off worthi men that doughti were, As duke Ector of Troye there; For ther was neuere man that myght stand A strong stroke of Ectores hand, That he ne deyed In that stounde With his dynt and falle to grounde, But the strong Achilles, That was best of alle that pres Off the kynde of Gregeys, As &yogh;e schal here how it weys. This capital is in blue and red paint, and so they are everywhere else in the MS. HErkenes now, and &yogh;e may here The werre sothe alle plenere: What was the forme enchesoun, The formest skyl and resoun, That alle the kynges of Grecis formast Inued And the Troyens so longe pursued; And how the batayle was first be-gunnen, And how Troye was sithen y-wonnen; And—as the storie here beris recorde— Alle the dedis of euery lorde, And alle the dayes that thei faught there, And alle the dedis as thei were Of alle the lordes that ther faught, And whiche of hem here dethe þer laught; ¶ And how fele termes and trewes Where take be-twene Troyens and Gruwes, And how longe euery trewe laste, And how thai spedde when thei were paste; And alle here wo and al here breste; And how many tymes that thei reste With-Inne ten &yogh;ere that thei were thore, Er that the toun distroyed wore. ¶ Dares, the heraud of Troye, sais, ¶ Dares The sign in blue, the name in red paint. . And Dites that was of the Gregeis,— For thei were euery day in the feld And alle here dedis thay be-held,— And as thei were thei wreten hem bothe; Thei nolde not lette, for leef ne lothe, The sothe to say with-oute les Of gode Ector and Achilles, And of alle the gode lordes echon; And of alle here dedis schal lakke non. ¶ And afftir hem come Maister Gy, That was of Rome a Notary, And fond here bokes In Athenes Afftirwardes when it was pes, ¶ Polleus. ¶ Thesalie The signs in blue, the names in red paint; and so always. Here the last three stand in the left margin in MS. . And turned it of Grew into Latyn, And wrot it faire in parchemyn In the manere as I schal telle. Hende, now herken to my spelle! IN the lond of Thesalye— As telles vs the right storie— Was sumtyme a noble kyng, Riche of kyn and other thyng, That het Polleus, whil he hadde lyff, ¶ Rex Polleus The signs in blue, the names in red paint; and so always. Here the last three stand in the left margin in MS. . And Tetes het the qwene his wyff. On here gat he that doughti knyght In wedlac, that Achilles hight, That wondir wrought and gret meruayle Afftirward in Troye batayle. ¶ This Polleus hadde an eldur brother, That higthe Eson, he het non other. Eson was so lad with elde, ¶ Rex Eson The signs in blue, the names in red paint; and so always. Here the last three stand in the left margin in MS. . That he ne myght his hondes welde: He toke Polleus al Thesaly With alle the Rentes and seygnory For to gouerne and for to &yogh;eme, And bad alle him serue to queme, For thei schulde be in his pouste; For he was blynd and my&yogh;t nou&yogh;t se. That blynde kynge, that het Eson, ¶ Jason ffilius Eson The signs in blue, the names in red paint; and so always. Here the last three stand in the left margin in MS. . Hadde a sone, that het Iason, Strong, sturne, stalworthe & stoute, Off speche curtays, of contenaunce deuoute, Large of &yogh;ifftes and [ryght] ffre, Wondur fair and ryght tempere. Alle the lordes of that lond Seruede that child to fote & hond For his prowes and his noblay, And loued him wel and quemed ay; ¶ Insula Colkos. Thai dede him as gret reuerence As Polleus kyng in his presence; The lordis and alle the comunalte Held that [child] child is not in the MS., but there is no blank either. In gret cherte. ¶ Polleus hadde wel gret envye That men dede him suche seruagery; He was aferd in his herte: If that child &yogh;ede forth In querte, And afftirward my&yogh;t falle gret toyle, And of that lond he wolde him spoyle; For he was gret of wasselage And loued with alle his baronage. Night and day the kyng then thought, How he my&yogh;t brynge that child to nought With sum sley&yogh;te priuily, That he were not schent ther-by. ¶ So longe he that a-boute sought MS. that caste a-boute sought ; perhaps caste aboute was the original, and our copyist tried to amend the rhyme aboute : thought by inserting sought , but forgot to cancel the caste ; sechen about occurs again l. 1687. , That it come thus in his thought, Off a wondur selcouthe gile To him by-traye that ilke while: He thought sende that ilke childe To Colkas,—that perilous Ilde, That was so fer out in the est,— To wynne that schepe, that wondur best, That neuere man In come and &yogh;ede a-gayn Out of that Ile for-sothe vn-sclayn. Therfore ther-at I most dwelle, The manere of that Ile to telle. BE-&yogh;onde the lond of Troye, gode men,— I trowe: of Iorneys more than ten— Ther was an Ile that het Colkos, That alle the fyght of Troye by ros; As I schal schewe by what skylle, When my matere comes ther-tille. These 'signatures' are all by a later hand. The comune sawe was thorow alle Grece: Ther was a schepe that bar a flece With-In that Ile, that was of gold, That neuere man that was on mold With strengthe, my&yogh;te, ne with gynne That ilke schepe myght not wynne; That schepe was y-kepid The k altered from l ; cp. l. 743. day & ny&yogh;t With Marc&yogh;, a MS. as. god of mykel my&yogh;t. Who-so wolde that schepe come to, Many thinges he most do: He most ferst fyghte with strong nete That were hidous & wondir grete, And out of here mouth thei keste fir And brende men [&] here atir; And whan he hadde the nete ouercomen, That thei were mate and alle be-nomen, Ther lay a plow MS. aplow. with alle þe gere,— And make hem drawe and that lond ere, He moste &yogh;oke hem in that plow, The bestes bolde—if that he mow— And make hem drawe and ere that lond And holde that plow faste with his hond, Til it were ered thorow and thorow. Whan he hadde turned eche eche partly erased in MS. a forow, ¶ He most fyght with a dragoun And scle him, if he may or kun; The dragoun was gret and meruelous, Off sight & body ful hidous; No man wiste non suche by north ne be southe, He keste brondes of fir out of his mouthe,— Ther was none suche In no land— Ther my&yogh;t no man his hete with-stand. The brennyng brondes þat from him wente Brende men In here garnement; Off thei were armed neuere so wel, He brend hem thorow Iren & stel. Whan he hadde sclayn that dragoun, Out of his hede he most takoun Alle his tethe with his owne hond And sowe hem in that ered lond; Whan that thei were In that lond, Quiklyche ther wold ther-of stond Stalworthe men, clene armed kny&yogh;tis, Lyuand men at alle mennes sightis, And fight to-gidre with brondes bry&yogh;t, Til echon hadde sclayn other with her my&yogh;t. By these periles and other mo Sicurly by-houes him to go, That wolde that schepe wynne or haue; Ther was neuere non that my&yogh;t him saue From these bestes and fro here hete, That he ne Inserted by a later hand over the line. scholde sone his lyf lete. ¶ When Pelleus was be-thought of this, He was Ioyful and glad y-wys, He thou&yogh;t egge Iasoun ther-tille Thedur to go on his fre wille; And so my&yogh;t he be most blameles And of his deth be holden giltles; For were he Inserted by a later hand over the line. went þidur fro home, He hoped neuere of his gayn-come. PElleus kyng send fer & ner Bothe Corour and Messanger Thorow his lond and bad hem crie That he wolde a Mangerie, A riche feste and a riale, And thedur schulde come gret & smale; He sente his lettres and his sond Afftir alle the grete of the lond,— To Erle, lord, and bold baroun,— And bad hem come to his toun, For ther wolde he his feste holde With ladies bry&yogh;t and kny&yogh;tes bolde. Whan thei were comyn, thei were alle glad With moche merthe that thei mad, Til thre dayes were fulli paast, This Mangeri then so longe so longe substituted for, and written (by the later hand) above atte ; atte is crossed out. laast. Pelleus kyng then—soth to say— Be-fore the lordes of that contray Spak to Iason, ther he stode Barehed with-outen hode,— He spak to him with fair semblaund, With louely chere and speche smyland; But it was fals and foule disseite, For he him be-thou&yogh;te thanne wel streite. ¶ He seide: 'Iason, my dere Cosyn, Thow art the beste kny&yogh;t of al my kyn, The worthiest man, the beste kny&yogh;t; I loue the wel—and that is ry&yogh;t— For I am douted and eke dred Off kyng & kny&yogh;t and less MS. lest . mys-bed Be the alone and thi prowes Then by my lond and my riches. I haue more Ioye of thi body Then of alle the lond of Thesaly, For thow art kny&yogh;t with-outen pere— Saue Ercules, that is thi fere.— I trowe that thow my&yogh;t fulfille Alle thyng that thow &yogh;af the tille; But if it were schepe ffelle! That I haue herd men of telle That is so hard for to wynne In that Ile ther he is Inne! And &yogh;it I hope—so haue I roo,— If thow woldest &yogh;eue the ther-too And put ther-to thi bysynes, Thow scholde it haue with-oute distresse. Then were thow kny&yogh;t of worschepe most Off alle that wones in any cost, If þow that flees with prowesse hadde; Then were I, Cosyn, of the gladde, For gret honour then dedest thow to me, And ther-by schuldest honoured be; And my lond afftir my day Schulde be thyn—as I say,— And also in my lyff treuly Thow schulde be lord as wel as I, And haue thi wille and thi comandement Off alle that euere to me apent.' IAson stode In his emys halle By-fore his Eme and lordes alle, He herkened alle that he euere MS. he euere he. sayd, With his wordes he was wel payd; The wordes ri&yogh;t wel to him liked, He wist nou&yogh;t that he was beswiked, He wende not the wordes that were spoken Of him so to be a-wroken, But for he scholde wynne gret loos And be þe more drad of his foos. He wiste wel if he seide 'nay' By-fore the lordes, that he schulde ay Holde him for a coward MS. acoward. And neuere-more of him take reward, But hope it were for cowardise That he durst not take a prise MS. aprise. . ¶ Iason seide: 'so mote I thriue, This feste schal neuere be don so blyue, That I ne schal be redi to go In-to that Ile, for wele or wo, What-so-euere schal be-tyde; I schal not longe thenne abyde, If it be so &yogh;e wil me fynde That nedeful is to mannes kynde: ¶ A strong schippe MS. schiþ. , and vitayles good, And other thynges that me by-hood, And worthi kny&yogh;tes In my companye, That proued ben In chyualrie. And I, my lord, to the schal brynge That golden flece, that worthi thynge, If I may wynne it with doughtinesse, Or any man with hardinesse.' ¶ When Pelleus herde his Cosyn speke, He wiste wel his othe he wolde not breke; He was Ioyful in his mod, He sais: 'Cosyn and al my blod! As thow art, my Cosyn, thi-self alone, Is non so strong of body ne bone; I schal fulfille al thy lykyng That thow hast nede In any thyng And nedeful is in that viage; The worthiest of my baronage For-sothe, Cosyn, schal wende with the; A strong schip schal ordeyned be, It schal be mad that &yogh;ow may bere, That the see do &yogh;ow no dere, That in the water &yogh;e ben not spilt; Al thyng schal be as thow wilt.' PElleus kyng was wonder blythe. A strong schip was mad swythe, Strong & wyde and wondir large, With his boot and his barge; The schippe that he made to Iason Afftir the wright was cleped 'Argon.' Whan it was mad with seyl and mast, Thei hyed hem to fille it fast,— With Mete and drynke it is wel frau&yogh;t,— And worthi kny&yogh;tes with him be-tau&yogh;t; To wende with him in his fere, Many a dou&yogh;ti kny&yogh;t was there. ¶ Among whiche was Ercules, The strongest kny&yogh;t that euere wes, That in that world was þanne levand; No man my&yogh;t his strok with-stand. This was he that men of speke, In erthe was non so my&yogh;ti freke, Kyng, ne kny&yogh;t, ne Champioun, In Ile, ne in regioun, That my&yogh;t with-stande that kny&yogh;tes strengthe The mountans of a dayes lengthe. ¶ This was he that strong man That al the world speke of can; He caste alle men that he wrasteled with, Were thei neuere so strong of lith. And Atthenes, the gode kny&yogh;t, He wrasteled with him with al his my&yogh;t, And Hercules him so hard thrist, That alle his ribbes al to-brast. This was he that in his dayes In batayles hard and gret affrayes He sclow geauntes with-outen tale, He wroght amonges hem gret bale; He sclow champiouns with-outen nombre, So manye that no man my&yogh;t hem vmbre. This was he that ilke kny&yogh;t, That was so strong & of so moche my&yogh;t. ¶ De Iasone. What schulde I speke more of his dedis? Eche man that of him redis Wot wele he was with-outen pere, Whil that he was lyuande here; I leue þer-fore and turne eft A-gayn to Iason ther-as I left. THis schippe was redi and set on-flote With his barge & his bote; Iason takis his leue to wende At Pelleus & at other frende; Hercules schal with him go. Ther-of schal rise al this wo, That Troie schal so foule be for-don, As I schal telle &yogh;ow sone. Thei are schepped now eche a wyght, The schip is &yogh;are & redi dight, Ther sail is drawe, the[i] wende forth faste, In-to the see thei ben forth paste. Thei sailen many a day and ny&yogh;t With many stormes lyght, Til thei were weri of the see; Thei wolde fayn at reste be: Vpon a day the mariner Saw a lond that was hem ner; Ther schip thei turned thedir prest, For on that lond to take here rest. Vpon that lond thei lepe vp alle, An[d] of ther teld thei made an halle, And ete & drank & made hem glad; Thei were fayn that thei lond had. The lond that thei were on lyght, The lond of Troye that tyme hight; Troie was not that tyme so strong, Ne so moche, ne so long, ¶ De Rege Lamedonie Troiani. Wyde, ne large, ne no-thyng toward, As it was sethen afftirward When Priamus hit made a-&yogh;eyn, When Lamedon, his fadir, was sclayn. ¶ The Greges hade seten but a stounde And made hem merie on the grounde, Or hit were told to Lamedon That men were lyght his lond vpon, Stout, & fers, and full gay, That wel be-semed of gret noblay; Thei wende thay wold hem robbe in hast, Or brenne that lond and leue it wast; Thei sayde: "it were good to wete here wille, Whether thei were comen for good or ille;"— 'And bidde hem go and rise And voyde this lond, if thei be wyse; Or &yogh;e schal hem honge and drawe, If thei dwelle til the day dawe. ¶ Lamedon called a gret lordyng, Wyse of speche & of beryng, And bed him go to hem anon, And take with him men gret won And bidde hem wende out of his lond, Or he wol reue hem foot and hond. ¶ This riche lord his hors hath hent And to the Gregeys he is went, And seyde: 'lordynges, so god me mende, Lamedon me to &yogh;ow sende, Oure kyng, and seys: him meruayles What &yogh;e thenken and what &yogh;ow ayles, Vpon his lond that &yogh;e aryue; And biddes &yogh;ow hye hennes blyue, That &yogh;e be not founden here to-morwen; For &yogh;if &yogh;e ben, &yogh;e be for-lorn. He wil &yogh;ow hewe lym and lythe, &YOGH;if he to-morwe may mete &yogh;ow withe. Voydes this lond and dos be my red,— Or sekirly &yogh;e ben alle ded!' ¶ Iason was al a-stonaid Off that þe kny&yogh;t thus to him said, He turned to his felawes ward: 'This kyng sais vs an ille forward To voyde his lond with-outen gilt, Or we schal elles alle be spilt; For-sothe he nys not curtays To vncouthe men that resten in pes In his lond vpon a brynke MS. abrynke. ,— That non ille do, ne non harm thenke, But reste vs here on this ryuage,— To sende vs suche a message MS. amessage. . But I se wel he loues vs litel That hates vs by suche a titel MS. atitel. , For we vpon his lond reste r corrected from l. ; He loues litel an vncouthe geste.' IAson thenne with heuy chere Turned him to the messangere; He sayde: 'lordying, I herde wel Al thi message euery del. God I drawe to oure wittenesse: We reste here for no wickednesse, But for to reste vs here a while MS. awhile. ; For we haue sayled many a myle MS. amyle. And weri ben bothe more & lesse And resten vs here for werinesse. But say thi lord, my leue frende, Out of his-lond that we schal wende; Say: "I se wel be his sonde, He wil we reste not on his londe." Belli inter Troianum & Grecos This—and before it: ' Caret rubrica '—written in a very fine hand. . And say him: "&yogh;it may this wel be qwyt By some that thow sest here sit." ' HErcules, that dou&yogh;ti kny&yogh;t, At Lamedon hadde gret dispit, He was Angered and alle a-rage Off this kyng and his message; Him thoughte for tene his herte to-brak That Iason then so mekely spak, He was not payed with his sawe 'Here now,' he says, 'felawe, What in erthe so thow art, Or he that sente the hidirward, Say thi kyng: "this day thre &yogh;er Or ere he schal se me her Vpon this place and other mo. Out of his lond wil I not go For his biddyng, but lye here stille Maugre his tethe, agayn his wille; For he schal be so ouer-sette, That we for him wol not lette To do oure wille and oure lykyng." Go and say thus to the kyng! Say him: "he has be-gunnen a strif, That he and his schal rewe his lyf"; And bidde him be sekir her-of & bold, And say that I him thus told!' ¶ Hercules his lippes gnowe For tene he hadde not folk y-nowe, That he als-tide and sir Iason Might not ffyght with Lamedon. But a-mong hem was no merie gale Off alle that ther were, grete & smale, Ther was not a schip ful of men, And thei were mo then thousandes ten De Rege Cete in Ciuitate Ieconite. Off bold kny&yogh;tes hardi & kene; What wolde thei alle to hem be sene! Thei gadered vp alle that ther lay And to thair schip thei toke the way And sailed forth vpon the see, Til thei wolde comyn ther thei wolde be In-to that Ile that hight Colkos. Eche a man on londe than gos, And leyde here sail thanne by the mast And lefft here schip teyghte fast.— And this þe forme skyl to schewe was, That Troie was lorn so foule a-cas, Driuen doun and foule distroyed; Ther-with were Troiens foule anyed, For thei of Grece reste on here land Fer fro the cete opon þat sand; For sir Iason and his nauee Sette & reste vpon the see, When thei wente out of Grece To wynne the schepis goldyn flece. IN Colkos Ile a Cite was, That men called thanne Reconitas MS. reconitas ; the r quite distinct, though the rubric has Ieconite. , Fair and mekel, large and long, With walles heye and wondir strong, Ful of toures and heye paleis Off riche kny&yogh;tes and burgeis. A kyng that tyme, that hete Cetes, Gouerned than that lond In pes; With his baronage and his meyne, Dwelleden thanne in that Cyte. For al aboute that riche toun Stode wodes and parkis enviroun, That were replenysched wondirful Off herte and hynde, bore and bul, And other many sauage bestis; Be-twix that wode and that forestis Ther was large contray & playn, Faire wodes & fair Champayn, Ful of semely rennyng welles— As the romaunce the sothe telles— With-oute the cete that ther sprong; Ther was of briddes michel sang Thorow alle the &yogh;er, and mykel cry, Off alle Ioyes gret melody. ¶ To that Cite & kyng Cetes &YOGH;ode Iason and Hercules And alle the felawes that he hadde, In clothes of gold as kynges be-cladde. When kyng Cetes his men herde say That Gregeys come in that aray, In his paleis he spak hem with, Alle in pees and loue & gryth; He ros him vp out of his se As curtais kyng and kny&yogh;t so fre, Out of his halle with mykel spede With his men agayn hem &yogh;ede MS. &yogh;ode. , And welcomed hem with louely chere And ledde hem bothe to-gedir in-fere And ther other ffelawes alle With gret worschepe In-to his halle. He dede hem sitte opon the benk, And bad his men bryng a drynk; When thei hadden dronken what her wille is, Sir Iason, the kny&yogh;t of pris, Tolde the cause of his comyng On fair manere to Cetes the kyng, And seyde "that he was comen to wynne,— If he myght spede,—of of is added above the line and ought to be deleted. the golden skynne. He prayed him ther of his gode wille, That he scholde graunte loude and stille Holly his landes ordenaunce MS. ordenanaunce. , If him my&yogh;t happen suche chaunce." ¶ The kyng graunted to fulfille His desir and alle his wille; The kyng bad with mylde wordes: "Anon thei scholde sette the bordes; Tyme hit was to sopere go," he sayde;— The bordes were set, the clothes layde. He called to him a kny&yogh;t MS. akny&yogh;t. wel hende And him afftir his dou&yogh;ter sende MS. wende. , And seide, sche scholde comen a-doun To glade his gestes of gret renoun. ¶ The kny&yogh;t Originally kny&yogh;tes in MS.; es erased. &yogh;ede to the mayden ffre, The kynges dou&yogh;ter, dame Mede, And bad here come with-outen dwellyng With here Maydenes to the kyng. Sche dwelled not longe—I vndirstonde:— Whan sche hadde herd here fadir sonde, Sche come doun vnto the table With contenaunce good and stable, And grette here fadir sikurly And other kny&yogh;tes that sete him by. He bede here go and sitte that tyde His vncouthe gest Iason be-syde; And Mede dede as here fadir bad, And of his biddynge was wel glad. Off this Mede, this worthi may, Sumwhat of here wol I say, Off here wisdom and of here beryng, Off here science & of here kunnyng: Sche coude the science of clergy And mochel of Nigramauncy; De Medee Filia Regis Ceti. In alle that lond [ne] was here pere As wide as men gos fer or nere, Ne that was to here half so scley Of cours of planetes and of the sky, Ne couthe so many enchauntement As coude Medee, that may gent. ¶ Sche coude with coniurisouns, With here scleyghte & oresouns, The day that was most fair & lyght Make as derk as any nyght; Sche coude also In selcouth wyse Make the wynde bothe blowe & ryse And make him so lowde blowe As it scholde houses ouerthrowe; Sche MS. He. couthe turne verement Alle wederes and the firmament, And here liked make it reyne And if here liked make it schyne. Sche coude do many selcouthe thyng: In somer when the leues spryng Make stormes hem to driue a-way And make trees drye as clay; Sche wolde also the trees that ware In wynter-tyde naked & bare Make hem florische a&yogh;eyn & bere, That wynter hem my&yogh;t not dere. In al the world was no man So kunnyng of wit and wisdam— As seyn these autours and these clerkes— As was Medee In here werkes. MEdee sette here doun to mete By-twene her lord and Iason to ete, Sche cast here eye wel offte vnfold That Ioyful kny&yogh;t to be-hold; So fair a kny&yogh;t at here likyng Sche saw neuere old ne &yogh;yng; Here hadde leuere than al Assye That he hadde ben in here baylye, Might sche brynge to that acord That he wolde be here lord; Gode in erthe! that Perhaps naught was in the original. sche desires, But that Iason were one of heres. Sche hadde here herte so on him set, Here eye my&yogh;t sche not fro him let; Sche loued him so wondirly tho, That sche wiste neuere what to do, But toke here leue and be-gan to go To the chambur that sche come fro. ¶ Vnto the chambur sche is comyn, Loue hath here so vndir-nomyn, That trauayles here wondir strong With thought and sykyng euere among; Sche thenkith bothe day & ny&yogh;t How sche that loue performe my&yogh;t With-outen schame and vylonye, That sche were not reproued ther-by; Fayn sche wolde haue here wille, But sche my&yogh;t not come ther-tille. ¶ And thus leued sche fourtene ny&yogh;th In gret wo as any wy&yogh;th: Til hit be-fel vpon a day That kyng Cetes—soth to say— And Iason were to-gedur set And bad here men Medee doun fet In-to the halle of his paleis, To talke with the kny&yogh;tes curteis. Off the tydynges was Medee blithe: To hem doun sche come swythe; ¶ De Iasone. And he bad here sitte be Iason,— That al here loue was vpon,— And speke with him In fair manere, As Mayden schulde to bachelere. Medee did his comaundement; But Cetes was ther-with ablent: He wist not of Medee wille That sche loued Iason stille. ¶ When Iason saw that worthi wyght So sitte on benche by him right, He was wel glad, as him gon thenk; Ercules ros vp of the benk, And he sat be that worthi wenche To wete what that mayden dede thenke. ¶ Kyng Cetes with-oute doute Spak to the kny&yogh;tes him aboute, Of Ercules asked tydynges, At other kny&yogh;tes of other thynges; So to him &yogh;af no man gome, Kny&yogh;t ne sqwyer, lord ne grome. Medee say that sche was brou&yogh;t To telle Iason of here thou&yogh;t ¶ With-oute heryng of any wyght: 'Sir Iason,' sche seide, 'thow art a kny&yogh;t MS. akny&yogh;t. Off whiche I haue mochel rewthe And gret compassioun, be my trewthe! For I se wel and haue in mynde That thow art comen of gentil kynde, And art a louely MS. alouely. creature, And art hardy with-oute mesure; For I se wel—and sothe hit is— That thyn heye herte and thi hardines Hath brou&yogh;t the fro the lond of Grece For to wynne the golden flece, ¶ De Medee. Thorow whiche—is a sothe thyng— Thow schalt go to thyn endyng. And I haue gret pyte Off thi manhede and beute, That thow thus foule schalt be spilt For a schepis MS. aschepis. skyn that is ouer-gilt. Ther-fore I &yogh;eue the consayle— The beste that the may a-vayle— That thow wende hom hole and sound, A-&yogh;eyn to thi lond with-oute any wound.' ¶ Iason thanne with chere deuout Vnto that lady gan lout And seyde louely, curtays & fre: 'A thousand tymes I thanke it the Of thi goodnes and thi curtasye, That thow hast reuthe of my folie; For &yogh;oure biddyng outerly I put for-sothe al my body.' 'SWete Iason, my louely frend,'— Saide Medee, that mayden hend,— 'Has thow not the sothe herd telle Off that flece and the gret perille? Or thow knowest not the sothe That makes the so bold of othe, Thow may ther-to make assay And lese thi my&yogh;t and thi noblay. For sekurly ther was neuere kny&yogh;t That hadde that strengthe and that my&yogh;t, That my&yogh;t with his hardinesse That flece wynne with dou&yogh;thtinesse: For it is keped bothe nyght and day With oure god Mars, that alle thyng may; For ther is no man on lyue, Agayn oure god that may stryue. Ther-fore I praye &yogh;ow for loue or awe: Fro that perile &yogh;ow with-drawe, That thow deye not thus sodenly For a lytel foly!' ¶ Iason seyde: 'my lady dere, Of this kepe I no more to here! Wene &yogh;e my hert so to stere, Or with &yogh;oure wordes me to dere, That I schulde this thing for-sake That I gan ferst vndirtake? Me were leuere certes to deye Than to do that vylonie! For now I haue it be-gonne, And I &yogh;ede hom, or it were wonne— Me were leuere I were vnbore Then suche a schame were me before! For my deth schal I not lette,— If that I may,—that flece to fette!' MEdee seide: 'my derlyng, Is it thi wil for any thyng To putte thi deth be-fore thi lyff And to putte the to that stryff? I haue pite of thi ded, But I schal &yogh;eue the suche a red MS. ared. , That thow schalt come a-&yogh;eyn ful rathe And wynne that schepe with-outen skathe— If it be so thow wilt fulfille Mi desire and my wille.' 'Lady,' Iason thanne sayde, 'Of that &yogh;e sayn I holde me payde: What &yogh;e schul in erthe ordeyne, I schal holde it for prow or payne The while that I am leuyng— I drawe to witnes god, oure kyng!' ¶ Medee sayde to Iason than: 'If thow wilt be so trewe a man MS. aman. , That thow wilt hete me to wedde, And as thi spouse to brynge me to bedde, And leue me neuere for wele ne wo, And graunt me home with the to go Out of this lond that is fair,— Off whiche I schal be qwene and ayr,— Vnto thi lond, to thi hous, And wedde me there to thi spous: I wolde make the that schepe-fel Wynne to-morwe with-outen perel.' IAson sayde to Medee: 'Riche bene that thow proferest to me: &YOGH;oure-self to be in my bandoun And al in my subieccioun, That art the fairest that lyf beres Or any clothe on erthe weres; And also to saue me Off alle perile that ther-Inne be, And do me wynne that flece of golde, That no man may do that leues on molde With-oute &yogh;oure help, my derlyng! That is to me a fair proferyng! Body and herte to &yogh;ow I profre, And alle my-self to &yogh;ow I offre: I take &yogh;ow here my trowthe I-ply&yogh;t MS. I. ply&yogh;t. , That I schal neuere by day ne ny&yogh;t Do not a-&yogh;eyn &yogh;oure lykyng Ne forthermore neuere of &yogh;oure byddyng! And I schal with me &yogh;oure-self lede In-to my lond—so god me rede!— And wedde &yogh;ow there vnto my wyff And leue &yogh;ow neuere whil me last lyff!' Off that beheste was Medee fayn, But &yogh;it sche wolde be more certayn That he schulde here no-wayes be-gile Ne holde here afftir for no vile. Sche sayde: 'Iason, be thow not wroth! I wole that thow me make an oth, That thow schalt trewly & trusly holde Of alle that thow hast sayde & tolde; For no-wayes we may not now Do this thyng be-twene vs two. I wol that thow when day is gon Come to my chambre sone anon, When I schal sende aff[t]ir the, That thow alway come to me; And than schaltow make thi surment Opon my god with sacrament, And swere me ther by that god Alle this to holde for euen or od. And when thow hast thus wrou&yogh;th & don, Al thi wil schal I graunte son.' ¶ Iason seyde: 'my ladi fre, As &yogh;e haue seyd, so schal it be! When &yogh;e haue afftir me send, Wightlyche schal I to &yogh;ow wend.' And thus were thei bothe at one Vpon the benche hem-self alone And toke leue thenne and ros; Vnto here Chambre faste sche gos. MEdee is vnto here chambre gone, And here maydenes euerychone. Here thought longe vnto nyght, That sche my&yogh;t speke with that kny&yogh;t. When ny&yogh;t was comyn and day past, And alle in bedde vpon sclepe fast, Sche cleped a mayden MS. amayden. that het Ane,— So trewe a mayden MS. amayden. hath sche nane,— And bad here pryuili to go And MS. A d . say: "Iason schuld come here to." And Ane &yogh;ede wel priuyli And bad him come to here lady; And he ros bothe blythe and glad And dede as the mayden bad. And whan thei were to-gedur met, Ane that him thedur fet &YOGH;ede here way with-oute more And lefft hem to-gedur thore. ¶ Whan Medee saw Iason ther-In, Sche sperid the doris with a pyn And bad him sitte doun vpon here bed,— With riche clothes hit was spred. That faire lady, that louesom brid, A Craffty cofre sche vn-did And toke out an ymage, frely dyght With fele torches and mochel lyght, That MS. Ther. sacrid was In Iouis name. 'Iason,' seide that faire dame, 'Thow schalt thin hond on this god lay And thow schalt holde that I schal say: On this ymage thow schalt swere, Faith & treuthe thow schalt me bere, And wedde me to thy wyff, And leue me neuere whil I haue lyff.' ¶ Iason sayde: 'my trewthe I layd, To do al as thow hast sayd.' And layde his treuthe on that ymage To MS. And. take here the terme of his age. When sche hadde take of him that oth, Thei caste of hem euery cloth ¶ Iason concubuit cum Medee. And &yogh;ede bothe in-to a bed,— With riche clothes hit was spred. Alle that ny&yogh;t to-gedur thei lay, Til it was nere a-gayn the day. Iason sayde: 'my derlyng dere, It is not good to dwelle here; But say me now, my derlyng, Wolt thow ordeyne for me o thyng, That I my&yogh;t thorow thi techyng My purpos wele to ende bryng? For al the haste that I haue Is, swetyng,—so god me saue— Out of this Ile the to lede In-to my lond with-outen drede.' ¶ Sche seyde: 'Iason, I am al &yogh;are, When thow art redi, With the to fare! Rise we now vp! I schal the kenne With the neet that the ne brenne. For-&yogh;ete thow not my kennyng For no ferdnesse of brennyng!' ¶ Iason thenne and sche vp ros; And Medee to here forsure gos, And drow out relikes manye & gode, And toke Iason ther he stode And tau&yogh;t him how he scholde do, When he that Ile come to, That he were not with nete ybrend, Ne with the dragoun y-schend. ¶ &YOGH;it of the forsure the lady rau&yogh;te A fair ymage and him by-tau&yogh;te, And bad him sclely with him bere,— For sorcery schuld him not dere: For it was alle with sorcery wroght, Alle sorcery it brou&yogh;te to nought. And afftir that Medee out hente A wel riche oynemente And an-oynted alle his body, Visage and alle witterly: For hit for-did al brennyng of ffire, Off hit brende neuere so schire. ¶ And afftirward that fair swetyng By-tau&yogh;t Iason a riche MS. ariche. ryng, That alle venym for-dede & strued,— That he schul not be venym-noyed That bar that riche ryng on him: For it fordede alle venym. MEdee tok with him thanne a writ, And him bad he schuld bere it; And when he come with-Inne that Ile, That he schulde with herte mylde On his knees him doun sette, Er he that flece &yogh;ede to fette; And thries he scholde hit ouer-rede; That he ne lefft for no drede. ¶ Sche toke him thenne a riche MS. ariche. licour,— A viole ful of gode sauour,— And bad he schulde that lycour poure, When he come In-to the stoure, In the mouthes of the neete, For hit was wondur cleuand wete; Then scholde thei holde here mouth to-gedur And make no more so foule a wedur:— 'For if thow konne this in here mouthe throwe, Thei schal no more no fir blowe!' ¶ Iason seide: 'I thonk it the, That thow hast thus ordeyned for me! I hope, or it be euenyng, That golden flece to the bryng.' He toke his leue at that may, In-to his Chambre he tok the way, Ther-In he lay and Hercules; Wel stille he lay doun in pes, Til it was cler day and lyght, That the sunne schon wel bryght: He ros vp and come him doun, And alle his felawes enviroun. OVt of his bed is Iason rysen, To wende his way he is not grysen, To wynne the schepe,—if he haue grace,— Now he these thinges of Medee has. He is comyn in-to the halle With Hercules and his men alle; To Cetes the kyng he is forth went. He asked anon, what it be-ment, He asked at him and at hisen, Whi he was so erly rysen. 'Sir,' he saide, 'be godis ore! That I thus dwelle me rewes sore; I wol ther-fore make asay To wynne the flece—if I may:— &YOGH;eue me leue and lete me go, That I no lenger be ther-fro.' ¶ Cetes saide: 'I haue gret drede, That thow be dede and not wel spede; I schal therfore haue harm and schame, For men wol rette on me the blame; But that thow art of wil so bold, That I may not at home the hold— God, that this world made round, Brynge the a&yogh;eyn hol and sound!' ¶ Then was Iason wondir blythe, He toke his armure and tyred him swythe, ¶ Qualiter Iason fecit bellum. And &yogh;ede forth the schepe to wynne To that Ile that he was Inne. When he was comen ther it was, Ther he schulde ouer the water pas In-to that Ile In-to a bote MS. abote. , He kest his armes In fote hote And rowed ouer with an ore. When he was ouer that watur thore, He armed him—as he coude wele— Bothe in Iren and in stele, And on his hed thanne sette His trewe and trusti basenette, And kest his scheld a-boute his hals, And bere his spere with him als; And &yogh;af aboute him ful good kepe, If he my&yogh;t be war of the schepe. And thedirward Iason him drow, To wynne the flece—if he mow. IAson is now on londe lyght, Armed wel and nobly dyght. When he was comen to that stede, Ther he saw the schepes trede, On the first thenne was he ware, Where the nete were standyng thare, Kestyng fir with-oute sese Of her mouthe with-oute relesse, That alle the sky with-oute doute Was on fire alle a-boute. But he thought then on his swetyng, Of dame Medee and her kennyng: Ful radly thenne the boyste he hent That was with the oynement; Al his visage and his face Anoynted ther-with sone he hase. He toke also that ymage bry&yogh;t That was of siluer made & dy&yogh;t, And hanged it aboute his hals a-boue,— As Medee him bad do so for here loue,— And turned it to the fir anon, And the nete stood and loked ther-on; And sette him doun meke & wyse And redde his writ thanne thryse, And when it was thries red, To go to hem was not dred. His perel thanne a-wey was rau&yogh;t, And with this nete faste he fau&yogh;t: The flaume of fir thenne on him caste And brende his gode scheld on haste, And his spere to his hond To coles hit fel vpon the sond. HE toke thenne that licour wete And poured qwyk into the nete; And when it was with-Inne ther r by a later hand. lippes, Faste to-gedur hit hem grippes, That thei my&yogh;t not her mouth vn-spere, With hete Iason no more to fere. When Iason hem thus discomfit Thorow dame Medee that was perfit, And saw a-boute that the aire Was good and clene and ful fair, And the nete myght fyght no more Thorow here kennyng and here lore, He toke hem be the hornes long And here hedes a-boute wrong, And loked, if thei were tame ynow, And ladde hem thanne vnto the plow, And &yogh;oked hem and dede hem drawe, And turned that lond with-outen awe. When he hadde don, he toke his way To the dragoun ther he lay; And the dragoun sey him ney, He made thanne an MS. and. hidous cry, And hissed loude, and brondes blew, Fyr faste on Iason he threw, And spitte venym and keste aboute; But Iason ther-of hadde no doute: Whan he herde that how loude he hissed, Iason dede as he was wissed, He toke the ryng that sche toke him For drede of fir & of venym,— That bare a stone MS. astone. , was fair and grene,— And held hit sone hem be-twene, And keste it doun be-fore his syght. And whan the dragoun saw that lyght MS. lyght , altered from syght. , He lefte the fir and his brennyng And al foule venym of his spittyng, And loked stabli on that ston, And he beheld euere ther-on, And whil the dragoun ther-to &yogh;aff tent, His swerd Iason out hent And smot the hed fro the bouke, And the ryng with him toke MS. toke , altered from boke. And in hold he gan hit do. And when he hadde sclayn him so, He wente—and so he my&yogh;t wele— And drow his tethe out of his chavele, And sewe hem thanne vpon the land That he hadde ered on that sand. Armed men of hem ther sprong, And echon on other faste dong, Til alle were sclayn that were thore; On lyue leffte there none wore. ¶ When Iason saw that ther was an ende Off alle that wondir enchauntemende, Toward the schepe be-gan he go With-oute drede him to sclo: With bothe his handes the schepe he sclow, And fro the body the skyn he drow, And bare with him that schepes skyn With mochel Ioye & mochel wyn, Til he come to his bote; And lepe In with a merie MS. amerie. note, And ouer to his felawes rode, Ther Hercules him a-bode,— Wondir blythe, Ioyful, and glad That thei on lyue him had. ¶ Iason thenne and his Gregeis Rode to Cetes & to his paleis; When Cetes saw that Ioyful kyng Iason that schepes skyn bryng, He hadde ther gret envy That he raff him that drury; But euel semblant my&yogh;t he non make For Hercules and Iason sake, But dede hem sitte by his side And fair semblaunt made him that tyde. Then come &yogh;ong and old The schepes skyn to be-hold, Thei hadde of Iason gret meruayle, How he it wan in batayle A&yogh;ens thair goddis wil and my&yogh;t; Thei hadde meruayle of suche a kny&yogh;t. IAson now the flece hath wonne, The tydynges thorow the Cete is ronne, Many a man come him to see, Ther he was set by dame Medee. He dwellyd ther a ful mon[i]the Cf. ll. 1686 and 9407. , And Hercules kyng Cetes withe,— And til a tyme that he & sche, And Hercules and his meyne, Stale away with-Inne a ny&yogh;t And &yogh;ede to schepe by sterre ly&yogh;t; And drow vp sail, and scheped sone, And wente hom forth by the mone. The wynd be-gan to rise & to blowe And brou&yogh;t hem home in a throwe To the lond of Thesalye, Iason and his companye. ¶ The word was told to Pelleus blyue b perhaps altered from v. "That Iason was comen hom alyue, And how he hadde brou&yogh;t in-to Grece"— 'For-sothe' thei seyden—"the golden flece." Wo was him of tho tythandis: He wrong to-gedir bothe his handes For sorwe and wo and care of herte, That he was comen home in qwerte. But when he saw him comande, He wente a-&yogh;eyn him with fair semblande, And welcometh him wel home, And was glad of his come, And thonked god that he ferd wele, And &yogh;af him the lond, eche a dele Off Thesalye that lond aboute, So he be-het him, or he wente oute. ¶ With this lond was he not payd; He wolde be venged algate—he sayd— Off Lamedone, the kyng of Troyene, For he him dede reproue and tene. To Hercules wel offte he spake: "That he that charge wolde take; ¶ Hic Incipit Bellum. For elles my&yogh;t it not come to ende;"— 'For thow hast many a noble frende, Many a kny&yogh;t MS. akny&yogh;t. , and many a kyng, And wil be fayn at thi byddyng.' Hercules seyde: 'ne drede the nou&yogh;t! Ful wel to ende it schal be brou&yogh;t To my worschepe, if my lyf last, Or this &yogh;ere be ful past. Haue thow no care, ne make no mone! But let me here with-al alone! I schal so venge oure vilonye, That thay schal ful sore abye.' HErcules the charge hath tane; He thenkes to be that kynges bane, He thenkes him scle with his hond, If he may come to his lond. At hom is he no lenger wol he erased after lenger. abiden, To Sportes is that kny&yogh;t reden,— That was a lond of Romanye altered from Romayne. ,— Ther two bretheren were were ought to be struck out. of chiualrye Regned Inne by ther dayes. Hercules ther the bretheren prayes To wende with him ouer the see, With armed folk a gret meyne, To venge him on kyng Lamedon, That kest him out and sir Iason Off his lond, whan thai hem reste, That dede him nother noye ne breste. The bretheren bothe as kny&yogh;tes hende Thai were redi with him to wende,— What day that he wolde assygne,— With many worthi kny&yogh;tes and digne. Castor hete that on brother, And Pollus called men that other. Hercules toke leue at hom And rode hym to Salom, A lond that was to Grece longand, That Thelaman thenne held held inserted by a later hand above the line. in his hand That was kyng of gret renoun, An hardy kny&yogh;t, a bold MS. abold. baroun. He prayed him that he wolde go With him and other kynges mo, That were of Grece, ouer the see, Troye to brenne, that hye cete, And venge him of that foule dispite That Lamedon dede with gret vnri&yogh;te— Not long tyme sithen past,— That he him of his lond cast. ¶ Thelaman seide: "hit schuld be don, He was al redi at his bon To wende with him, as good and hende, Whan he aftir him wol sende." Hercules thanne rode a-&yogh;eyn— Off his be-heste he was ful fayn— To Polleus kyng and bad that he Schuld gader faste alle his meyne, And alle that he my&yogh;t with written by a later hand over line between my&yogh;t and purchase(s). purchase MS. purchases. , By loue, or awe, or any manace MS. manaces. . ¶ He tok him thanne the nexte way To Pilon lond—right as I say;— Pylon was a lond also That longed that tyme Grece to, And duk Nestor was lord and sire Dux Nestor On the left side in MS. . Ouer al that lond and that Empire;— And prayed him of his ffraunchesse ss perhaps written by the later hand. That he wolde wende with him and hesse The first s added by the later hand. , To venge him on that kyng vilayn, And helpe that he were ded and sclayn; And reue al his bothe lyff and lym, That wolde not soffre Iason ne hym On day reste to take, Nother for prayer ne for sake. ¶ Duk Nestor seide to Hercules: 'I am al &yogh;are with-outen les To wende with the at thy biddyng, And kny&yogh;tes fele with me to bryng, To venge the of that vilonye And do him knowe his folye. I schal make me and myne &yogh;are With-outen dwellyng with the to fare.' ¶ Hercules was thanne wel blythe, A&yogh;ayn to Pelleus &yogh;ode he swythe. A[nd] whan he come to Thesalye, He fonde a louely MS. alouely. companye Of kynges and kny&yogh;tes to-gedur thore, That for his help comen wore: For thanne was comen Thelaman, That dou&yogh;ti kyng, that noble man; And the bretheren bothe two, Castor kyng and Pollus also, With alle here men and here nauee Stondyng redi on the see; And Pelleus was al redi dy&yogh;t With many a bold baroun and kny&yogh;t; And here schippes were vitayled, Ther mete and drynke schal non be fayled. Alle the kynges bene now to-gedur, And hit was ful meri wedur: That Marche was passed and Feuerer, Hit was that tyme of the &yogh;ere, It was in-myddis of Averille; T[h]e wedir was clere, the wynd was stille. And alle these kynges to schip &yogh;ede First e indistinct in MS., might be o. To taken the see with-oute drede; Thei sayled forth day and ny&yogh;t, Til thei hadde of Troye a sy&yogh;t MS. asy&yogh;t. . The sunne was set and al away doune, Thanne thei hadde syght ferst of the toune. Thei toke the hauen, whan it was derk, With-outen wetyng of prest or clerk, And kest here ankyr on that sond And &yogh;ede alle vpon the lond, For ther was non that euere hem lette; Hit was longe afftir the sonne sette, That no man wiste of thair comyng, Kny&yogh;t ne sqwier, ne the kyng. Eche man thanne his hors oute hentes, And drow out Armure & here tentes, Speres, dartes, helmys, and scheldes; Thei sette here pauylons & here teldes, And sette here wacche ouer-al abowte, That thei my&yogh;t reste with-oute dowte. THe Gregeis ben londit and proud y-pyght With gay tentis arayed aryght. Longe ar the day be-gan to sprynge, Pelleus sent aboute tythynge To eche a kyng that there he lay To come to him, or it were day. Thei come echone to wete his wille; When thei were comen and set doun stille, Pelleus seide: 'my bretheren dere, Now we ben to-gedur here, Me thenketh it were good to speke, How we my&yogh;t sonest vs wreke Off oure fomen and oure enemys, To oure worschepe and to oure pris; And saue vs fro perele, How so it euere it be-fele, And take the toun with my&yogh;t and wyn, And alle that euere is ther-In.' HErcules, that dou&yogh;ti man, Be-fore alle other to speke he gan: 'Seres'—he sayde—'&yogh;oure skylles is good, As &yogh;e haue seide, so vs be-hood. This is myn avisement, How thei schal sonest be schent: &YOGH;iff &yogh;e wole alle that it be so, That we parte oure men atwo— Er it be day and sonne vp-rise,— That we be seuered in alle wise: And &yogh;e, sir kyng, and Thelaman, And I also, and sir Iason, Schal be to-gedre In that on ende; To the toun and we schal wende, Er it be day or any lyght, That no man of vs haue a syght: For we schal hide vs In the vynes, And when the sonne is vppe and rises, We schal holde vs stille and coy By-side the &yogh;atis with-oute Troy. And kyng Pollus, and duke Nestor, And his brother kyng Castor, Schal beleue here on the see With alle here folk and here naue. And Nestor schal ferst with hem dele With alle his men and his eschele, And Castor schal be my red haue The secunde warde—so god me saue!— And kyng Pollus schal haue the thridde With alle the men that are him myd. ¶ And when the kyng hath tydandes, That we are restid on his landes, And he comes out with his baronage To fyght with hem on this ryuage, We schal entre in-to the toun And breke the walles & throwe hem doun, And scle that we ther-Inne fynde, Honge, and brenne, and faste bynde, And do dye that vs dos MS. do dos. dere. Then schal we turne to were And scle hem alle for vs & &yogh;ow. And thus thynketh me most for oure prow, When thei may not fro vs fle On no syde to no contre.' ¶ The kyng sayde: 'as haue I roo!'— "That hit was good his rede to do, Better red schuld thei haue non To confounden sone here fon." Thei parted here men In two parties; And Hercules with his he hies Vndir the toun In the greues And hides him there in the leues; And duk Nestor lefft stille thore With alle that with him wore. HIt is ly&yogh;t day, the sonne is hye, And Hercules the toun is nye With-Inne the greues, ther leues sprynge; And Lamedon has herd tydynge That thay of Grece with gret feute Bene in his hauene with gret naue. He armed him with-outen any bode With alle his men and to hem rode, With scheld and spere an[d] swerd in hande; ¶ Hic veniunt ad pugnandum. And whan Nestor saw hem comande, He ordeyned him with-oute drede With alle his men, and to hem &yogh;ede; And ther be-gan a strong cuntre, Lamedon his dethe ther hent he; He and his were wood opri&yogh;t, Or endit were that fy&yogh;t. LAmedon is armed wel, His stede is trapped In iren & stel; Out of the toun is he now ryden, And his men, that he hath bydden To go with him that ought were worthe, Now are thei alle to-gedur forthe, In-myddes the feld out of the toun Ridyng ouer dale and doun, Toward the see to the Gregeis That he sei stonde in here harneis, Redi dight with hem to ffyght With scheldes brode and swerdes bryght. ¶ The Gregeis were not of hem dred; Nestor that the vanwarde led, Whan he saw hem come to him ward, He busked to hem as hard And toke the feld brod and large With Many a scheld MS. ascheld. , target, and targe; And kepe him euene in the berd, For he was nou&yogh;t of him aferd. A dredful dyn my&yogh;t men thenne here, A carful noyse, a dredful MS. adredful. bere: When thei were met to-gedur on hepis, Euery man on other lepes, And beris him doun, & throwys him vndur, And leues him him written by a later hand over line. dede stryken asondur; A fel batayle was ther by-gonnen, When thei were alle to-gedur ronnen. The noyse was gret, the speres brake, Whan eche man mette with his make; Some were ded and thorow born, And some hondes or legges lorn, Some were wounded to the dethe, Some my&yogh;t not drawe her brethe; Helmes were holed, and scheldes cloven, With grete strokes here hedes houen. Kny&yogh;tes were feld, stedis strayed; Wel bolde barons bledde and brayed, To ther deth then were thei dy&yogh;th With swerdes scharpe and brondis bry&yogh;th. Gret sclau&yogh;ter was be-twene hem there, When Troye and Grece to-gedur were. But Troiens with gret multitude At the laste hadde strokes rude, But &yogh;it a-bak thei droff alle Nestor men Ouer mose and ouer ffen. ¶ But when that noble kyng Castor Saw how thei ferde with the duke Nestor, And saw how he a-bak was dreuen, And his scheld with strokes reuen,— With alle his men thedur he hyed And hertely the Troiens defied. CAstor kyng, that dou&yogh;ti kny&yogh;t, Is comen doun to that fy&yogh;t, To helpe Nestor, that worthi duk, That he se Troyens so rebuk. He sclow Troyens—as he were wode,— He bare hem doun and schedde her blode; So bitterly ferd he with: Agayn hem hadde thei no gryth, Thay my&yogh;t no more with-stande his myght, So he was fers, stalworthe, and wyght. And so thei fou&yogh;ten and were wery, Off his strokes thei were sory. ¶ But Lamedon, that dou&yogh;ti kyng, When he saw his men fleyng, With alle the men In his warde He ran thedur as a lyparde, And sclow Gregeis here and there As a lyon fers and fere. He felde doun some, and some fflow, And of here hors doun hem drow, And lete hem lye, and some storuen, Sore woundid and al for-koruen, Many he greued and al to-hewed; That he was kny&yogh;t, ful wel he schewed: He ferd with hem so sorily, That thay discomfith were wel ny. BVt when Pollus saw that syght, The Gregeis were so discomfyght: With alle his men he thedur ran And sclow of the Troyens many a man. Many men was be-twene hem sclayn, When thei were alle on the playn To-gedur mette with thaire batayles; Eche man other ther assayles. ¶ But Lamedon saw, his men fau&yogh;t Ouer my&yogh;t and out of mau&yogh;t,— What with loue and what with awe,— A litel a-bak he made hem drawe And gedered hem alle on an hepe As a witti kyng, my&yogh;ti, and &yogh;epe. ¶ Duke Nestor aboue his scheld Lamedon that tyme be-held: He saw alle men do his byddyng, He hoped therfore, he was here kyng. Alle thynges lefft—to him he &yogh;ede, To scle him, if he my&yogh;t spede. ¶ But Lamedon saw him comande Towardes him with spere In hande, He smytes his stede and slakes his rayne, And rod to him as faste a-gayne An[d] brak his spere in many a splent MS. asplent. On duk Nestor In that dynt; He harmed him nou&yogh;t worth a thong MS. athong. , For his Armes were so strong, And elles hadde he ben sclayn With Lamedon on the playn. ¶ But Nestor on an-other wyse Smot Lamedon by-fore al hyse: He smot him on his scheld so That he cleue hit euen In-two, And bare him doun to the grounde And &yogh;af him there an hidous wounde; But he lepe vp with gret spede, When he was born thus fro his stede, And drow his swerd raply & smert— As hardi man and bold of hert— And made him romme aboute and way To duke Nestor—the sothe to say. A Newe-made kny&yogh;t, that hy&yogh;te Cedar, Off Lamedon, his lord, was war Among that prese faught on fote; He thou&yogh;the to do ther-of gode bote b altered out of u. : He smot Nestor on his gold plate, That he &yogh;ede doun in-myddes the gate; He bar him fro his hors in fyght By-fore his lord, in the kynges syght. Whan Lamedon saw Nestor felde, He thoght his strok scholde be &yogh;elde That he &yogh;af him at her Iustyng: Lamedon, that worthi kyng, He hyed him faste to Nestor tho And &yogh;af strokes y-nowe and mo, He brak his coyfe and his ketil-hat, That to his hed sore it sat. He smot him so ryght in the face, That he hath lorn his solace; For he was ther so for-bled And with that kyng so ouerled, That he hadde dyed and ben for-don, Ne hadde him come socour son. ¶ But then come to that stour Many a Grek MS. agrek. to his socour And fro the kyng of Troye him reffte, And elles had he his lyff ther leffte; Out of the pres [thei] him ladde, For of his lyff were thei adradde. And Lamedon, that dou&yogh;ti man, A noble stede the whiles wan And lep vp qwyk with-oute fayle And strok forth in that batayle. ¶ Pollus brother, kyng Castor, Saw Cedar, that felde duke Nestor; Wo was him for that fallyng, He thou&yogh;th to make of him vengyng: He rode to him, as he were wode, Vpon a stede MS. astede. worth mechel gode. ¶ But ther be-fel another kny&yogh;t, That was of Troye, Secundam hy&yogh;t,— He was of Cedar blod and kyn, He was seker his ney cosyn,— He saw, how Castor wolde haue him smetyn Sydlyng, or he hadde weten, That wold he for non aw&yogh;t: Be-twene hem the strok he caw&yogh;t And brast on kyng Castor his spere; But he my&yogh;t not him doun bere, Castor spere was tow and strong,— Ther was non strenger in al that throng;— He smot Secundam in the syde A gret wounde and a wyde MS. awyde. . WHen Cedar saw his Cosyn woundid, He was for del al confounded: With drawen sword—as a wode man— Cedar thanne to Castor ran; Cedar than in that wode brayd On Castor so wonderly layd, That his helm al to-roffe, And his basenet to his hed droffe. He wounded him in his visage For his ffoly and his outrage, That hit in alle his lyff was sene,— And feld him doun vpon the grene; And his stede from him cau&yogh;t And his sqwyer him by-tau&yogh;t. ¶ Now Castor is from his hors born, His stede was taken and fro him lorn; Opon his fete he stode and fau&yogh;t, Many a strok MS. astrok. Cedar him rau&yogh;t, And other mo that ther dede stande. But kyng Pollus was ner-hande And saw, how Cedar & many other Ferd with kyng Castor, his MS. Castoris. brother; Kyng Pollus then come him ney Thedur with al his company, He hadde with him In his eschele Seuen hundrid kny&yogh;tes gode and lele. He ferde as he hadde y-raued, So fayn he wolde his brother haue saued. He rod thanne al aboute To his fomen with gret route, And amonges hem [made] ful gret pay; To his brother he made him way, And halp him fro his foos hondes, And felde Troyens on the sondes, And brou&yogh;t to Castor the Troyes stede, And halp him vp at his gret nede. POlleus kyng brende as the fyr For gret wratthe, onde & ir MS. hir. , That he had so his brother dyght And warisched him of his myght. He saw a kny&yogh;t agayn him— His name was Eliachim, The kynges sone Sartaginis, And Lamedon Cosyn also y-wys— He smot the kny&yogh;t with al his my&yogh;t Ryght be-fore the kynges sy&yogh;t, That he died be-fore his eyen With mechel wo and mechel pyn. ¶ Kyng Lamedon that be-held His cosyn dyed In the feld, &YOGH;eld the gost be-fore him there, He wepte for him ful many a tere MS. atere. . He sette his horn to his mouthe And blew thries, as he wel couthe; When he hadde blowen the thridde blast, The kny&yogh;tes come aboute him fast, Thei asked him, what him was; Lamedon saide to hem: 'alas! Se &yogh;e not my cosyn dere Lye be-fore me ded here, The kynges sone of Artage? Pollus sclow him In his rage. Now with alle the myght that &yogh;e konne Venge now my sistir sone!' ¶ When Lamedon hadde thus spoken Off his fomen to be wroken, Among the Grues then he presed And sclow many, or he sesed: He bare kynges and lordes doun Off gret prise and gret renoun; The Troyens then sclow the Grues, That thei for wo chaunged thaire hewes; Thei were wounded and sore ybete, For thei were so ouersete, Thei fledde a-way and lefft here place; The Troyens thanne hem gon chace And droff hem to the sees bank, And hewes of hem armes & schank. The Gruwes for-sothe hadde deye[d] alle— So wo that tyme hem was by-falle With gret wo and encomber MS. encombrer. — Ne hadde ther come a messanger MS. amessanger. Out of Troye and brou&yogh;t tydynges To hem of Troye and to here kynges: "That proude Griffons hath taken his toun And robbed hit and caste it doun, And sclayn alle that thei ther founde Stark ded vpon the grounde." And he him-self that brou&yogh;th tythand Might not wel on his feet stande Ne on his hors wel ride, For he was smetyn thorow the syde, He my&yogh;t not wel sitte in pese; Troyens clepid that man Dotes, That Lamedon tho tydynges brou&yogh;t; Ther lyues alle thei set at nou&yogh;t. WHan Lamedon these tydynges herde, With Mechel del thenne he ferde; Lord god! what him was wo! For he wiste neuere wheder to go. But at the laste his horn he blew, And his good men that him knew Come aboute him wondur blyue, As faste as thei my&yogh;t driue. ¶ As thei reden to Troye ward, Thei saw come many a lord MS. alord. , Many Gryffons on a ffrape With mychel spede MS. speche. and mychel rape. Thay loked be-hynde hem to the see: Off hem that fledde how it my&yogh;t be? He saw hem come be-hynde his bak Afftir him a wel gode schak. ¶ Thenne hadde the Troyens wel gret awe, For thei wist neuere whedir to drawe, Thei were be-twene her fomen set. Whan Hercules and thay were met, Hit was gret del and pite What martirdom he made to be; For thai of Grece were mo than thay The double-fold—sothe to say. ¶ Hercules rides oueral and rennes— As a fulmard doth afftir the hennes— Al forsothe that he tas he sles; Til he haue doun, he wol not ses. He makes aboute him styes and wayes, His my&yogh;t on hem he sayes. ¶ As he rode so aboute raykand, ¶ Lamedon occisus est. Lamedon sey he fyghtande, That many a Greu hath sclayn that day; He rod to him—so weylaway!— And smot MS. smot. in-two bothe nekke and bon, And kest the hed fro him anon; Among the horses ther thei ran. The Troyens then no counsel can, When thei sey here lord so dede; Off hem-self kan thei no rede, Alle &yogh;ede to dethe that hem abode; Ther were ffewe that thennes rode, For thei my&yogh;t no ferthere fle To toure ne toun ne to cite. NOw Lamedon is ded & sclayn, And alle the kny&yogh;tes on the playn With-oute the toun on the wolde, Ther ne was leefft nother &yogh;ong ne olde. And thei of Grece ben went to Troye With mery herte and mechel Ioye: Alle that thei mette ther-In, Thei dede to dethe, er thei wolde blyn. Thei dwelled ther a ful MS. aful. monithe The MS. first had month , a later hand [?] made i out of t , put an e behind the h , and altered this e to t ; so the MS. now reads moniht. In gode pees and in grithe, Til thei hadde sought the toun aboute And robbed hit with-oute doute Off al the good ther-Inne was, Er thay wolde thennes pas. And alle the Maydenes that thei myght fynde, That comen were of gentil kynde, That louely were, &yogh;ong, and free, Thei ledde with hem ouer the see; And helde hem there in gret seruage, That were come of gret parage. As thei of Grece the toun sought ¶ Ciuitas Troieanus destructus est. And mochel wo the Troyens wroght, Thei fond a fair Mayde and a curtays In Lamedon kynges paleis, That was of wonder gret beute, The fairest may that man my&yogh;t se: Long, and smal, and ri&yogh;th tretis Was that mayden schapen y-wys; That blisful, that swete wyght Dame Oxonie forsothe sche hight; ¶ Oxonia Filia L'. Regis. Sche was the kynges dou&yogh;ter Troyene MS. troyene ; the first e written by later hand over line. , Getyn in wedlak on the qwene. ¶ Hercules toke Oxonie, That kynges dou&yogh;ter of genterie, And &yogh;af here Thelaman to mede, In-to the toun for he furst &yogh;ede; For he was the furst man That toke Troye, when thei it wan. So weylaway! that sche was born! So fele gode men for here were lorn Afftirward wel many a day, As &yogh;e afftirward here may; For bi here roos al the wo, That sixti thousand kny&yogh;tes and mo Deyed for her, and al here kyn, And gode Ector, here owne Cosyn, And gode Troyle, and Dephebus, And here brother Priamus, And Hectuba the gode qwene This line stands behind the next one in MS. , And here dou&yogh;ter Pollexene; And alle that to Troye longed For hir rape the deth ther fonged. Thay of Grece haue robbed the toun, And brend houses & throwen hem doun; Thay lefft right nou&yogh;t that ought was worth, That thei ne bar hit with hem forth To ther scheppis and her naue; And sayled hom in sauete With alle þe Over line by later hand. riche tresor of Troye, And leuyd ther-on with moche Ioye, For thai were riche for eueremore The while thei on lyue wore. ¶ But Thelaman, that worthi kyng, Dame Oxonie, that lady &yogh;ong, Held alle his lyff to his leman And nold her not to his spouse tan; And sche was grettere than he Or alle his kyn by suche thre; Of her so was his lykyng A later hand has made many scrawl|ings and scribblings in this and other lines on this page. And mo also of his ofspryng MS. osspryng. . But of here In his lechurie Wan MS. Whan. he that kny&yogh;t of chiualrie: Ayax Thelamonyus, That was so bold and vigurous, Afftirward that at Over line by later hand. Troyes batayle Wroght many a Over line by later hand. gret meruayle.— Thus was Troye formas lorn and wonne,— Fille the cuppe who-so konne! TRoye is downe and al to-rent And lyth on the pament: Ther nys nou&yogh;t stondende an hous In al the toun to hide a mous MS. amous. , That hit is Over line by later hand. downe and ouerthrowen, Ther may the wynd wel colde blowen. That tyme that this chaunce be-fel Priamus—that sothe to tel— A noble kny&yogh;t and a ful fair, That was the kynges sone & his air, Was not at home in that contre: ¶ Hic Priamus venit ad patriam suam. He was fer out of that Cite, A strong Castel to be-sege, That was holden with his men lege That were a&yogh;eyn his fadir rebelle. Off these tythandes herde he telle, He laffte the sege that was be-gonne,— And elles for-sothe it hadde be wonne The castel certes, hadde he a-byden; But he is thennes with his men ryden With carful herte and sore wepyng, Til he wiste the sothe of this tythyng. ¶ Toward Troye he toke the way With alle his men, the next that lay; Til he come ther he neuere belan. Than was he a sori MS. asori. man, When he saw al downe and brend, And his frendes dede and schend. He sorwede day and ny&yogh;th, Til he hadde ben a-wroken be his my&yogh;th; He leuyd euere in gret wayment, Til he was ney-honde yblent. ¶ But at the laste his wo he leffte And sayde, "he wolde make Troye effte Wel stronger than it was ore, Widdur, lengur, and mochel more." ¶ He dede seche ouer-al and sende Afftir Masons fre and hende, Sklatteres, Masons, and Carpenter, And other Men of alle mister, That schulde be-gynne to make that werk. Priamus hath sette the merk, How long, how brod it scholde be; The wryghtes haue hewen many a tre MS. atre. , Postes, Pileres Many and grete; The Masons on the stones bete,— Bothe of Marbil white and gray,— To make the werk as I &yogh;ow say: Euere was a ston MS. aston. of Marbil gray, And another of white, of alle that lay. Many an ymage ther was grauen, Wel smethe were thei alle schauen, To sette with-outen vpon the walles. On here chambres and on here halles Ther was wroght alle maner best, That was walkynge In any forest, Were koruen on the walles enviroun. Many fair hous was in that toun. MAny worthi paleys and heye Ymade MS. ymade. was ther of Masonrye. Sithen god made first the werld, Off suche on haue &yogh;e not herd That was so By another hand over line. mechel of strengthe: Hit was thre dayes iornes of lengthe, And as moche it was of brede— As men doth on boke rede. Suche a toun MS. atoun. was neuere &yogh;it non, Ne neuere schal be—by god alon!— As longe as this world schal stande, In cristendome ne in hethen lande MS. hande. . The wal fro the ground streygthe Were thre hundred fete on heygthe; The lowest cote with-Inne the close, That was werst and lest of lose,— Sicurly as I erased after as in MS. say alle men,— Was foure-score fete of heygthe and ten. With-oute the toun is mad a dike, Ther was neuere toun that hadde it like! Hit was diked doun plum, That no man my&yogh;th ther-ouer com. And &yogh;it he dede a paleis make With-oute the diche, of many a stake, That no man schulde the diche come to Ne no harm to the toun do. Afftir thanne so dede he make A paleis for his owne sake, And a rennand MS. arennand. fair reuer. But I wol not ther-of speke here, For afftirward schal &yogh;e here and see, How [was] that werk of gret noble. PRiamus is lord and kyng— Afftir Lamedons endyng— Off Troie and many fair Cite And of many other riche contre. He hadde a lady to his wyff, Hectuba, that louely lyff; On here gat he children fyue, The dou&yogh;tiest men that were on lyue. ¶ Gode Ector the furst hyght; ¶ Ector. God made neuere a beter MS. abeter. kny&yogh;t Off dou&yogh;tinesse and of chiualrie In cristendome ne in paynie. The secunde brother het Paris, ¶ Paris. The fairest kny&yogh;t that lyued ywis. The thridde name was Dephebus, ¶ Dephebus. A doughti kny&yogh;t and vertuus; He was wys to &yogh;eue consayl Off alle that euere fel to batayl. The fourthe hight Elenus; ¶ Elenus. The &yogh;ongest doughti Troylus, ¶ Troylus. A doughtier man than he was on Off hem alle was neuere non,— Saue Ector, that was his brother, That neuere was goten suche another, And Elenus, that was the fourthe, The wisest kny&yogh;th a-boue erthe: Off alle science of Clergye, Retorike, and astronomye, He was forsothe a wis man MS. wisman. , Off alle science that any clerk can. ¶ Off Hectuba also gete he Gentyl ladyes doughtres thre: The eldest, Clusa, weddid was ¶ Clusa On the left side in MS. . Vnto that traytour Eueas The MS. has Eueas throughout, cf. also ll. 5521, 7647, 7650, &c. , That afftirward trayed Troye; God &yogh;eue him sorwe and neuere Ioye! ¶ The secunde was of mechel pris, A witti womman and a wys; Sche couthe alle the seuene science, Men dede here gret reuerence For here wit and here konnyng; Cassandre thei called that may &yogh;yng. ¶ Cassandre On the left side in MS. . The thrydde was comely on to sene; Men clepid here dame Pollexene; ¶ Pollexene On the left side in MS. . Ther lyued non so fair a wyght In al this world to mannes syght; Ther fayled no vertu In here body, Saue that god made here dedly. And &yogh;it gat he on other wymmen Thritti other doughti men, That were euere gode knyghtes and sekir, Bold and strong in eche bekir. Consilium inter Troyanos ad pugnandum This line in red paint. . WHen Troye was wroght to the ende, Priamus thoght In his a-tende, That he wolde make a gret feste With alle burgeis moste and leste: The day is set, the feste is made; When thei hadde eten and were glade, ¶ Priamus spak to hem an hey, With sykyng herte and heuy— He seyde: 'lordynges &yogh;e ben here alle! The moste partie to me schal falle, And we haue set a-&yogh;eyn oure toun That thei of Grece hadde cast a-doun; Thei haue don schame and vilonye To me and to alle my progenye, And to &yogh;ow, gode men, also: What schame my&yogh;th thei vs more do Then scle oure kyng In oure lond, And bere away alle that thei fond, And robbe MS. roble , cf. 2675. oure toun and brenne, And lede a-way wymmen and men, And holde hem there In foule bondage That we held here of gret parage? That was—lo—a foule MS. afoule. meschaunce! It were now tyme to take vengaunce That haue now oure frendes schent And vs brought now in gret torment. For we haue now a Cite strong, Wide, brode, and wonder long, To herbare men with-oute mesure. For thei may not a-&yogh;eyns vs dure, In oure owne lond to do vs dere— Nought the value of a pere! For we haue frendes gret plente, That ben alied to &yogh;ow and me, That schal ben to vs in mayntenaunce With alle her men and lyaunce, And we ben riche and haue tresoure, Siluer and gold with-oute mesure, To make of vitayles purueaunce To oure allers sustenaunce. &YOGH;e wot wele, that alle Assye Is vndir me, the moste partye; Wherfore me thenke: by resoun and skyl We may vs venge, if that we wyl. But for batayles ben euere in doute, And er that it be brou&yogh;t aboute, No man wote who schapis the better, I rede that we sende oure letter Or elles Message by som lordyng To hem of Grece that dide this thyng, To make a-mendes of thaire trespas That thei vs dede In this plas, Off that thei brende and doun threwe That we haue made a-&yogh;eyn newe, And that thei robbed so oure lond And sclow oure frendes with here hond. ¶ And &yogh;if thei nyl amendes make, Ne do so mochel for oure sake With any other amende, My sustir home that thei sende That thei holde ther in hordome, Me to vylany and to schome,— &YOGH;it scholde we thole her errour That thei haue don to vs & our, That ther be no more ado Be-twene hem & vs, if thei do so. And thus me thinke we may sum-dele Agayn men be excused wele.' ¶ Alle that euere sat and stode, Saide, "his consail was gode;" But thei seide, "it most be A witti man to passe the see, That on this Message schuld go, That thei for wratthe dede him not sclo." The wisest man that thei had Was Antenor; the kyng him bad That he schulde on that erande wende, To wete of hem alle the ende. ¶ Antenor dede the kynges byddyng: He dyght his schip with-oute dwellyng And spedde him faste on his viage, To do MS. To to do . the kynges gret message MS. gret me message . . So longe he sayled day and nyght, To Thesalye he come right, Ther Pelleus kyng dwelled than With Many a lord and many a worthi MS. aworthi . man. ¶ Hic Rex Troiani misit nuncium ad Regem Grecorum These two lines in red paint. . ANtenor on londe is lyght, Wel arayed and semely dyght; To Pelleus kyng he is now went And salued him faire verament. And he &yogh;ede faire to his gretyng And asked of him, "what tithyng, Whennes he come, and what he was, And what made him the see to pas In-to contrays, and what he soughte?" And bad that he schulde gabbe noughte. ¶ Antenor saide: 'sir, by the rode! To telle the sothe so me be-houede. I schal &yogh;ow telle ffor no Latyn, Off I schal therfore be sclayn— For I am sworen be myn othe, To say the sothe for leeff or lothe: ¶ I come on Message fro the kyng of Troye To &yogh;ow, sir kyng,—so haue I ioye! The kyng of Troye to &yogh;ow me sende And asketh, whether &yogh;e wol amende In the MS. line 2001 after l. 2002! The harme, the schame, the vylony, The Mansclaughter and the robbery Off his fadir that &yogh;e sclow, And of good that &yogh;e fro him drow, And of his sustir Oxonie, That &yogh;e haue here In &yogh;oure balye And make that ladi an hore to be That is gentelour, then &yogh;e or he That holdes hir here on suche a manere MS. amanere . ? Sendes him home his sustir dere, And &yogh;it wol he alle other trespas For-&yogh;eue, when he hir at home has, And be in qwyete and in pees, And his fader deth relese And alle the good that &yogh;e haue of his, That no contake be-twene &yogh;ow ris.' WHen Pelleus kyng had herd this, He was angered for-sothe y-wys, With Priamus was he ful wroth; Fro Antenor a litel he goth, His mautalent to refrayne That dede his herte mochel payne For vilens wordes of Priamus. To Antenor thanne seyde he thus: He seyde, "he nolde &yogh;eue a fecche, He holdes him certes but a wrecche"— 'And thow that hast these tythynges brou&yogh;t: By him that al this world hath wrou&yogh;t! But thow go with-oute dwellynge, In dispite of thi lord thi kynge I schal do the to vyle dethe With-oute consayle or other rede!' ¶ Antenor for ferd schoke, With-oute leue his way he toke Toward his schip wonder faste And sayled forth, til he were paste Out of his lond in-to the see Fer fro him In his contre. And sayled forth in his way Many a ny&yogh;th and many a day, Til he were comen to Salenne; A fair Cite ther was thenne, Ther Thelaman dwelled In That þat Mayden held in syn. ¶ When Antenor herde that tythand, That Theleman was kyng of that land, Out of his schip to him he soughte; And asked, "whether he wolde oughte With him that he aftir spired?" With the Troye[n]s was he a-greued, For he wiste wel, if that thei my&yogh;th, Thei wolde him reue the worthi wy&yogh;th. ¶ Antenor sayde: 'sir, herkenes now! The kyng of Troye send me to &yogh;ow And bad &yogh;ow for &yogh;oure curtesye Sende him home dame Oxonye, Out of his lond that &yogh;e haue led, That neuere wolde that lady wed, But holde hir with &yogh;ow here As an hore and hores fere, That is come of more honour Than &yogh;e, sir kyng, and alle &yogh;our. And &yogh;if &yogh;e wole this so do, In pees may &yogh;e for him be so.' THelaman stode & these wordes herde, He swore by him that made this werlde: "Out of his lond but if he hied, If he ther-Inne myght be spyed, He wolde him brynge In-to foule endyng For Priamus loue, that fals kyng;"— 'But say thi kyng, that me meruayles— That nyse Cokard—what him ayles, Off loue or pees to praye me,— And MS. That . alle hise, him, and the, And alle that ben &yogh;ow toward; But say, that I make forward: He schal neuere haue that blisful birde, But he hir wynne with dynt of swerde; [I] wan that lady Oxonye At Troyes toun with Chiualrie. Say thi kyng: "be no wayes I wol not do that he me prayes." But hye the faste out of my lond, Or thow schalt deye with myn hond!' ANtenor a-wey him spedde, Off Thelaman was he a-dredde; To his schip wel faste he &yogh;ede And sayled forth with gret spede, Til he come to Acayas; A worthi Cite thanne ther was, Ther Castor dwelled and kyng Pollus. When Antenor herde telle thus, That these bretheren bothe were In the toun to-gedur there, He come to hem and tolde his tale By-fore hem bothe in the sale. But sicurly the kynges bothe, When thei herde him speke, thei were wrothe; In gret wratthe spak Castor To the knyght sir Antenor, And bad him sese of his spekyng,— "Or he schulde deye, be heuene kyng!" ¶ He seyde: 'falawe, what-so thow art— He that made the come hidirward, I holde him a nyse MS. anyse . cokard, I wot no man of him a-ferd; A nyse MS. anyse . Iauel is he that the sendis, That we schal make him amendis Off alle thinges that is ydon, Or sende him hom his suster son. ¶ What wrecche is he that biddis vs thus, When we hate him and he hates vs? Vs is leuere werre than pees; We wol not, that he relees His fader dethe ne no-thyng elles,— As thow thi message here vs telles— For we dede his sire neuere suche schame, That we ne schal do to him the same! Other amendis wil we not make; But In his dispite and for his sake We schul do the to dethe vyle, Iff thow dwelle here any while!' ANtenor for wratthe wex al pale, With-oute leue a-way he stale, As faste as he my&yogh;th skippe; He toke the way to his schippe And sayled a-way to the see, For ther durst he no lenger bee. To wende for-sothe to ende his nedis, To Pilon faste the knyght him spedis; Ther duk Nestor the knyght be-held, And his erand as-tyde he teld. Duk Nestor was ful of wratthe and ire Toward Antenor, that proudely sire, That for tene chaunged alle his hewe: He wex &yogh;olow, bloo, and blewe. Antenor sees his colour meued, That he come there ful sore him rewed; He hoped neuere thenne to wende With-outen deth and schamely ende. Nestor sayde: 'thow seruaunt lythur, How artow so bold these wordes wethur To speke hem here in my presence, In my wratthe and myn offence? Certes! ne were my genterye, My fredom, and my curtesye, Thow scholdest not passe fro me on lyue: That I schulde thi chekis on-sundir dryue, Or I scholde In &yogh;oure kynges dispit Thi bodi with hors to-drawe hit Thorow-out my lond, and take vengeaunce Off thi proude wordis and contenaunce. But hye the faste of my sight, Or—here my trowthe I the plight!— Thow schalt deye with mechel pyne, If thow dwelle longe in lond myne!' Antenor stale away fro him, He dredde to lese bothe lyff and lym; He stale to schipe and sayled a-way, For he dredde Nestor ay. He sayled forthe on his iornay, Til he come to Troie contray; Ther he fond manye on glade, For his come gret Ioye thei made. ANtenor is comen to Troye, Off his comyng thei made Ioye, Al that lond and that Cite. To Priamus as-tyde went he ¶ Hic Rex Troianorum iratus est. And told "what answere that he hadde, And how the lordis alle him badde Out of here lond that he schulde ffle, Or he scholde honge on a tre MS. atre . , Or al to-drawe him lym fro lym In dispite forsothe of hym;" 'For thei seyde alle by on sawe, Thei tolde right nau&yogh;t of thyn awe, For of thi loue kepe thei nought; Thi wratthe echon thay sette at nought. And thi sustir most be bought Wyth dynt of swerd, or thow getest hir nought.' WHen Priamus this vndir-stode, Wel coldful tho was his blode, Gret sorwe in his herte made, Ther myght no man that day him glade. Then was the kyng bothe wan and pale And sat doun stille In the sale; He was an-angred and greved, That Antenor was so repreued On his message a-monges the Grues; That he come ther, wel sore him rewes, And that thei set by him so lyght; He thoght be wreken, if he myght, Off here euel dedis and answeres, And so he wol, and so he sweres. Anon he dede afftir sende The grete of Troye that were hende, And spake thus to alle that wore Comen then to-gedir thore; He seide: 'lordynges, &yogh;e wot wel alle, That ben now sembled MS. semblent . In this halle, I sente message—as &yogh;e me consayled, Ful wele I wende hit wolde avayled— To the kynges and lordes of Grece, That robbed &yogh;ow and this contrece, That Lamadon, my fader, sclow, And &yogh;oure kynrade to hem drow: If thei wolde amendes make For curtesye and for oure sake, That we myght In pes be so, That ther were no more a-do; Or if thei wold hit not amende, That thei wolde my sustir sende, And I and &yogh;e wold be In pes, And alle oure harmes make reles.
