Now lyest thow ther on thi syde, The deuel made the a stede be-stride, For litel myght is In thi lymes. Palamydes Hupoun vp nymes, And sent him to his Pauyloun With mychel lamentac[i]oun. ¶ Afftir that Neoptolomus Rod to kyng Archilogus, Ayther &yogh;aff other suche a kayl, That thei fflowen ouer the hors tayl Opon that playn, as it were two rattes, Thei lay ston-stille as two cattes. ¶ Carras rod to kyng Schelene MS. schenele . , Him hadde be beter at home to bene, For Schelene &yogh;aff him suche a balle, That of his stede he made him falle, He &yogh;aff him suche a benedicite, That he fel dede opon the ble. ¶ Afftir that kyng Philomene Fel to ride to kyng Mescene, But Mescene rod ouer his cropere And lefft his stede, that was him dere; Philomene sende him vnto hise, For he him [wan] with valyauntise. ¶ Philocoas and kyng Remus Rod to-gedur wel irus, That to the grounde rode bothe kynges, As euen as thei were drawen with strenges. CAriolus, a kyng corouned, And Theseus kyng to-geder routed With speres scharpe, that men my&yogh;t here; When thei to-geder met In-fere, Here speres brast al In-sunder, As it were a blast of thonder; The strokes were strong, here bakkes bent, Ne hadde the speres a-sonder went, Thei schuld haue dyed at my wenyng Bothe to-geder at that metyng. Here mayles barst, her aketons rofe, The yren In-to the fflesch drofe, The blod gerd out, as were a gote, Thei tombled ouer bothe hed and throte; Thei lay ston-stille In that plot, As it hadde ben an erthe-clot. ¶ Ector bretheren were mechel to prayse, Many a doughti man thei reyse Out of here sadles and bere hem bak, And lefft hem ligge as a sak With grisly wounde and al ded leffte, That thei come neuere to batayle effte. ¶ The doughti kyng sir Thelamon Saw ther a kyng,—het sir Padon,— To him he wolde [faste] ride, He smot his hors and made him glide Ouer forow and ouer falow As swyff[t] as any swalow, Til he him met atte speres ende; Sir Pedoun a-&yogh;eyn him gan wende: 'Thow semest,'—he sayde,—'no lyuande creature, In my god I the coniure! And if thow be the deuel Sathanas, I schal the mete In this plas.' Thei riden to-gedur with-oute fayle, That thei fel doun top ouer tayle; Thei mette so wel, that nother fayled, That the blod fro hem rayled; Thei fel doun vpon the grene, That men wende ded thei hadde bene. ABoute Ector euere thei rayled; The Gregeis euel he assayled, He hewys hem offte alle to grotes, He falles hem thikker, than the motes In somer-tide fflyen In the sonne, He spares nother qwik ne donne, Lord ne lady, riche ne pore, Strong ne feble, stiff ne store. ¶ Achilles clepes to him Thoas, A dou&yogh;ti kyng,—his cosyn was,— He sayde: 'Cosyn, I haue meruayle, We are not worth a scnayle A-&yogh;eyn that man, that &yogh;onde fyghtes Vndir vs alle with myght & scleghtes; He sles oure men by fyue and six, He countes hem as thei were a kex; He weries not, ne belynnes nere, But lastes euere In his wode gere, Ryght as it were enchauntement; Many a kny&yogh;t hath he schent. Go we to him on a closter, Oure myght on him let vs now muster! For now I hope and wot right wele, His myght be passed som dele; I trowe now wel, he be myghtles, Or oure godis be not rightwes, And he of my&yogh;t is more than thay. Go we and loke, what we do may! And so schal we on him be wroken!' When Achilles hadde thus spoken, THese kynges two with-oute abode As-tide thei to Ector rode, And layde on him as lyther hynes MS. lytherhynes , but the down-stroke of the second h is crossed. Many a strok the two cosynes, Achilles and kyng Thoas; Thei roffe his helme In that cas, That hadde ben made of tre or lether, Hit greued not him of a feder; Thei brast his helme In many a stede, And made his blode aboute him sprede. ¶ Thei did bothe certis ther myght, To him sle or take In that fyght With many a knyght bothe fat & megre. But kyng Toas was on him egre, Off Ector heued his helme he drow; But Ector &yogh;aff him strokes y-now, With tene smot he that lorer, That he brast helme and his viser, And halff his nase he did of-kerue, Off suche a seruice he did him serue; Thoas fel to grounde thore, For he was wounded swythe sore. ECtor brether come then alle, Thei saw Thoas by Ector falle, Thei ride to him and alle that other And help right wel Ector, her brother; Thei fau&yogh;t with Gregeis meru[el]ously And bare hem doun dispitously; ¶ Achilles wolde no lengur abyde. Thei toke Thoas In al his pride And ladde him to Troie to here prisoun, Thei caste him In a depe dongoun, Thei thrat him alle, tho he was tan, For ther brother Cassibalan, That he hadde sclayn with glad spede, Thei him be-hight In alle mede. ¶ Antenor and Dephebus Lad him to Troye ful greuous Of his woundes and his takyng, And also of his presonyng; Thei lefft him ther In sicur warde, And went a&yogh;eyn to her standarde. ¶ Kyng Thelaman at that rescous Was born to grounde as a mous, The bretheren him threw to grounde tho, For he assayled Ector also With kyng Thoas and Achilles; Him hadde ben better haue ben in pes, For suche a wounde thei him be-tau&yogh;t, That he leffte bothe mayn and mau&yogh;t. Thei bare him to his Pauyloun, Til he come ther In a ded swoun. Menelaus kest al his wit, How he my&yogh;t Paris best hit; ¶ Paris saw wel his waytyng, He was war of his laykyng, Off his euel wil was Paris war; His bowe he bente al redi thar, He set ther-In a kene beket And to Menelaus he hit schet; That hed was mad with foule venym. Paris wel euene schot at him, And he fel doun, as he scholde dye, The blod ran out of his eye. ¶ Paris at him euel taysed; Fro the grounde his men him raysed, And bare him home to his hale, And laide him doun In-myddes the sale. To him come sithen surgiens And other noble ficisiens; His wounde ful wisly then he soghte, When thei were to him broghte. ¶ Thei &yogh;af him drynke & gode medecynes, And slaked him then of his pynes, Thei schof aboute wel soffte his flesche, With good wateres thei him weche, Thei greythed him gode oynement. When he was dyght, his stede he hent, And rod a&yogh;eyn to that stour, And sought Paris with semblant sour; ¶ He swor by goddis dyng[ne]te, He schuld on him wel venged be. When Paris hadde with him thus toyled, Off his Armes he him dispoyled, He cast of al his armure, And fau&yogh;t with him In cors pure, With bowe and arwe fedred with po, He wroght amonges hem mechel wo. ¶ Menelaus was wel war, That Paris thenne non armes bar, But was al naked In his clothes; He swor his dethe with gret othes, A stalworth spere to him he kipped With stelen hed that wel was tipped. I hope wel Paris ded hadde ben, Ne hadde Eueas gon be-twen, That he myght not Paris come to, For no-thyng that thei my&yogh;t do. ¶ Eueas thanne hath led hom Paris With mochel folk to Troye y-wis, That Menelaus met him not with, For he nas y-armed nother lym ne lyth. ECtor saw al that fare, How he was lad to Troye al bare. To Menelaus &yogh;aff he tent, To scle his brother how he hadde ment; Ector therfore was sore greued, Ther-fore his helme In-two he cleued, Thorow his coyfe his gode swerd bot; Menelaus ther-fore not flote, Ne hadde no wordes him to speke, Ne hadde no my&yogh;t him-self to wreke. ¶ Ector wolde haue taken him fayn, He put ther-to my&yogh;t and mayn; But ther come many a moder barne, Duk and kyng,—I the warne,— With alle her kny&yogh;tes, him to rescowe, For he lay stille as a sowe; Ther come mo knyghtes to his defence Than ben now In alle Tarence. ¶ On Ector alle thei gan leye, Many a body he did ther dye, Many a man to dethe gos, For thei lette him of his purpos; ¶ Hic Greci ffugerunt. He sclees hem & falles that he reches, Delful strokes he hem be-teches, He maymed hem and ouer-al slees, That he hadde neuere more pees, Many a man he ther spilles; The Gregeys ffleis ouer dales & hilles, As faste as thei may ride, Toward her tentis on eche a side. ECtor affter euere chases, At eche a lepe his stede vnbrasis, Thei fledde him as hare doth hound; Men my&yogh;t haue filled a gret dromound With bodijs that he sclow chasand, And euere he folowed manassand. He swar here deth by bok and belle, He nolde neuere sese hem to qwelle; Scholde neuere man ne creature Haue went fro MS. for . that batel sure, ¶ Hadde thei of Troye had day-lyght,— So were thei ferd and discomfyght;— But sterres ros vpon the sky, Ector lefft his chase for-thi And turned hem to his Cite, With kyng, duk, and his meyne; And did sone off hem her harneys & set hem doun on benche & deys This line written in the margin very neatly, but by the same hand.—The last line of this MS. page (not printed here) is repeated there on the back of the leaf as first line. , And made her bones nesche and souple, For ther was many a worthi couple, For gret trauayle that thei hadde had Off thaire restyng were thei glad. NOw is Ector comen to halle, And the stedis stabeled alle, Thei ar vndight and set In stable; Then was reysed many a table, The bordes were layd, the clothes spred This line is in the MS. a repetition of the last line of the preceding page, where only leyd is written instead of layd . See footnote 2 on preceding page. , And thei are set and richely fed With mete and drynke, gret plente, With vernage, Cret, and clarre, With other drynkes and riche metes. ¶ But Priamus no-thyng for-&yogh;etes To make thaire &yogh;ates fast— He was of the Gregeis so sore agast,— With many bare and many a croke, And men y-nowe the &yogh;ates to loke, That alle men that were trauayled Schulde, when Gregeis hem assayled With noyse or cry or any affray, In thaire bed [be] ther thei lay. ¶ The &yogh;ates he keped, and thei ben sere To ete and drynke and make gode chere, To ete & drynke can thei not sese, Thei were serued with many a messe, With many noble diuers rost, With mete bakyn, sothen, and tost. THe clothes were drawen, when þei had eten; Kyng and duk and alle that ther seten, Layd MS. layd . be-side hem bothe gerdel and pouche, And wente than alle to thaire couche, And held hem vnder couertoure, And sclepte wel a gode mesure,— Til nyght was gon, and sonne schon wyde, That men my&yogh;t se on eche a syde. ¶ With mechel noyse thei hem atyred, Thei hadde long sclept and were en-yred, And as thei her armure held In hande, Kyng Priamus sente his tithande, That thei schulde be that day In pees And make hem alle wele at es. ¶ Priamus sende his messageres, And afftir his priue counseleres, To kyng and duk and to Ector, And afftir Troyle and Antenor, Til Dephebus and Eueas, Paris and Polamydes, That thei scholde come to his Paleis, To here his consayl ther alweis. ¶ Thei spedde hem faste euerychon: Thedir is comen kyng Monnon, Gode Ector, and many another, Troylus, and Dephebus his brother, To Priamus that were priue, What he wolde, to here and se. When thei were y-comen alle To Ylion In-to the halle, Thei sat hem doun on that days, Thei were stille and held her pays; Saue Priamus, that kyng corouned, Was non of hem that o word souned. HE spak to hem with glad chere And seyde: 'lordynges, &yogh;e are me dere; With-oute &yogh;oure wil and &yogh;oure assent Wol I not do, so haue I ment. I schal &yogh;ow telle myn herte wille, What is my resoun and my skylle, Whi I haue sent afftir &yogh;ow; Sittes stille and herkenes now! ¶ Me thinketh oure goddis speciale And haue vs &yogh;euen gret riale, For vs haue thei mechel wrought; To honour hem ful wel we ought. Thei loue vs wel specially, And worchin for vs rially, Ther-fore schal we on alle wyse Do to oure goddis sacrifise With riche offerand and gret dispense, And hem worschepe and do reuerence. ¶ We mot nede hem glorifye, That hath vs sent oure enemye And schamely lyght In oure prisoun, That vs hath don gret tresoun With force and armes and cruelte, That wolde sle bothe &yogh;ow and me, To robbe oure goddis, and oure Cite brenne, And oure wyues ledde henne, And make oure childer thral and cherles, That schulde be kynges, dukes, and Erles; And we hem ones greued, By alle the gode non ther leued! ¶ Me thinketh by resoun, and &yogh;ow thynk als, That this freke and traytour fals Be &yogh;oure consayl and Iugement With-oute the toun be ybrent, Or fle him quyk al by the lawe, Or with wilde hors him to-drawe, Or elles hong him on galowe-tre, That wolde distroye &yogh;oure Cite; And so schal alle these other drede. What sey &yogh;e now, what &yogh;e rede? ¶ Lete se now, what dethe demes, Wheche deth of thes him best semes? Schal he be qwartered MS. qwarteler . with a knyff? To se him ded, were al my lyff!' Ther was no kyng that croune bered, That Priamus that tyme answered With word, whan he was demand; But sat stille as dere on the land, But were of that strong stonayd, Of hem alle no word thei sayd. Eueas was wis, witti, and lered, To speke than was he not fered, He saw the kyng hadde wratthe I-tane For the dethe of Cassibalane, The kynges sone, he loued best; For wratthe him thoght his herte brast. ¶ By-fore the kyng Eueas stode, And spak to him with milde mode, And sayde to him as the wyse: 'Nolde god, that any of thise Schamful dethe that to him deme! Hit is wel better that &yogh;e him &yogh;eme Hole and sound In gode sauete, For we wot neuere,—no more wot &yogh;e,— What may be-falle som tyme to &yogh;oure, How it wol schape to vs and oure. ¶ The doughtiest man that euere was born May falle, be tan, or elles lorn Among his fos be chaunce and happe. God made neuere so dou&yogh;ti a schappe, That was so michel of strengthe & myght, Geaunt, champioun, ne other knyght, He mot be take In batayle; Al day we sene it, no meruayle! ¶ Ther-fore, sire, I do not rede That &yogh;e do thus Thoas to dede, For &yogh;e wot wel, my lord the kyng, That kyng Toas and his ospryng Is comen of alle the beste lynage Off hem of Grece that ben of age; Alle the gret blod of Grece Ben some his Emes, and some his nece, Alle of his kyn, and to him longe, Ther is non gretter hem amonge. So thei wolde do to oure frende, Iff any come In here bende, And &yogh;iff vs the same Iugement, The beste of vs if thei mowe hent; Off som of oure hit myght be-tyde, &YOGH;e wold not for al the world wyde Se him haue suche a chaunce For al þe lond of Spayne & Fraunce This line inserted in the margin, like l. 7024. . ¶ I rede therfore, kyng Thoas saue; The same a-&yogh;eyn &yogh;e mowe it haue, &YOGH;e may &yogh;it kyng Thoas chaunge For on of oure or for som strange. Ther-fore, lord, if I durst it say, I wolde &yogh;ow rede and also pray, That &yogh;e wolde kepe kyng Thoas wele; Hit may be-quyt &yogh;ow euery dele. ¶ Gode Ector, assente ther-to And rede thi fader, to do right so!' He radde his ffader "that consail holde That Eueas hadde ther tolde";— 'I holde his consail gode and trewe. Iff &yogh;e him scle, hit may &yogh;ow rewe; For if any of &yogh;oure be y-take, We may him chaunge and so pees make.' PRiamus held him not payde, That Ector thus to him sayde; In his entent &yogh;et he leffte And sayde to Ector wrothely effte: 'And if we do with Thoas thus,— What schal oure enemys saye of vs, That we haue of hem suche awe, That we dar not do the lawe? . . . . . No gap in MS. And therto amonges hem be wel ffawe The last word, ffawe , on erasure. ; Thei schal drede vs the lesse And holde vs ferd and hertlesse. But not-for-thi! a-&yogh;eyn my wille, I schal assente &yogh;oure consail tille." And so was Thoas saued fro ded Thorow gode Ector and Eueas red. And Eueas &yogh;ede to Eleyne, to se That curtays quene of gret bewte. Kyng Thoas herte be-gan to qwake, He wende to be hanged al nake; But Ector wolde he were saued. Priamus wolde that Troye hadde be paued With hethen hond and euery a membre; That he hadde bended or Septembre, If he my&yogh;t haue had his wille; But Ector wold not lete him spille, And thus hadde thei that conseil ent. The nyght is comen, the day is went, ¶ Euery man to his In owe, The wayte be-gan nyght to blowe. Mone ne sterre saw man non, The cloudes haue hem ouer-gon; It wex al dym with derk cloude, The wynde be-gan to blowe loude, The wynd turned In-to the west, Hit made a wonder gret tempest. Among Gregeis blew many a blast And alle ther tentis to grounde cast; So wonderly the wynd it blewe, That alle here tentis ouer-threwe; Al &yogh;ede to grounde bothe tent and hale, Here ropes vayled not of a schale. Wo is hem In here MS. hem . sclepes, The wynd brast bothe tre and ropes, Ther was no stake that fast held, Nother of Pauyloun ne of teld. Hit was as derk as helle, Might no man se—the sothe to telle,— To set a-&yogh;eyn teld ne tent; Thei were almost with wedir schent. ¶ It be-gan dredly to thunder; Thei hadde nou&yogh;t to hele hem vnder. Hit blew, it rayned, and eke snewe, Thei turned for cold bothe hide & hewe; It thundred loude, it ffres, hit hayled, Michel wo that nyght hem ayled; It lygthned vp In the firmament, As al the world hadde y-brent; Hem thought, the sky had y-brend al opon, In-to the erthe thei wolde haue cropon For sorwe, and wo, and gret turmentes That thei hadde of the elementes. Affter that be-gan it rayne, As al the world scholde be sclayne; As water rennes In a goute, The sky gan falle hem aboute. Vp In the sky thei it hadde lade, Men myght with-Inne a wyle wade A-mong the hors vp to the hamme, Than lefte no man synge his gamme; ¶ Thei were a-ferd of Noye flode Hadde comen a-&yogh;eyn, thei vndirstode. Al was fir in the firmament, As it scholde the world haue brent; The stedes starte out of here stalle And ran aboute faste with-alle, Men wende, that thei hadden ben wode; The sky was as red as any blode. Hem selff to helpe thai ne my&yogh;t, I-wis thei hadde a vile ny&yogh;t; It my&yogh;t haue ben no worse wedur, Off heuene & erthe hadde gon to-gedur. ¶ Thei banned & cursed alle tho, That made thedur hem for to go Fro thayre gode and fro ther wiff, To lede ther so karful lyff. Lord, the sorwe that hem was with! That ny&yogh;t hadde thei non other grith, Thei quok for cold, thei were al wete, Thei longed sore afftir hete. IN sorwe and wo the Gregeis are, For drede of dethe thei droupe & dare; That thei come ther ful ofte thei playn, Thei hopeth ful wel to be a-tayn To neuere se thing that thei owe, Wiff ne child, moder ne mowe. Thei sorwe thus, til hit be day; "And her ffrendes"— thei seyde ay— "That lay ther dede, and som were roten, Some smetyn, & some were schoten;"— ¶ 'Alas!' thei seyde, 'this foul vnwit, We were with sorwe so combred and knyt! Whan that we passed the Grekysche see, We knewe ful lytel Ector poustee; Hadde we knowen,—as we do now,— Than hadde we wrought afftir oure prow, And saued vs, and we dispende; For now may vs no man amende, Thes wederes done vs mechel tene. What wonder is, of we vs mene? We leue oure lord and oure frende, And we ligge here in stormes and schende; Er we wende hen, we schal be sclayn; Litel wondir is, of we vs playn. A, Ector, that we ne hadde knowen Thi dou&yogh;tines, er we hadde sowen! Schulde neuere kyng ne Emperour, Duke ne kny&yogh;t, ne vauesour, Haue made vs passe the salte strem For alle the gode of Ierusalem!' Thei made gret del and playnyng; But it be-gan to leue raynyng, ¶ The wynd sesid the gret blast, The snewyng then no lenger last, The tempest then be-gan to sese, The thonder slaked & held her pese. Thei were glad of the sesed tempest, Thei were ful glad to cacche rest. ¶ The ny&yogh;t is gon, the cloudes with-drawe, The day be-gan for to dawe, The sonne schon, the wedir cleres; The Troyens then with brode baneres ¶ Were redi armed In the feld, On stedes stronge, with spere and scheld; The &yogh;ates were open, and thei rod out. The Gregeis of hem hadde gret dout, But not-for-thi thei hadde no nede, Thei armed hem with mechel spede, And made hem redi to the fight— With alle her power and here myght— ¶ A-&yogh;eyn Ector, that thei drede sore, With alle here men bothe lasse and more Here strengthe to kythe, her my&yogh;t to proue Off hem of Troye that thei saw houe In-myddes the feld, and hem abode. When bothe parties to-gedur rode, ¶ Hic Rex Hupon Troianus mortuus est. Delful dyntes thei deled and dalt; Many in his armes swalt, Er euen come and day was gon. Suche batayle was ther neuere non Betwene two kynges on lande ne se, Neuere was, ne neuere schal be. BOthe parties ben y-dyght, With scheld and spere and brynes bry&yogh;t, In playn feld on gode aray; Ther is no speche of no loue-day, For eche man wol on other be wreke,— What bote is than of loue to speke? Achilles with his Murmindones Passed ouer dales and dounes; He rides ouer dounes and dales With alle his men out of his hales, With baneres brode and many a sygne, With many a worthi kny&yogh;t and digne. ¶ The furst batayle sir Achilles To lede that day for-sothe ches; Out of his tent he is now yssed, To kyng Hupoun was he wel wyssed, A dou&yogh;ti kny&yogh;t of gret a-fere; But him thoght euel that he come there: Hupoun was michel and long, Hey and brod, mechel & strong, He was mechel as a geaunt; But him hadde ben better to haue ben at Gaunt Or haue leyn seke in his bed, Then he that day batayle hadde led. ¶ Achilles smot him with a spere, That al his Armes gan to-tere, He smot him thorow bothe flesch & bone And thorow his armes euerychone; Thoow he were mechel and long, Out of his sadel he him sclong. ¶ To Ector rod kyng Octomene With hate and moche tene, He come to Ector faste fleande With a stalworthe spere In hande, He smot Ector, that his spere barst. 'The deuel the honge hard and fast!' Seide Ector, 'what eyles the? Whi hastow thus smetyn me?' ¶ Ector was with him ful wrothe, He drow his swerd and to him gothe, And smytes him on a-nother manere; Of his scheld a ful quartere He carff a-wey at that strikyng; The stroke was smyten at his lykyng, He smote him doun vnto his chyn, That men my&yogh;t se the tethe with-In. DIodemes and kyng Antipe, With-oute trompe or pipe Or any other Melodye, Thei redyn to-geder with gret envye; Here speres brast In splentes, But thei fel not with here dentes, With that Iustyng ne that Iornay. But thei &yogh;ede not quyte a-way: ¶ Thei drow here swerdes of here scauberkis And smot on scheldes and hauberkes, The rynges barst, the nayles out, Thei were strawed al a-bout; Her woundes bledde, her flesch was tamet, The holest of hem ful sore was lamet. But at the laste be-tydde it so, That Diodemes smot In-two Thorow dou&yogh;tines duk Antipe gorge, With his swerd—was fair of forge,— That he fel ded on gresse and rote, Off that wounde he hadde no bote. GLorious kyng lord Ihesu! Who-so hadde sen Ector vertu, How he the Gregeis ther reuerced MS. reuerted. , Helmes and hauberk how he persed, How he hem sclow by two and on,— He wolde haue sworn by Peter and Ion, By Marie bry&yogh;t and persones thre: That god that is In vnite Made neuere man that was so goode, Ne so many schedde of mannes blode, Ne non so strong as Ector was. By him my&yogh;t no man pas, That he my&yogh;t take or hent, That the lyff a-way ne went. Ector slees the men of Grece, Thei dyed thikkere then men dryues gece To chepyng-toun for to selle; It is a wondur for to telle, What men he sclow In felde, A-mong his foos how he him welde. THer come two kynges In that batayle, That saw Ector aboute rayle, As faucoun flees afftir drake, A-mong Gregeis gret murdir make; He made hem fle for drede a-ferd, As hound dos dere of his herd. That on was kyng Episcropus, That other his brother Cedyus; Thei rod to Ector bothe at ones, For to cleue him bothe flesch and bones. But Ector &yogh;aff off hem ri&yogh;t nou&yogh;t, Thei fond bothe that thei hadde sou&yogh;t; Episcropus, that ape and owle, Spak to Ector wordes foule, He called him "fitz-a-putayn MS. fitz aputayn . ," And seyth: "he was a cherl velayn." ¶ Than seide Ector: 'as I am kny&yogh;t, Thow schalt of me haue a foul dispit, Of me, thow kyng Episcropus,— Thow hast defouled me thus!' EPiscropus Ector defies. 'Fals ataynted traytour, thow lyes;' Saide Ector, 'I was neuere thral, I am fre, and my kynde al; In al my kyn is no throle, But kyng and duk, kny&yogh;t & erle; My ffader is a gentil kyng, Suche is non In thyn ospreyng! ¶ Fyfftene kynges, genteler than thow, Doth him omage and fewte now; And I, his sone, kny&yogh;t, and Air, Vndir me is man and mair, Duke and Prince, and kny&yogh;tes strong, And alle that euere to him long. My moder is a gentil quene, A trewe lady, and euere hath bene; ¶ Sche did her lord neuere falshede, But euere was trewe In word and dede. It semes wel thanne, that I am fre, I may be skyl no cherl be! And that thow schalt wite, if I the take, Thi proude wordes schal I slake. I drede neuere man of thi nacioun, Whi scholde I now fle a glotoun, ¶ Hic Ector occidit Episcropum Regem et Cedium Regem. Suche a caytyff, suche a wrecche! I holde the not worth a fecche!' ¶ Then was wroth Episcropus That Ector spake to him so spitous; Dispitusly Ector he myssayde, And sadly to him he layde With al his strengthe and al his myght, With Ector sone he gan to fyght. Episcropus that schrewe vnorne Might not his word performe; ¶ Ector sone to him gan take, He thoght him venge of that wrake; Ector bare his sword on hye,— For he hadde no spere him bye,— He &yogh;aff the kyng Episcropus Suche a recumbentibus, He smot In-two bothe helme & mayle, Coleret and the ventayle; He carff him doun In-to his vent, That to the deth sone he went. ¶ 'Thow art now dede and ouer-throwen, Thi bostful wordes that thow blowen, Velenly thow hast thi mede; To myssay thow efft take hede!' CEdius saw his brother sclayn, The swot ran doun—so doth the rayn— And of his eye doun by his lere, For his brother that was him dere. 'Alas,' seide he, 'that euere I was born! I se my brother In-sonder schorn, I schal him venge—what-so be-tydes— Thoow my hert brest out at my sydes.' A thousand knyghtes that dou&yogh;ti were Cedius hadde with him there; Alle he called to him tho, And many other Gregeis mo; And asked him: "what was his wille? Whi he so called and cried him tille?" ¶ Thei asked of him: "what him ayled?" And he seide: "his lyff him ffayled, No-thyng In erthe myght do him bote, Er he saw Ector on his fote,"— 'For he hath sclayn my dere brother, Episcropus, and many other; And him folwe I thus aboute, To seche Ector among the route, And leue him not, vnto he be founde, Ded or sclayn, or cast to grounde.' ¶ Cedius then with-oute lesyng Sou&yogh;t Ector faste with gret sikyng; A thousand kny&yogh;tes rod with him than With many another dou&yogh;ti man, To scle Ector and him wounde. Thei &yogh;ede him to seke & sone him founde, And of his stede thei bare him doun, And &yogh;ede to Ector alle en-viroun; And that me thenke no meruayle, For he wist not of here consayle. ECtor was to grounde I-bet, A thousand kny&yogh;tes thei on him set, To scle him ther thei all hadde thoght, For her euel wil ful thei boght. Cedius strok to him wel offte; Ector saw his arme on loffte Al redi him for to strike, Then gan Ector sore myslyke; ¶ Than seide Ector to Cedyus: 'Wenestow to sle me thus? I sette at nou&yogh;t alle thi Coueye, Whil I may se &yogh;ow with myn eye!' ¶ Ector &yogh;aff kyng Cedius on And cleff a-two his schuldir-bon, That hond & arme bothe fley a-way; The kyng fel a-doun, and ther he lay. THen come thedir Menelaus, And also the stronge Archilaus, And also the stronge Thelamon With many a kny&yogh;t, & kyng Makaron, The noble kyng Diodemes With many a thousand, & Vlixes; Ther come also the riche Athene, The noble man Duk Mescene. The riche kyng ther Emperour, That was her alther gouernour, He come doun with the rerwarde Strong and yrus as any lyparde. ¶ These kynges comes with here batayles, Eche man thanne Ector assayles; Thei died faste on euery syde. Alas now! how schal Ector abyde These kynges alle and her power, Whan hem come socour fer and ner? ¶ Prime was past, hit was Midday, And ney-honde none—as I &yogh;ow say. Whan alle that armes bere myght— Off hem of Grece thei fayled lyght— Were comen doun to that batayle With men & hors and pedayle, With bowe and Arwe and alblast; Then were the Troyens sore agast, For thei hadde fou&yogh;ten for the best Al the day with-outen rest. ¶ Hic Achilles interficit Phillum Regem. For then were comen the kynges alle And begonne on hem to falle, Thei were ffresch, these other wery. Then were the Troyens al sory; Thei keped the Gregeys not-for-thi And stode a-&yogh;eyn strongfully; But thei my&yogh;t not endure so longe, The Gregeis were that tyme so stronge, That thei be-gan so to fle. It myght with hem no better be, So weri thei ben and ouer-charged, Here socour foule fro hem targed. ¶ Achilles folwed and alle hise, He ouer-toke the kyng Philluse; Phillus turned and with him fau&yogh;t, But suche a stroke Achilles him rau&yogh;t With his hondes sicurly, That he fel dede ther sodanly. ECtor saw that Phillus was ded, 'Alas'—seide he—'that I ete bred That euere was mad of corn of whete, That I schulde se my men so bete! I may not longe it suffry Off that Achilles with his sculkery.' He turned and loked his men toward: Thei flowe the while faste a-weyward, Thei wolde not bide be doune ne dale, For that the Gregeis were so fale. ¶ Then my&yogh;t men se the Gregeis ride, Thei closed Ector on eche a side, Some be-hynde and some be-fore. Ther was a kyng—het Alpenore— Another also het Doryus, Thei were to Ector envyous; On eche a side Doryus him strikes, With his spere ful harde he prikes; Ector deled aboute lyueray To alle that euere come In his way. ¶ Then men my&yogh;t se swordes drawe— Thikkere then trees by wode-schawe— A-boute Ector, to bere him doun; Thei thoght he scholde neuere come to toun, But leue ther as a caytyff Clene ded with-oute lyff. A Thousand swerdes aboute him clatered,— As Masons hadde on stones batered,— But al was nou&yogh;t thei were aboute, For hem alle hadde he no doute: He deled a-boute him suche strokes, That he carf bothe hed and chokes, Hond and foot & haterelle; Many on ded to grounde felle. He sclow for-sothe the kynges two, And many a-nother kny&yogh;t also. ¶ To scle the Gregeis hadde he neuere pees; He cried and seyde to Achilles: 'Thow sclow long er a kyng of myne, Now haue I sclawe two of thyne. Come thi-selff to venge hem; I &yogh;eue of the right nou&yogh;t certeyn!' ¶ The Troiens thanne that were fled, When thei sey how Ector sped, How he him-self that stour mayntened, With hem-selff ful sore thei tened; When he hadde sclayn the kynges bothe, With hem-selff thei were wrothe, Thei turned a-&yogh;eyn on thaire enemys, And died faste on bothe parties Below the last line, upside down and very badly written, are the words: ' paphylun was an vter man bothe of le&yogh;ing & dissiuing ' [? desseiesing ]. . ¶ Hic Amphimates Rex Interfectus est. AVeas thanne his sword out-drow, A kyng of Grece ther-with he sclow; Amphimates his name was kyd That Eveas ther to dethe dyd. ¶ The Troiens keuered a-&yogh;eyn the feld, A&yogh;eyn the Gregeis fast thei held. Ther was a duk of gret emprise, That saw Ector hem alle to-brise Alle tho of Grece that he my&yogh;t reche; Ful ffayn wold he take wreche. ¶ He swore by him that sit in trone And made bothe sonne and Mone: "He wolde him lette of his doyng, Off his slaw&yogh;t and his quellyng." Wel boldely to him he Ioyned, And with his spere faste ffoyned, That his mayles barst in-sonder,— That thoght Ector moche wonder;— He drow his sword and hoved stille And fau&yogh;t with Ector al his fille. ¶ Gret my&yogh;t the duke schewed thore, He layde on Ector strokes sore, He lettid him moche of his prowes, Off his scleyng and his rebelnes. ¶ Ector was with-al anoyed: 'Now is my my&yogh;t strongly distroyed,' Ector sayde, 'whan I schal thole Off on that is not worth a cole Suche vilony and suche repruse. I may wel say, I am refuyse Off alle the kynges sones of Troye, When that I suffre of suche a boye Suche vilonye to me be done,— Ne se I neuere sonne ne mone! ¶ Hic venit sagittarius. But thow schalt dere thi strokes a-bye, Thi hardines and thi folye! I schal kembe MS. kemble . thi &yogh;elowe lokke!' He &yogh;aff the duk suche a knokke, That helm and coyfe In-sunder &yogh;ede; He cleue him doun vnto his stede, That he fel doun on that other side. 'Now wil thow &yogh;iff me leue for to ride, Where that I loue & thow not me lette! Now hastow that I the be-hette!' NOw cometh a-nother kyng Episcropus With many a kny&yogh;t a-venterus, Out of Troie comes he ridande With men of Armes thre thousande. ¶ With him come A quaynte Archer, That mad is on suche a maner: He is halff hors and halff man. With hem of Troye thedir he ran; This archer ran to fight al naked. Herkenes now, how he was maked! Fro his nauel dounward He was hors, and man vpward; As a hors hadde he foure fete That he ran on, whan he schete; Bak and bely of hors & tayle, Thus was he maked saunfayle; ¶ His [s]kyn was hard and no-thyng thenne, His pyntel was of hors-kynne. And al that was fro the nauel aboue, Al was man—for goddis loue:— Sides and ribbes, hed and hals, Bak and brest, & visage als, Armes, scholdres, chekes, & eres,— Al was of man that he op weres. Saue that he hadde of man no voyce,— As an hors made he the noyce, As it were an hors—for-sothe—he neyed.— Many a man thorow him ther dyed!— Tethe and gomes and mannes mouth— Now lyues no man by north ne south, That euere saw suche a best In feld ne toun ne in no forest! ¶ Al was of man bothe nese & throte, And fyngres als for his schote; But alle his membris lasse and more Were al be-growen with hors-hore, Bak and bely, & legge and nase, Brest, Armes, & his visage; As he were a hors, he neyes & ondes Line 7729 after 7730 in MS. . His eyen were lyke to brennande brondes; He fferd, as he scholde men haue brent With spark of fire that fro him glent; His vice was red as any fir. Bowe and arwe was his atir. WHan he was comen, he bent his bowe; Alle that euere him sawe Were ferd of him and strongly wondred; The horses snored, as it hadde thondred— So were thei of him agrysed, So brend his eyen and dredful glysed. Ther durst not on loke to him ward, Here hors turned aweyward; ¶ Thei wolde haue fled out of the feld, But eche a man his hors held: With mochel wo thei hem resteyed, To make hem dwelle thei offte assayed; Thei held hem stille with bridel & reyne, With mechel wo and mechel peyne. THis Archer schotes & sendes Arwes, He slees the Gregeis, as men take sparwes With lym or net or lym&yogh;erdes, Hors & man that Archer ferdes; And Ector slees al that he hittes. Ther is no man that on hors sittes Off hem of Grece, that may restay Ther hors lenger, but fled a-way; Ther is no man that ther abydes, But eche man aweyward rydes To here tentis & Pauelons. Achilles with his Murmondons MS. Murmondous . Vnto his strengthe a-weyward prikes; Ector faste afftir him strikes With hem of Troie; and that archer, He schet aboute him fer & ner With arwes that were wel I-heded Line 7765 after 7766 in MS. ; The Gregeis offte In-sunder hem scheded. ¶ A wonder chaunce he did hem thore: When thei of Grece discomfited wore And to ther tentis a-weyward fledde, Her Archer faste Afftir hem spedde; The Archer hadde so smartly ronnen, That he hadde lond of hem wonnen. As he thus ran aboute schetande, He saw a&yogh;ein him come prikande Diomedes vnto his tentis; The archer thenne an Arwe out-hentis, He smot at him—so was he thare— Diomedes was wel ware, ¶ To schote at him so was he prest; He wiste neuere, whedir he my&yogh;t best To his pauyloun for to ride, For he most ride that Archer be-side,— ¶ Hic Diomedes occidit sagittarium. Or if he turned a-weyward, — His enemys come on him bakward: For if he come a-monges her hondes, For al the godis of Gregeis londes Wold thei not lette the kyng quyk go, With lyff and lym hem go fro. ¶ He was In gret a-visement, How he myght passe and be not schent; He saw be-fore him that foule best, The Troyens afftir him with many a crest. ¶ The Archer was the kyng so hende, To scle that kyng wel he wende: To that kyng he gan to hale, And drow an Arwe vp to the vale; And as he was In his losyng, Diomedes, that dou&yogh;ti kyng, Hadde his sword al redi drawe, That many of Troie hadde done of dawe. ¶ He strok his stede & to him rode, Ar euere arwe fro him glode: He smot the best vpon the bak And &yogh;aff him right an euel knak; He smot his bak [right] in-sunder, That he fel doun his hors fete vnder. NOw are the Gregeis fayn and bolde, The Archer lyes vpon the wolde Sclayn and dede, as men telles; None is ther that langer dwelles, Thei turned a-&yogh;eyn and toke the feld, Thei droff Troians fro tent to teld. ¶ To Ector rennes Achilles,— But [of] him &yogh;eues he not two strees, He kepte him and not for-soke. A stalworthe spere to him he toke And smot Ector with myght and mayn, And he smot him for-sothe a-&yogh;eyn, That eyther fel doun, er euere thei wiste, That bothe her eres the grounde kiste. ¶ But Ector was hurt the sorrour, For he come doun fro the fferour As he had ben a man [a-]rage. He toke Ector at his a-vauntage, Wher-by Ector In his ffallynge Toke wel more the brussynge, And lenger lay his hors beside Then Achilles dede that tide. ¶ Achilles ros op witterly And lepe on hors sicurly, He layde his hond on Ector stede And went a-way wel gode spede. ECtor was risen and vp-stode, He loked aboute as he were wode, And swor I-tened MS. & tened . and he sporles, The blod ran out at his nase-throlles; When he fro him his hors saw lede, Mouthe & nase began to blede, For tene & wo his hew chaunged. Ector afftir Achilles sewed, ¶ Opon his feet faste he hyes,— To his men faste he cryes: 'Se &yogh;e not, how myn enemy Ledes a-way my hors &yogh;ow by? Iff he him lede thus fro &yogh;ow alle, Foule reproues &yogh;ow schal be-falle! But &yogh;e him sonner ouertake, &YOGH;e bene not alle worthi an hake!' ¶ Eche man than afftir rides, Is none lengur that then a-bydes, ¶ Hic Greci tenuerunt Antynorem Regem. Eche man afftir rides & rennes. Achilles MS. Ector . thenne for tene brennes, Maugre his tethe the stede he lefft, For Ector brother ffro him it refft; He my&yogh;t no ferther for him go, Therfore for-sothe he was ful wo. ¶ Lord! so Ector thanne was fayn, Whan he his gode stede hadde a&yogh;eyn, He wold not for his wey&yogh;ht of gold, That Achilles it hadde hold. Many of Grece bowte his takyng, Men my&yogh;t se thenne speres schakyng: ¶ Ector sclees and Ector felles; His hors takyng dere he selles; He riues helmes and cleues hedes; Ther is no Gregeis that him MS. that thei him . [ne] dredes. Ther died for him on that sond Sixti that neuere layde on him hond. ANtenor rode aboute strikande,— Fro Ector was he fer fyghtande On that other half of that batayle, And that was him to wrothe-haile: For thei of Grece opon him throng And him be-closed hem among; His men bacward fro him frusched, And many of hem to grounde crusched. ¶ Antenor did that In him was, But he myght not fro hem pas, For thei of Grece were more then he: Thei toke him at that semble And sent him to her MS. his . pauylons With-outen any hauylons, And held him In her prisoun. Polydomas of gret renoun Therfore was he ful sori,— At the head of this page, not very distinctly: Aynesworth . That was his sone, was him bi: His hert forsothe wex al cold, When the tydandes were y-told. ¶ Gret meruayles tho in hem he wrou&yogh;t, Off his lyff as he nad rou&yogh;t, But he ne hade no space at his lykyng, For it was thenne ney euenyng; ¶ The day was gon, thei hadde no lyght, For it was wel with-Inne nyght. To dwelle lenger was erased between lenger and thenne . thenne was not gode, The[i] leue ffyghtyng, as hem be-hode, And turned hom with weri bones,— Eche man to his owne wones,— Vn-Armed hem, and wente to reste; To house come many a weri geste. ¶ Thei layde borde & clothe & &yogh;ede to mete. Polidomas my&yogh;t not for-&yogh;ete Off al that ny&yogh;t for no thyng His dere fader takyng: Ful litel he drank and les ete, The teres fel to his fete. ¶ Off alle that ny&yogh;t my&yogh;t he not slepe, Al that ny&yogh;t he lay and wepe, Til hit was day, the sonne gan schyne, Euermore dured his pyne. Then he ros vp, as most nede, To arme him, his men to lede, A&yogh;eyn Gregais to fight to-morn. Wo was him, that he was born, For sorwe and care and mornyng That he toke for his lordis takyng. ¶ The nyght is passed, hit is day, The sonne hath dreuen the sterres away, Ther is no sterre opon the sky; The sonne is resen & schynes on hy, Fair & bry&yogh;t he schewes his bemes. Thei risen vp of here dremes, Off Troie and Grece [the kny&yogh;tes] bothe; Many of hem schal be wrothe: ¶ Hadde thei of here sweuen taken tent, That thei hade wyten, what it hade ment, When hardi thynges thei did mete, Tho that schold her lyf for-lete! But ther-of toke thei kepe no-thyng, But busked hem In the dawyng, And Armed hem In sail & schip; And than thei &yogh;ede and toke a sop, Thei ete a sop, and afftir dranke, For In batayle thei wolde be strang. ¶ When thei wente out of here hale, Many drank nother wyn ne ale Affter that, ne ete, ne drank, But layen ded & foule stank! Eche man sclow other & felle doun, Many of hem come neuere to toun Hole a&yogh;eyn, as thei &yogh;ede out; Some lefft his hed, and som his snout, Some to-hewen and foule ferd with; Some les his lyff, and som his lyth. WHan bothe parties to-gedir wore, Thei smetyn to-gedur strokys sore: When thei were comen out of her hales, And thei of Troye out of here sales And passed her &yogh;ates & here dikes, Eche man at other strikes; He drow his swerd, and he his bowe, Mechel sorwe ther was y-sowe: He anon, his knyff he drawes, —And he is ded,—and ouer-thrawes, He schakes his spere, he rides owerre, And he fel doun I-hurt MS. and hurt . wel sorre, He is ded, and he is sclayn, And he is born thorow the brayn, He ses his lyuer and his entrelles; Michel is the wo that hem ayles. ANd thus ferde thei fro that thei ros Til the day a-weyward gos, And nyght was comen, and lyght was fayled. Ector euere aboute rayled, As MS. And . faucoun doth opon his pray; The bodyes thikke aboute him lay, That ther lay with dethis wounde; Many a kny&yogh;t fel to the grounde. Ful sorily he hem ransaked Fro that morwe that he waked Til euen-tide that home he &yogh;ede, For he hadde neuere so moche nede To help and socour his meygne, As he hadde at that Iorne. ¶ For Gregeis were so styff and stronge, That thei his men doun sclow & sclonge, As thei of hem hadde &yogh;eue right nou&yogh;t; But euere among thei it dere bou&yogh;t: For Ector sclow hem al a-boute, Many Gregeis made he loute; ¶ Ector hem sclow, as it were mys, Thei died faste on bothe parties Off hem of Troye & of Gregeis, Thei lefft liggyng many karkeis. Echon wolde other sclo, Off Grece died fele, of Troye wel mo. Glad was he that ther ascaped. The better side the Gregeis schaped As for that day—as I herde telle. With hem of Troye so it be-felle: Ne hadde dou&yogh;ti Ector ben, Thei hadde not lefft a cyteseyn With him In the feld, that thei nad fled; So were the Troiens sore adred, For thei of Grece were so strongful, That thei vnnethe stode hem a pul MS. apul . . BVt Ector mayntened his syde For al here strengthe and here pride, He brekes her hedes, her helmes & scheldes, Ful nobly his men he ledes. And thus he heldis with gret labour A&yogh;eyn Gregeis al day that stour, Til ny&yogh;t was comen and day gon, And thei departid euerychon On bothe parties more and les, For it was so gret derknes. ¶ Thei &yogh;ede euen home to her hous, Thei fond ther many a sori spous, That sori were for here husbondis; Some lay dede on the sondes: ¶ The wyues of Troye made gret mornyng; Amonges the Gregeis was gret roryng, Thei blew and cried—as wilde bere brayes— For her frendes that died tho dayes; Thei wende neuere that day abyde, That thei scholde hom with her lyff ride, To passe ouer the Grekissh wawes. Thei hadde In honde wel carful sawes A-mong the grete and the smale, Al ny&yogh;t ther-of thei hadde here tale. ¶ That Agamenon was vp rysen, That hadde Antenor In his prison; When he saw it was day cler, He sent out his Messanger To Priamus and to his baronage, Trewes to aske and trewes to wage,— Off thre monthes thei him besought, Til the ded MS. he did . to erthe was brought. DIomedes and Vlixes To Priamus were sent in pees, To aske this trewe, and make it stable On bothe parties with-oute fable: That non of hem schuld other dere With non harm In maner of were Lastyng the terme of that trewe, And who-so did, it scholde him rewe; Thei be Iugement const[r]eyned To suffre therfore that men ordeyned. ¶ These kynges to here hors take,— Wel richely dyght ffor worschepe sake: Thei dede on robes that hem best payes, Off riche gold were alle the rayes, Off riche scarlet were bothe here champes, Poudred ful of golden lampes, With lilye-leues and fflour-delys; The robes were of mochel prys, ¶ Thei were parted with riche palle. The knyghtes were fair & clene with-alle, Here hodes dyght with gold ribanes,— Better weres non among the Danes;— Thei were with gold wel I-fret, The ffloures of gold on hem set, With wilde bestes and fflyande ffoules, Liouns, lipardes, ernes, and owles Off riche gold that louely schon; In hem stode many a riche ston, Saphur riche, and selidone, Erbe-de-bothe, & Cassidone, And euere among the dyamaund, Sewed wel with gode orfoyle-suand; ¶ The frette of gold was like a belle, So were thei gret & horrible; Worth michel gode thei were apraysed, Thei were so couched and hye vp-raysed. ¶ Thei rode to-geder with-oute debate; Thei are now comen to Troye &yogh;ate, In forme of pes thei aske entre: "To lete hem In for charite, That thei my&yogh;t wende with-out outrage To Priamus on here message." THe &yogh;ates are opened and vndon, The kyng[es] were leten In son, Thei were I-kept with curtesye. Ther was a kny&yogh;t of genterye, A riche man, that het Delon, A gret courser sat he vpon; He was In Troye bothe geten & born, He saw the kynges come him be-forn. ¶ On his hors that he be-strode A&yogh;eyn tho kynges he thenne rode, And kept hem faire as kny&yogh;t curtays, And led hem In-to the kynges palays; He led hem bothe In-to the halle: The kynges were at the mete alle, ¶ Priamus and his kny&yogh;tes of my&yogh;t; Ther-Inne was a louely sight. When Delon broght thes messageres To the kyng and his consaleres, To speke with him, her erand to schewe,— Off his consayl were ther but fewe. ¶ Delon broght hem to the bordis, Thei gret the kyng with louely wordis, Thei told her erand and asked respit: "That alle my&yogh;t reste, bothe knaue & kny&yogh;t, On bothe parties monthes thre By siker hostage & gode surte." With louely wordes and faire spekynges Kyng Priamus answered the kynges: ¶ 'I holde him certes with-oute manhede, That loueth wrong or any falshede; I dar of trewe make myn avaunt: I schal helde siker that I graunt, I schal holde trewes I vndirtake; I schal hem helde and siker make, That non of myne schal do &yogh;ow skathe, Nother late, erly, ne rathe Lastyng the trewe; and &yogh;e also The same a-&yogh;eyn to me schal &yogh;e do. ¶ But &yogh;e wot wel: It is not skylle, That I assente the trewes tille With-oute red of my consayle, Off my baronage, & myn avayle That ar with me In myn enprise. But I for &yogh;ow now schal arise And herkyn, what my consayl sais; So longe &yogh;e schal dwelle In peis. Iff thei assent, I graunt for me: What thei wol say, &yogh;e schal sone se.' PRiamus wol no lengur ete, He settis a-way drynke & mete, For curtasie of his two gestis He settis a-way borde and trestis. He wolde thei were sone answerd, That ther drecchyng hem not dered. ¶ Priamus did to him calle Kynges and dukes and lordes alle; Thei stode aboute him on a rowe, He spak to hem with wordes lowe: 'Wol &yogh;e thus longe trewes fulfille?' Sayde Priamus—'say me &yogh;oure wille: What schal I tille MS. telle . hem now say? Schal I seye: "&yogh;e," or: "nay"? ¶ Avise &yogh;ow now alle In-fere, Now &yogh;e ben to-geder here: What is &yogh;oure wit? how thenke &yogh;ow? Hope &yogh;e hit be for oure prow To graunt this trewe? wol &yogh;e assente? Telle me &yogh;oure best a-visemente!' THe kyng[es] sayde by on name: "To graunt trewe, it was no schame,"— 'Sithen thei it aske at oure request, Hit is worschepe to oure behest; And we may reste vs the whiles, For we ben ful of woundes and biles, That ben ful of quytour & wores; We may the while hele oure sores. We wol the trewe graunte and hauen, Sithen thei comen hit to crauen.' ¶ Ther was no lordyng In that halle, That thei ne graunte the trewes alle And wel apayed—saue Ector one; Ther-to spak he wordes none; He saw what thei alle thought, Therfore wolde he say right nought; He saw it was al ther MS. alther . lykyng To be In pes and haue restyng; ¶ Hic Greci pecierunt pacem. And not-for-thi hit liked him ille, That thei schuld ligge so longe stille, And for he was not al wel payd, To hem thus mechel Ector sayd: ¶ 'The Gregeis haue the trewes craue, For thei wolde her ded men graue; I dar wel say: hit is not so. But I wol not the trewes vndo, Sethen &yogh;e alle the trewes wol holde; I wole it be as &yogh;e haue tolde; But I dar say that thei thenke falsnesse MS. salsnesse distinctly. , Thei are purvayd of gret queyntenesse. ¶ I wot ful wel, her mete hem fayles, Thei haue defaut of here vitayles; Thei may not fyght, for strengthe hem fayles. Thei schal the whiles puruay vitayles, Off corn, wyne, and other store, And be better thanne thei were ore. And we that while oure good schal waste, Hit wol vs faile now In haste; Thei wol mis-lede MS. vs lede. vs with a trayn. What good be-houes vs to sustayn ¶ The folk that is with vs her-In? Where schul we the godis wyn, To mayntene vs and holde oure lyues? I trowe that roste schal oure knyues, When we haue no bred for to kerue; I not wher-of thei schal vs serue, We may be serued with-outen brede. But now &yogh;e haue graunted to take hede THis trewes to holde, I say for me: I wole right wel thei holden be; For I schal neuere a&yogh;eyn calle That thyng that &yogh;e assenten alle. I wol &yogh;oure hele and &yogh;oure wel-fare; &YOGH;if &yogh;e mys-ferde, it were my care; I wole right wel that we vs reste, Then may we be bothe tacte & preste A&yogh;eyns the terme the trewe comes out, We may be thenne bothe styff and stout. I holde me payd of &yogh;oure Iugement, I wol not fro &yogh;ow disasent.' ¶ Then were the MS. we. Troiens mury & glad, When thei leue of Ector had, That thei scholde reste so longe; Many man for Ioye songe. Hit was gret murthe & Ioye To hem of Grece and eke of Troye, That trewe is tane and last so longe; That thei myght bothe ride & gonge To take her murthe and her solace, Eche man is glad In that place. THese lordes toke leue of the kyng And wente hom al hying; And to the Gregais hom he brynges Off his trewis gode tydynges, That thei of Troie hath graunt the trewes. Then my&yogh;t men here many glewes, Pipe and Trompe, and many nakeres, Synfan, lute, and Citoleres; Ther was so many a daunce. Thei made tho gret puruyaunce Off corn and hay, of wyn and otes, And thei songen wel merie notes; Thei hele her woundes In gret quiete, With mochel Ioye thei dronke and ete. And thei of Troye were as fayn Off here reste, bothe kny&yogh;t & swayn, And hele her woundes at here layser, — Kyng[es] and kny&yogh;t[es] & kayser. And al the while the trewes held, The[i] speke to-geder In toune & ffeld; And that riche kyng Thoas, That with Ector takyn was, Scholde go quyte to his Pauyloun, And Antenor home to Troye toun. ¶ Ayther of hem the prisons hom sendes With-oute raunsoun & with-oute amendes, For that on that other is gre; And so schal thei quyte be. THe trewes is graunt & schal be holden: Riche robes were then vnfolden: Many a coffre was vnstoken, To drawe out robes that were y-loken; Eche man his coffer vnsperes And takes gerdeles of riche barres With bokeles of gold and fair pendaunt, Wel anamayled with the mordaunt; ¶ Many a broche and many an oche, To stike on hede and on pouche. Thei toke out rynges and made hem gay, Thei leued In Ioye & mechel play, The whiles the trewes last; But al was lefft, when that past. Whil it was trewes, was many hode Gayli wered with mochel gode; ¶ When thei were gon, thei layde hem doun And toke the stelen haberioun, The ketil-hattes and stelen hure, And layd away the gay pelure; Thei toke her spores with kene roweles, And leyde a-way the riche jeueles MS. reueles. . ¶ Hic. Ector ibat ad Reges Grecorum in tempore pacis. HIt was a day lastyng the trewes, And eche a lord his clothyng newes; Ector was ffair and semely dyght. The day was fair, the sonne was bryght, Merye synges the nyghtyngale, The throstil, and the wilde wode-wale; It is gret Ioye to here the larke In toun and feld, fforest and parke. ¶ Ector sayde: "that he wolde go Achilles to se and other mo; He wolde with him haue daliaunce, To se her hertes and her contenaunce." He rod him out of his Cite, The lordes of Grece for to se; ¶ With him &yogh;ede many a riche lordyng, Many a duke, and many a kyng. He was welcomed with gret honour To Agamenoun her Emperhour, The kynges did him worschepe alle; Achilles bed him to his halle, Ful Inwardly he him be-sought: "That he fro him departid noght, Til thei to-gedir In his tent Hadde dronken vernage and pyment, And that thei my&yogh;t to-gedur carpe;— Hit were him leuere then note of harpe." ¶ Ector graunted alle his prayeres, He &yogh;ede with him and alle his feres. When thei were comen and alle doun set, The wyn was asked and forth y-fet; At here comyng thei made fair wedur And spak of many thynges to-gedur. Achilles euere Ector be-holdes, His legges anon on crosse he foldes, For he was naked, he was fayn. ECtor saw Achilles wagge As with the wynd doth the flagge, On euery a side he louted lowe, He was In poynt to ouer-throwe With eche a strok that he ther toke, Out of his sadel almost he schoke, He my&yogh;t not sitte stille In pes. A wonder stoure ther was by-gonnen, Er man my&yogh;t a forlong haue ronnen, ¶ Ther were ffyue hundred kny&yogh;tes sclayn Off hem of Grece opon the playn; Thei hadde but litel to-geder streuen, Er thei of Grece were bacward dreuen. But Menelaus, when he beheld How thei of Grece had lorn the feld, Opon his stede the kyng him dresses, To Troiens euen he him gesses; He lased his helm, his spere he ri&yogh;tes, And rides thedir with alle his kny&yogh;tes. HE halp hem wel and wan hem erthe, He felde the thridde & sclow the ferthe; He and his bare Troiens ouer, And hem of Grece made hem couer And tok the feld the Troiens opon. But then come thedir kyng Odemon Out of Troye with mechel ffolk, He spared neyther the appul ne the colk, Vn-til he come to [the] Melle: Many a man then my&yogh;t thei se ¶ Set vp the fet and doun the hed, And many lefft among hem ded. To Menelaus Odomoun rode, And Menelaus him abode In the right corner of this page is the signature: Q iiij. ; But Odemoun, that doughti kyng, Toke Menelaus In that swyng And him bare ouer his hors tayl: He &yogh;aff him there suche a wassail, That he lay longe In colde swot; Odemoun on his face smot And wounded him among alle hyse, That he my&yogh;t not wel vp aryse. ODemoun ffelle Menelaus, And that be-held dou&yogh;ti Troylus: He saw the kyng on grounde lyand, Troyle come faste thedur ridand, He wolde him take wonder ffayn, That he my&yogh;t haue lad him to Elayn; He departid alle the route, He and Odemoun were aboute To take the kyng, and so the[i] did. But not[-for-]thi it so be-tid, That thei that tyme so wel not sped, Out of that pres thei him not led: ¶ For ther was then so mychel pres— For-thi be-gan than to encres,— So fele batayles a-boute him spred, That thei were sone with hem so sted, Thei my&yogh;t not lede fro hem not ferre For al here my&yogh;t and her powere. ¶ For than come Diomedes doun With many a worthi bold baroun And many a kny&yogh;t dou&yogh;ti In dede: When thei saw Troyle a-weyward lede Menelaus her ost outward, Thei hyed hem faste thedirward. Whan he come ner, he stroke his stede, That he made bothe his sides blede: I trowe ther was neuere wilde ro That ran faster then his stede tho. ¶ He strok Troilus lus on erasure. so wonder sore, That fro his hors fel he doun thore; And ther-fore was it no pris: He hadde a spere at his deuys, And Troyle that tyme hadde non; Thoow he hadde broke bak and bon, Me thynke it hadde ben litel wonder, Off Troyle lay his hors fete vnder. He toke his hors and lad a-way, He sente it to the semely may, ¶ Vn-til Cresseide, þat Vn—þat on erasure by another hand. fair womman, That sumtyme was Troyle lemman: A bischopis dou&yogh;ter that het Calcas, That sumtyme byschop In Troye was, Her mayster-byschop of the lawe; But he was ferd of that sawe, That ther god saynt Appollo In Delos yle had sayd him to MS. so . : HE sayde: "that Troye scholde be distroyed." He was therfore ful sore MS. fulsore . anoyed, He durst not wende to Troye a&yogh;eyn For fferd he scholde haue ben sclayn: He dwelled stille with the Gregeis A-mong her ost—as Dares sais,— Or elles to lese his lyff he wende. Afftir his doughter theder he sende: ¶ He prayed the kyng Diomedes In here Message and Vlixes, When thei delyuered the kyng Thoas For the ffader of Polydamas, That thei wolde preye kyng Priamus To sende hir him ffro sir Troylus: ¶ Priamus graunted her prayeres And sent hir hom with-oute dangeres. And Diomedes loued here sithen; In hir loue was he so writhen, That he myght not his wille refrayn And suffred for hir sithen payn. To hir therfore Troylus stede he send In token of loue and to presend. OPon the grounde ther he lay, His stede was taken & lad away; Wo was him that it was so! Ector &yogh;aff to him wel gode sy&yogh;t, He saw him wel to grounde go, His stede ytaken and lad him fro; He was ney wod for ire and tene: He wolde meruayle, that had sene What wonder that Ector wroght! Achilles fledde with alle his route, And so did alle these other Gregais, Than folued Ector and his Frigais: ¶ But Ector euere afftir dryues, Many of hem he reues the lyues, He droff hem home ri&yogh;t to here hales And sclow hem ther ri&yogh;t In her sales; He smot of bothe hondes & nayles, Ne durst no man aske "what him ayles," Ne speke with him In that Ire For al the gode of here Empire! But then come thedur Polydomas, That &yogh;it In Troye al ffresch was, With wonder mychel quantite Off kny&yogh;tes, of men of gret surte. POlydomas a spere hath lau&yogh;t With al the ost him was be-tau&yogh;t Out of Troye is he no ryden: His men hath he prayed & bidden To help wel Ector In that stoure, That thei my&yogh;t haue for here labour Off Ector bothe loue and thonk; He rides forth by brynke & bonk To assaut with that abuschement. Now are thei alle out of Troye went And comen alle to that semble With stour sembland & gret ferte: Thei bresten here speres and drow her swerdes And beten on hem, as don herdes On weri bestis that drow In the plow; Ther was amonges hem sorwe ynow. ¶ But Diomedes he beholdes Polydomas, how that he boldes The last four letters by another hand on erasure. Then . of Troye with his sokeryng, And deres Gregeis with his fyghtyng And the feld make hem lese: A stalworth spere to him doth chese Polydomas ouer to bere, That the Gregeis schuld not dere. ¶ Polydomas was wel perceyued Off his comyng, he him wayued And toke a spere stalworth & strong And met him so In that forlong, ¶ Ad huc magnum bellum. That he &yogh;ede doun & his hors bothe, Were he ther-of neuere so wrothe. ¶ Diomedes ful sore was hurt, But his stede ros, and he vp stert; Polydomas ther-of was fayn, He toke the stede by the rayn, A-boute his hand the brydel he knyt And &yogh;aff him Troyle, ther he fau&yogh;t &yogh;it Opon his feet with his enmys; Ther was no foule so merye on ris, ¶ Then Troilus was when he hors hadde; Lord In heuene, what he was gladde! He takes that stede and sone on lepes, And sclow the Gregeis doun on hepes. BVt Achilles loked to Troyle, And saw how he be-gan to royle, When he hadde hors, a-monges Gregeis: 'This is no gamen,' Achilles seis; Achilles rod to him sone, For he wende wele he hadde done. ¶ But Troyle was war of his comyng, He &yogh;aff ri&yogh;t not of his thretyng: A stalworthe spere he to him sesed, And smot his hors and him so fesed, He bar Achilles quyte and clene Out of his sadel vpon the grene; He made Achilles to reste thore, So was he wounded wonder sore, ¶ He made his eres the grounde likke. But he ros vp stoutly and quykke, As he no harm hadde y-lacched; Troyle wold with more haue macched, He wolde haue hurt him fayn sarror, But the Gregeis held him then forror, To Achilles he my&yogh;t come noght, For-sothe to him, as he hadde thoght. AChilles is vpward cropen, Opon his hors he is lopen: Him were leuere than al Lubik, That he my&yogh;t Troyle to dethe strike; He and his smot at him alle, As men smeten atte balle. ¶ But Ector was ther-of war, How thei be-gan with Troyle to fare; He hied him thedir wonder swythe, When Troyle saw him, he was blythe: He &yogh;aff Achilles suche a dasche, That al his helm be-gan to crasche, He smot In-to his serkelet. Now are thei to-geder met Among her men hem two alone, Thei delen dyntis wel gode wone; Be-twene hem two was gret hate, Thei haue be-gonnen a gret bate: ¶ Eyther on other be-gan to hewe, Here strengthe to kythe, her my&yogh;t to schewe, Dredful dyntis be-twene hem dele; He is a fole, with hem wol mele! Thei are now bothe on hors-backis, Ether of hem on other hackis With swerdes scharpe opon her scheld; A strong batayle was ther In feld. ¶ Here Aketouns roff as hadde ben pokes, Ayther of hem on other strokis, And tar here armes that were newe, A wicked brotthe thei ther brewe; With swerdes gode that were trenchaunt Fau&yogh;t thei to-gedur by that hil pendaunt. ECtor fightes with Achilles, He hewys his mayles res by res, He hewys hem alle In taterwagges, His hauberk heng alle In ragges; And he &yogh;eues him a-&yogh;eyn good pay, The grettest strokes that he may. ¶ But Ector &yogh;aff Achilles one And claff his flesch on-to the bone, Hit barst his helme & his coyfe eke, And it made him the grounde seke: The stroke was gret—as I &yogh;ow tolde,— Achilles my&yogh;t not his sadel holde, Opon his hors my&yogh;t he not sitte, When sir Ector hadde him so hitte. ¶ He lefft his hors and fel to grounde And swoned sore In that stounde; Top ouer tayl he gan loute. The Gregeis gadered him aboute, His Murmidones were alle agast He hadde be sclayn, for he was cast; Thei stode aboute him alle fyghtande, For Ector scholde not come him hande, Til he were rysen & vpward couered: Many a man aboute him houered, His body al for to fende, That Ector schold not come him hende. ¶ Then my&yogh;t men se strokes ride, Gregeis feld on eche a syde That thedir come In his defence, For thei made ther thanne resistence A-&yogh;eyns Ector & his Troians: He sclow that tyme a thousand Danes That then defended sir Achilles, Many on swalt In his owne gres. ¶ Ector wolde Achilles take, And the Gregeis defence did make: Thei wolde rather dye right ther, Then Achilles I-take wer. Achilles stode on fote & fau&yogh;t, Til he was almost out of mau&yogh;t: ¶ He was careful and wel drery, For that he was so wery, He my&yogh;t not wel his scheld vp bere, He my&yogh;t not him fro Ector were, He my&yogh;t not wel his breth blowe, He was In poynt to ouer-throwe; His vertu hadde he clene lore, But Ector wolde not lette ther-fore. ¶ But than come thedir Thelamon, With alle his men Agamenon, And the dou&yogh;ti Menescens: That halp him wel a-&yogh;eyn Troyens, With mychel wo and gret trauayle Halp thei him In that batayle. ¶ Thei brou&yogh;t him hors, and brou&yogh;t him vp, He hadde lau&yogh;t many a pop, For ther was many a strok &yogh;euen;— But it was welney euen. ECtor was sori that it was ny&yogh;t, Er thei of Grece were discomfit: For hadde thei had the lyght of day, Achilles hadde not went a-way To [be] taken then vnto his teld, But hadde died In that feld. Thei departid on bothe side— For it was ny&yogh;t and derk that tyde,— ¶ Ector to Troye ouer the downes, And Gregeis to here Pauylones. The clothis were layd, and thei doun lyght: To soper were thei alle dyght, Thei sette hem doun and ete & drank; Many hadde his clothis al blank Off blod that thei hadde bled. Thei ete and drank & &yogh;ede to bed, And rested hem, til the sonne vp ros: To Arme him there eche man gos, ¶ The stour a-&yogh;eyn wolde thei be-gynne, For good on erthe wol thei not blynne; Her hors are brou&yogh;t, and thei vp lepe, Thei ren to-gedre on an hepe, As thei hadde don that day be-fore; Ther died be-twene hem many a score. BOthe parties In the feld were prest, In pees wol thei neuere rest; Eche man rides vnto his macche, Many a man here deth there lacche. Whan thei to-gedre were met with speres, Many on other ouer beres; Thei drow here swerdes of good metal; Er it be ny&yogh;t, manye dye schal. Echon on MS. or . other ffaste doth bete, Ryght as threscheres doth on whete; On smytes his felawe thorow the pap, And he &yogh;eues him a sori wap. ¶ Thei sclow or euen a thousand knyghtes, Men saw neuere suche other fyghtes— Sithen In erthe god made man,— That of so litel thing be-gan! Ne so fele lordes with-outen fayle Were neuere sclayn at on batayle, Ne men of Armes and also naked, As were at Troye—sithen man was maked! ¶ Hic pugnant .xxx. dies absque respectu. Some were smyten of by the knes, Some thorow-out bothe thies, Some lay dede, & som cast doun, And some lay wounded and brostoun; Some In his body bar a tronchoun, As it were put In with a ponchoun. The while thei myghten endure, Thei threw doun men—I telle &yogh;ow sure,— Thei smyten hors and helmes barst, The while the brethe wold hem last. MIchel sorwe hem was a-mong; Sicurly hit were to long Me to telle, and &yogh;ow to here, How thei ffau&yogh;t echon In-fere, I may not al the dedis devyse; Ther wolde no boke it al suffise Alle here dedis for to holde, Iff thai schulde alle be y-tolde, And I schulde alle here dedis say, How thei fau&yogh;t to-geder euery day. The bible ne no Missale, The legende ne no Iornale, The Grael ne the Tropere, Schold not holde here dedis plenere. ¶ For .xxx. ti dayes with-outen pes Thei fau&yogh;t to-gedur with-outen ses, Al was sprad bothe diche and bank With dede bodies that lay & stank. Men redes In gestes of dou&yogh;ti men, How thei fou&yogh;ten to-geder dayes ten,— Euery day with-outen rest,— To se whiche of hem were best; Men tellen of Ywayn and Wade In gestes that of hem ben made, How thei fau&yogh;t a day or two, And afftir that more than so: Thei ffau&yogh;t ffourtene nyght, And that was kampiouns right. ¶ But I say: Ector and his feris, Achilles als & his comperis, Thei fau&yogh;t to-geder dayes thre, And wold thei not in pes be; Thei fau&yogh;t to-gedir fourtene nyght, And that was the Troiens right; With-outen rest thei fau&yogh;t al-weyes, Til thei hadden fou&yogh;ten .xxx. ti dayes— Euery day til it was ny&yogh;t, That neuere be-lan whil thei hadde lyght. ¶ Now wol I of this thing telle, I may not alle here dedis melle; For mochel wo be-twene hem wex: Off Ector brethere were sclayn sex With-In the dayes that thei so fau&yogh;t, And Ector also a sore wounde lau&yogh;t In his visage on of that day, Wherby Ector In his bed lay In Ylion a ful gret stounde, Er he were hol of that wounde. THretti dayes when he hadde foughten With-outen reste bothe euen & oughten, Priamus sente to the Gregeis Kynges two that were curtays, And other lordes mo wente hem with, Trewe to aske a six monyth. And thei it graunte al at her wille, Thei were fayn to holde hem stille And rest In pes al that terme; The trewes is graunt and holden ferme, ¶ Hic ceperunt pacem ad inuicem per vj. Menses. And therto haue thei trowthes plyght: "That nother of hem be dayes ne nyght Lastynge the trewes schal other wayte With vilonye ne other desayte; And if any man be gylti founden, Hand and fote schal he be bounden, On galowe-tre to honge hye For his ffalshede and his folye." ¶ The trewes be graunt a ful half &yogh;ere Be-twene kynges, dukes, & bachelere, Alle that on bothe sides wore: Now euery man helis his sore, Alle taken medycine that myster hade, To reste that while alle were glade. And Ector is to Ilion brou&yogh;t, A riche bed ffor him was wrou&yogh;t, He was leyd In that paleis, That was of riche werk Sarsaneis; ¶ His bed was made In that riche halle And y-couered with many riche palle: To him come fycisiens, The beste of alle Troyens, And soughte his woundes on eche halue, And leyde ther-to plastres & salue, And &yogh;aff him herbes & gode raysyns, And heled him vp with gode medysyns. IN Ilyon Ector was layd In that riche halle—as I sayd;— For alle these lordes & the ladyes, That were of worschepe and of pris, Scholde him comforte In his penaunce And with the speche do him legaunce And of his Angwis and his sekenesse, To come to him bothe more & lesse. Hit was an halle of gret noblay, Aula In red paint. . The halle ther-as Ector lay; The toures were of out-done hight, I-made with wonder art and slight. If thow wolt that halle discryue, Sicurly &yogh;e wolde not leue The wonder werk of the Pyleres; Men wolde holde hem grete lyeres, Man wolde wene that men did lye, And holde it alle for fairie. ¶ But man wolde wene In his thoght, That suche werk myght neuere be wroght; For now is non so glorious, Ne non In this world so vertuous, As Ilion was the while it stode, I-set ful of stones and perles gode; Rofe and wal and euery a gable, Dore and wyndowe, trestles and table, Courbel, beme, and euery a ston, With riche gold was vmbygon. ¶ Alle the walles of that wones Were thikke y-set with precious stones; A thousand rubies on a rowe Were set a-bouen on the wowe. Ther stode a-long & eke a-crois Many a riche erbe-debois; The matistre and a riche saphur, And other stones many & sur; Ther stode many a charbocle-ston, That as bry&yogh;t aboute hem schon In that halle aboute mydnyght, As doth the somerday lyght. That halle was brode & long, Off semely werk sicur & strong, ¶ Qualiter palacium Regis Troiani factum est. Two hundred fet was it be-met. On stones twelue was hit al set Off Alabaster that wele were wrou&yogh;t, It was gret meruayle how thei were bou&yogh;t Vnto that werk to rayse that ground, It was meruayle where men thei found. ¶ He was worthi be called a clerk, That of twelue stones made suche a werk. The halle flore was paued al Thorowout with clene cristal; In euery a hirne was set a post Off worthi werk with mychel cost; On euery a post stode an ymage As he hadde ben In fauntel-age; Alle were wrou&yogh;t of gold ffyn, Hede, body, visage, and eyn. ¶ Ther was no man MS. noman . In al that land That he ne wende thei hadde ben lyuand: So vereili thei loked and smyled, Many a man ther-with was giled; Off here makyng and of here lokes Many meruayles In his bokis. DAres wrot—I telle it &yogh;ow,— That I wol not speke of now: "The walles of that halle strey&yogh;t Were two thousand fet of hey&yogh;t, ¶ Altitudo Murorum In one line, sign blue, words red; but on the left side in MS. . And &yogh;it ther-to ffyue hundrid als,"— As Dares seis that neuere was fals. ¶ Dares seis: "the toures were so hy, That thei wente to the sky, So ney were thei the firmament A-boue the cloudes verament, A man that stode with-oute doute On hem, my&yogh;t se al the lond aboute, And other londes a-cost also On euery a side, that marches ther-to." ¶ Then were thei hye verament, Thei hadde nede of a good fundement; Euery a ston of Marbil was As smethe as any glas, Euery a ston was smethe schauen. The walles were with bestes grauen, Ther was no best In wildernes, Forest, ne feld, more ne les, That thei ne were ther wele entayled, Wilde ne tame non ther fayled. BEfore the dore was set a tre, ¶ Arbor ad hostium Sign in blue, words in red (in two lines thus). . That fair and semely was to se: The tre was al of riche gold Fro the grounde vnto the mold, And alle the bowes of that erberye Were siluer & gold with-outen lye; For euere was on of siluer bry&yogh;t, A-nother of gold that was so ly&yogh;t. ¶ Ther was neuere fruyt that euere grewe That thei ne hongen ther In here hewe, But al was MS. But al that was . siluer and gold with-Inne. This werk was mad with quaynte gynne. In that halle ende was mad his dese, Richeli made it was alweyes: ¶ Ther was a bord of gret richesse, In al this world such another ther nesse MS. wesse . . In that other ende of that riche halle, Wel fair vpright a&yogh;eyn the walle, He let make a riche auter, But ther-on was neuere seid no sauter. And afftir that he sette In that ende His god Iouys, he held his frende; For whan he wolde his help craued, He wende he my&yogh;t him haue saued. ¶ A ffair ymage that kyng did make Off ffyn gold ffor his goddis sake; On that auter did he sette hit, Off pure gold was hit I-bet; Hit was .xv. cubitis long. He sette hit there with mochel song, With ffythel, harpe, and mynstrasie, With mychel merthe and melodye. ¶ He spende on him gret tresoure, Certes he loste al his laboure. He made to him a redy way Off twenti grecis of marbil gray, That he & other my&yogh;t come him to, When that thei wolde him worschepe do. And thus was maked that riche halle, As I haue told to &yogh;ow alle. ECtor liggis In Ilioun; At his hed sat kyng Menoun And Hectuba, his Moder, the quene, So did Eleyne and Pollexene; That louely lyff dame Andromede To Ector takes sche gode hede: Wel tenderly the kny&yogh;t sche &yogh;emed, That fair lady that wel be-semed. ¶ Kynges fele a-boute come And comfort him alle & some Off his hurtyng & malady, For his sorwe were thei drery. Kyng Priamus let bery With careful herte and no-thyng mury His sixe sones that died tho dayes, Euerychon be-sydes other he layes. ¶ Hic Ector sanatus est. He bad that echon schuld haue By him-self a riche graue: Here graues were sone y-made Bothe with schouele & with spade; And leyd hem ther-In bothe body & bones, And heled a-bouen with riche stones. And so was grauen eche a brother, A litel echon fro other. ¶ Thei of Grece her riche kynges Graued also, here lordynges; And tho that were of lasse renoun Thei gadered to hepes with-oute the toun And brende her bodyes alle by-dene, And made the feld of hem ful clene, That no stynk of hem schulde rise, Hem to dere on no wyse. ECtor heles and coueres faste, His Angwys almost a-way is paste, He may bothe go & stande, In that halle is he walkande; And alle these other ben ner-honde heled. Delful dyntis were ther deled, When thei were heled and comen samen; Ther by-gynne a grisly gamen: Many on schal to the dethe wende, Er thei efft-sones make an ende. ¶ For Ector was fful sore a-greued That his visage was so cleued; He het his men for euene or od, That ther hors be faste y-schod, And her harneis redi dight, Her aketoun strong, her brynys bryght; 'That hors ne harneis &yogh;ow not faile A-&yogh;eyn the tyme of oure batayle.' WInter is went—as I wene— The leues growen In greues grene, The ffloures sprede & spedly sprynge, The thrustil sittes & mury synge, The sonne is hote, the terme goth out. The Troiens are bothe stiff & stout, And so ar Danes and eke Gregeis: Alle &yogh;are thei ben In here harneis For to fare & that stoure mayntene, But thei schal passe with moche tene. ¶ The trewes is passed and alle termened, And alle ben redy & haue dyned, Many an helme is set on hede That long er nyght schal ligge dede; The ladyes for her lordes caren, For thei wot neuere how thei schal faren; Thei made gret mornyng a-mong, Thei tare hir heer, hir handis wrong. ¶ The lordes hem busked & toke here caples, Men brynge hem speres of gode maples, And scheldes stronge thei brynge als, To honge semely a-boute her hals. ¶ Ector bad thei schulde ride, Thei wol not lenger here abyde: Thei riden forth out of the toun With scheld and spere & gonfanoun. And thei of Grece were gadered alle With-oute the diche be-fore the walle, In-myddis the feld ther standis her stale. And thei of Troye riden doun a dale, Til thei mete to-geder bothe; Two hundred thousand schal be wrothe Er thei do parte fro her frende, That schal be sclayn, er thei thennes wende. NOw are thei bothe In the feld arayed, Adhuc bellum In the top right corner, in a very fine hand. . Baneres brode ther ben displayed; On nother side was non so bold That thei ne be-gynne sone to cold, Whan thei schal mete thore: The beste of hem a-bached wore, Saue Ector on that neuere was ferd; He &yogh;eues of hem not a &yogh;erd, Off alle her fare, of thai were mo, For he blan neuere to wende and sclo ¶ Alle he myght mete with & ouer-take; He be-gynnes a-boute him to make Wayes to driue In bothe cart & wayn. Many Gregeis other gan frayn: "How thei my&yogh;t sclo him ther he rode?" But ther was non that him a-bode: He &yogh;ede doun or lost his lyff. He sclow a thousand In that stryff, When bothe parties to-gedur were; Many a man died there. ¶ Ther was gret del to se hem mete, So fele fel doun vndir hors fete, That neuere my&yogh;t afftirward arise, Thei made a schrewed marchaundise: Eche slo other, as thei were wode, Thei made no ruthe of mannes blode; Some is cloven In-to the shere, Some has lorn bothe cheke & ere, Some hath lorn lyuer & gut, Was many man ded doun put, Many hath lorn eye & browe; Euerychon wolde his frend rescowe, Than comes he & he also And girdes his bak euen a-two. And thus ferd thei fro that thei met, Til the sonne was doun set MS. pet . ; Thei blan neuere to smyte ne slo, Many a bak thei made al blo. ECtor fyghtes with his enemys, Thorow here ost he rod thris, Fro man to man a-boute he skyppis, Thei fel afftir him as hit were shepis: For siker, sithe erthe by-gan, Was not made a better man, That so stronge dedes In Armes did; Alas that euere him mys-be-tid! ¶ Off man was neuere so moche reuthe, For he was good & loued trewthe; Ther was no man that did suche dedis Off alle the kny&yogh;tes that men of redis, Ther was neuere man his strok my&yogh;t stande, That toke a ful stroke of his hande,— Saue Achilles that strong kny&yogh;t, For he was man of moche my&yogh;t.— Ther was no side of al that ost That he ne rode thorow ffor alle her bost. ¶ He sclow to grounde al that he toke, The beste of hem for drede quoke, Thei were alle aferd of that on kny&yogh;t, For he was man of moche my&yogh;t. The Gregeis alle his sword knewe, Many a man to grounde he hewe; And tho he bar doun or ouer, Ful ffewe a-&yogh;eyn ne myght couer,— Vn-til that lyff so sore he smot. The sonne schon bry&yogh;t, the day was hot. ¶ Hit greued hem sore of Grece, Thei sat toterynge as it were gece— What for the strokes & the hete! The Gregeis wel sore he gan bete, He made of hem gret martirdam: I trowe, sithen god made Adam, Dud neuere man so gret meruayles, In fightes fele and gret batayles He sclow so many grete of renoun, Armed with helme and hauberioun, As Ector did his owne hand, The while he was In erthe lyvand. ¶ Gret voyce was tho hem among, Swerdis ther on helmes rong, Many an helme was ther clatered, And many hede al to-batered MS. alto batered . . Ector makes of hem grete hepes, Fro man to man a-boute he lepis; As thik as leue on the tre He sles hem doun by two or thre. Thorow the feld hit is wel sene In euery stede ther he hath bene, For it is layd with dede bodies Thikkere than trees ar set In ris. ¶ He makes a-boute him roume & way. Achilles wot not what to say, Offte hath he that day him met, But he my&yogh;t neuere his proues bet, Ne he durst not for ferd of gyle Dele with him that ilke whyle, And if he scholde not haue grace, To parte with him out of that place. THe Gregeis saw this fare was nou&yogh;t A-&yogh;eyn the dedis that Ector wrou&yogh;t, Thei my&yogh;t not y-wis lenger endure, Thei swalt almost In her Armure; ¶ Hic Greci ffugerunt. Thei fled euerychon, and that was best,— The sonne was drawen to his rest, And that was fair to here be-houe,— For thei hadde elles euel proue. The Gregeis fled with michel hast; Wo was hem that was the last,— Ector sclow hem In that chace.
