Men my&yogh;t ffolwe hem by the trace Off dede bodyes he lefft ligande, The Gregeis he sclow fleande. ¶ Achilles was not then the laste, That he were then he hyed faste; And Ector faste afftir him prikes, He drof him home vn-to his dikes And turned a-&yogh;eyn—for it was ny&yogh;t,— He fau&yogh;t lenger than he hadde sy&yogh;t: He rod to Troye with his prisonnes And lefft hem In her pauylonnes. ECtor is to Troy riden, Priamus him hath abiden. Off his mete and his sopere, Thei are now set to-geder In-fere, Thei are wel serued with many metis, With murthe & play thei sitte In setis: His fader him makes mochel Ioye, And so did alle that were In Troye. ¶ The fader blessed offte his sone; He hadde ther many a benysone Off lordis faire & fre ladyse, Of kny&yogh;tes kene and men of pryse. For ther died mo at that semble, That Ector sclow at that Iorne With his hand—as thei seyde alle— Then alle that euere fre and thralle. So fele men died then In o day Off no mannes hond—I dar wel say— In hard batayle that Armed. were, As Ector sclow with his hand there;— He was wel serued, honourd & kepe. When thei hadde souped, thei wente to slepe And rest hem, til the sonne vp rose: Eche man then to arme him gose, ¶ Thei toke her horses & here a-tyre With swerdes gode aboute here swire, And ryden forth vpon a res. &YOGH;it wol thai not be In pes, Ten thousand schal her lyff for-sake, Er thei thenke reste to take. NOw haue thei taken the feld bothe, Ful Irrous & Inly wrothe. Thei are now MS. not . to-geder met, Her speres ar broken, and arwes schet, Thei drowe her swordes of here scauberkes, Ther cleue scheldes & hauberkes, The riche armure thei al to-kerue; Ther schal a thousand er euen sterue: Echon other al to-drawes, Thei cutte In-two bothe lyuer & mawes, ¶ Hand & hede, lunge & mylte; Many a gode man was ther spilte. Whil thei hadde day & my&yogh;t out se, Wolde thei neuere In pes be. Thei fau&yogh;t thus clene dayes twelue, Til thei hadde nede here dede men delue, And thei of Grece mouth not ordayn To fyght for-sothe no more sustayn; So were thei ouercomen & taken And with Ector holden waken At the foot of the page are some scribblings upside down. , That thei most rest or elles dye. It was past afftir the Maye, The weder was hot, the sonne schon, The Gregeis made ther-fore gret mone: For thorow ffight and the hete Many on lefft that day the swete. TWelff dayes fau&yogh;t thei to-geder With-outen rest In that hote weder; Be-twene hem died many a lord, Whil thei were at that discord; Many a lord on ayther syde Were ded In tho twelue dayes tyde. The Gregeis my&yogh;t fyght no more, Thei asked trewes with sikyng sore, ¶ Off xxx ti dayes thei faire be-sou&yogh;t, Til the dede were In the erthe brou&yogh;t, And til that hete were al doun; For elles hadde thei ben ded echoun: So gret was thanne the hete In feld, Thei my&yogh;t not lyue In tent & teld That wounded were or hurtyng hadde. A, Priamus! that thow was madde, When thow the trewes so ly&yogh;tly graunted! For haddes thow thenne that batayle haunted, Thei schulde haue died with gret vilte, With swerd at that gret mortalite! ¶ But ffortune was thi foo mortel And schop thi wo perpetuel; And for sche wolde thi blysse were doun, Sche made the graunte the trewes soun. For sicur I wot with-outen drede: The formast day the trewes out &yogh;ede, That thei to-geder In feld were met, Her blis & Ioye for euere was let. ¶ Hic Priamus concedit pacem xxx. dies. PRiamus hath graunted the trewe: The Gregeis maken murthe & glewe, Thei were neuere of trewe so blythe; Thei thanked her god fele sithe, For thei saued hem by her pauste Fro that gret mortalite; Thei maken to him gret offeryng With many broche & many ryng, And thanked hem of here dede, For thei wende efft better spede. ¶ Thei were ful fayn thei were at rest, For thei ther-of hadde mychel brest, Thei heled her woundes lesse & more, That woundes haue or any sore. So were thei hole or thritti day, For thenne was the grette hete away, And thei were styff & stout To renne & ride al a-bout, And do al thyng that mister was, Thei dredde not the Troyens a gras. ¶ Thritti dayes are now ful-filled, Alas! noble Troye, thow schalt be spilled, Thrawen doun & ligge al wast, For thow schalt lese thi lord In hast! This is the day of thin vnwyn, Alle may wepe that the ben In, Kyng and quene that to the longe; Wele may thow wepe & leue thi songe! Alle Troiens may say: weylaway! That euere come this Ilke day! ¶ Alas thi chambres & thi boures, Thi faire hall and thi toures, Thi semely &yogh;ates & thi faire walles, And alle thi crafftly corven balles! ¶ Lamentacio super Troianos. ¶ Fair Ilyon that stondes so hye, So lowe as thow schalt sone lye! Suche a Cite was neuere non wrou&yogh;t, Al schal sone turne to nou&yogh;t; But thow may say as gode Iob sayde, When he with sorwe was be-layde: He cursed the day that he was borne For wo that was leyd him be-forne, He bad it turne to derknes And euere be as thesternes. ¶ And so may thow that day banne, That the batayle furst be-ganne, Afftir the trewes was y-past: Alas, that ne hit hadde lenger last For Troye that was wel mayntened! Hadde he that day him abstened, He scholde haue ben conquerour Off his enemys with gret honour! PRiamus, this is the day That thow schalt lese thi noblay, Thi mayntenaunce and thi defence, Thyn honour & thi reuerence! This day thow leses thi seygnorie, For gode Ector this day schal dye, That the defended and thi kynrede, Thi landes & thi manhede. ¶ Now artow lord of thi landis, Many a duk byfore the standis, The hodes offe MS. offte. & bare the heued,— Sone schal it fro the be reued! That now bene thyne be trouthe y-ply&yogh;t, Schal lete of the wel sone ful ly&yogh;t! The au&yogh;t euere to curse that day, That fals god now the helpe ne may; At this nede may he not helpe No more then may a dogge whelpe MS. wlelpe. . Mochel sorwe was the toward, When thei of Troye ride out-ward; And so was also thi faire wyff, Wherfore scho afftir lase hir lyff; And Pollexene with-outen gilt Afftirward therfore was spilt. ¶ A, dou&yogh;ti Troyle, at euery a dede, Vn-to that day that thow take hede! What harme that day to the be-felle! Thow may telle of thi tenselle, And say, if thow be ri&yogh;t be halwed, Alas, that euere that day be-dawed— For to lese that the was leue & dere! For if he hadde lyued thre &yogh;ere, Thow haddest ben kyng of many a land Thorow strengthe of thi brother hand; For whan he died, &yogh;e died alle; Suche hap was to &yogh;ow be-falle. Allas, lady dame Andromede, This is the day that thow may drede, This is the day of thi gret wo, For thow schal now thi lord for-go! Thow schal lese the worthiest kny&yogh;t That euere was wedded to any wy&yogh;t; For hadde he lyued, thow hadde be quene Off many a land—& that was sene,— Thow haddest ben quene of Troye & dame. But now schal it turne al to schame, For thow scha[l]t falle In suche maystry, That the schal lede In vylony, In sclaunder and In foule schendyng, Al thi lyff to thyn endyng. Kny&yogh;tes kene that ben of Troye, Now make murthe and mochel Ioye; ¶ Alle Are &yogh;e bold for Ector sake, Gret is the murthe that &yogh;e may make, &YOGH;e drede no leuynge creature, So ar &yogh;e sicur of him & sure. But &yogh;it schal &yogh;e, or sonne go doun, Alle that are In feld & toun Sey "alas!" for sorwe & care, "That day that euere &yogh;oure moder &yogh;ow bare!" A, Curteis Citeseyns, Trewe & triste gode Troiens, Herde I neuere of no burgeis That were so hende & so curteis. Alas! me rewes &yogh;oure destene,— That were of &yogh;oure &yogh;ifftes so fre, Off noble blod & genterye, Off gret manhede & curtesye,— ¶ That &yogh;oure noblay & &yogh;oure largesse, &YOGH;oure curtesye & &yogh;oure richesse Schal turne to nou&yogh;t, and &yogh;e also! Fals fortune wol &yogh;ow for-do, For deth has sche y-schaped, Sche wil no wyse that he be skaped. And he be ded & fro &yogh;ow gon, &YOGH;e ben dede euerychon! &YOGH;oure brochis brode & al &yogh;oure byes That now ligges In &yogh;oure tyes, ¶ &YOGH;oure tresoure & &yogh;oure florayns Wol sche dele to kny&yogh;tis & swayns Off hem of Grece that are &yogh;oure foos. This is the day that all goos, &YOGH;oure gret noblay & &yogh;oure seygnorye Schal turne to dele & waymentrye. ¶ Hic Andromeda vxor Ectoris sompniauit de morte ipsius. THat louely lyff dame Andromede The laste ny&yogh;t the trewes out-&yogh;ede,— That thei schulde ffight afftir the day,— By her lord In hir bed sche lay: A dredful dreme that lady dremed, That In hir sclepe sche cried & scremed. ¶ The while sche was In hir sclepe, Ector &yogh;aff to hir good kepe, Sche was sore & sche was dredful, To wakyn hir it was nedful; He waked hir & seide: 'swetyng, Thow art ful ferd In thi sclepyng. Whi fares thow thus? what ayles the? Whi art thow ferd? what may this be?' 'Alas!' seyde sche, 'my gentil lord! But thow wil do be myn acord, Sicurly thow ne art but dede,— But thow wil do afftir my rede,— And I am lorn for euere also, And thi louely children two! For I am sicur be my dreme, That I am lorn, and thi barne-teme; And thow art ded with-outen fayle, If thow this day go to batayle. ¶ For I wot be my drem to-ny&yogh;t: If thow to-morne gos to fy&yogh;t, With-oute the deth may thow not passe; Then may I say for the "alas! That I was borne!" for care & sorwe. Be-leue at hom, my lord, to-morwe And come not there,—I the be-seche!— To my prayeres thow be my leche, Be at home, til al be done! For goddis loue here my bone!' 'FI a debles MS. b , distinctly, not v ; cf. l. 10746. !' seyde the kny&yogh;t, 'Thow art drecched with som euel wy&yogh;t; Hit is foly and vnsemyng A man to leue on MS. or. fals dremyng: Offt are men thorow hem be-swiked, And so was thow, whan thow scryked. A man that liggis In sclepe & dremes, It is not as hit thenne semes Off alle that euere he sclepande thought; When he is wakyng, it is nought. He is a fole that In hem leues Or any faith vnto hem &yogh;eues. ¶ Leue thi wordes & thy wepyng And holde thi pes, hit was sclepyng! A thousand dremes men may dreme, And &yogh;iff he &yogh;eue to hem gode &yogh;eme, He schal not fynde what on be-menes, For no-thyng falles as it schewes.' ¶ The ny&yogh;t is went, the day dawes: Ector is wroth with his wyues sawes, His wyues wordes Ector dispises; He toke his clothes and vpward rises, He is wel wroth toward his wiff, He biddis here vpon hir lyff "Hir wepyng leue, hir wordes holde, That sche no more be so bolde To crye ne wepe ne tales telle Off thynges that is not worth a schelle." ¶ Gret is the sorwe that sche makes, Sche wrynges hir hondes, hir hede schakes, As wyght that was with wo y-wounden And In bales was sche bounden; Sche drow hir heer & scratte hir face, Sche weped & cried and seyde "alace! That euere schuld sche abide the day!" Sche wente as sche were wod a-way. ¶ To Hectuba, his moder, sche ran,— As sche hadde ben a wod womman,— And to hir suster Pollexene; Thei wende that sche wod hadde bene, Thei asked "whi that sche so ferde?" 'For tydandes that I haue herde And sene also slepyng to-ny&yogh;t,' Saide Andromede, that bridde bry&yogh;t, 'A dreme for-sothe that not lyes, That thus mechel signifies: That, If my lord this day out gange, On lyue lyues he not lange; If he this day to batayle go, His enemys schal or euen him sclo. A-&yogh;eyn comes he on lyue no more, If he go out—be goddis ore! ¶ But thow that bare him of thi sidis And has for-don the Gregeis pridis— Off Chiualrie he is the flour, And thi defence & thi socour, That saues the & thi housbonde, Thi tounes, thi toures, & thi londe, Thi sones & alle thi doughtres als,— Let him neuere dye of no wyk-hals! Make him at hom this day to be, That he come not at that semble! For be he ded & fro vs went,— That we were borne schal vs repent!' HEctuba for ferd & drede Was ner wod, when Andromede These tydandes whan sche hir tolde, For sche wiste neuere, how him to holde, ¶ Hic Andromeda narrauit Regi & Regine. That he come not at that assaut; Sche hadde for him ful mychel aut, Gret sorwe then made the quene; And so hadde als dame Pollexene. ¶ 'Go we,' sche sayde, 'to the kyng And telle we him of this tythyng! For ther is non that so wel may Make him to be at home to-day.' These ladyes thenne fair and fre To Priamus &yogh;ede then alle thre And grete the kyng—as thei wel couthe— With louely wordes of thaire mouthe: 'HErkene, sir,' seyde Andromede, 'Mi louely lord, my dreme thow rede! As I to-ny&yogh;t by my lord lay, A litel be-fore the spryng of the day A wonder drem gan I mete, That doth me thus to me to wete,— I se qwat it sygnifie th erased after the last word of this line. ,— And do ther-to som remedie, To make my lord that he go noght To that stede that he hath thoght. ¶ For sikur! if that he go, He is lorne, and we also! Thow schalt [him] neuere with eyen se Come a-&yogh;eyn on lyue to the, For my drem—that is hidous— Openly be-menes thus: That if he to-day to batayle ride, He schal be ded by euen-tyde.' ¶ When Priamus that drem hadde herd, As he schulde dye, for-sothe he ferd; The water brast out at his eyen, Him thoght he my&yogh;t for sorwe dyen, Him thoght his herte gan to breke; He stode longe, or he myght speke, For sorwe & care that he hadde hent, When he wiste what the dreme ment. 'Whether I schal,' he sayde, 'alas! Lese my Ioye & my solas, Mi defence & my socour, And lede my liff In dishonour, In wo, & drede, & paynes strong, And alle that euere vn-to me long, ¶ Scholde I now lese my gode sone? I schal him helpe, if I cone, That he this day go not to fyght On hors ne fote,—by god al-myght!— That he die neuere for vnhap. For if he may this on day sckap, Wele wot I that he schal schende Alle his fos & saue his frende. ¶ For may he passe his destane, Conquerour then schal he be Off his fo-men, thei schal hem &yogh;elde To him & his and fle the felde.' THe sonne be-gynnes on hye to schyne, Troiens ar alle set to dyne, Thei ben serued with many a coupe; Euel schal thei or euen droupe, For thei schal se or euen ded The beste body that euere ete bred. ¶ Ector ordeynes his batayles alle, He biddis hem Troyle to him calle; And he come to him faste ridande, With helme on hed & spere In hande, Armed wel In iren wede. Ector bad that he scholde lede ¶ Hic incipit Bellum in quo Ector Interfectus fuit. The formast warde, the furste eschele, And come a-&yogh;eyn with Ioye and hele. ¶ He called to him Paris, his brother, And bad that he scholde lede that other. Afftir that he called Eueas,— And he come a ful gode pas,— He seis: 'Eueas, I the bidde That thow lede the batayle thridde; And thow the ferthe, Polydomas, To helpe him when he nede has.' ¶ The ffiffthe batayle Ector be-tau&yogh;t— With alle the men that he ther au&yogh;t— To Sarpedoun, that dou&yogh;ti kyng, And other mo In his ledyng. ¶ The sixte ledde kyng Episcropus, A noble kyng and curtayus, With many a dou&yogh;ti bacheler. Ector bad hem come him ner A dou&yogh;ti kyng with visage grym. The eyght batayle be-tau&yogh;t he him: He hete Forcius—I vndirstande,— He bad him lede the ward eyghtande. ¶ The ix. batayle—as I wene— Be-tau&yogh;t Ector to Philomene MS. Pollexene . . A dou&yogh;ti kyng of gret pouste, Hardi of hert and gret bounte, And other kynges that comen wore In help of Troye, that were thore. PRyamus the kyng [hem] seygned, When Ector hadde hem thus ordeyned; He &yogh;aff echon to that batayle Leue to wende, her fos to assayle; For thei of Grece were comen be than With-oute her diches, eueryche man, And redi dight, & hem abode; And thei of Troye vnto hem rode. But he bad Ector al on hye, Heryng alle MS. a lle , probably meant for Alle. that were him nye: "That he ne scholde that day armes bere Ne entermete him of that were, But be at hom with him that day— On his blessyng, & say not nay." ¶ Lord! so he wex wod wroth Toward his wyff, purful & loth! When his ffader Priamus Be-fore hem Alle hadde bidden him thus: Ful vilensly his wyff he chidde For that schame that sche him didde; But he wold not do his biddyng, He bade his men vnto him bryng His hauberioun and his target, His Aketoun and his basenet. ¶ His men did as he hem bad. When Andromede saw hir lord had His Armure In hand to Arme him with, Sche cried out on kyn & kyth, That sche was brou&yogh;t In-to this world. When Hectuba this word herd, ¶ Sche ran thedir as sche were wod Be-ffore Ector ther he stod; Vpon hir knes tho fel the quene, And his suster Pollexene, And Andromede kneled also And broght with hir hir childur two: That on of hem was &yogh;it so &yogh;ong MS. &yogh;oug. That he ne coude speke with tong, He coude ete no bred of whete, He soukede then his moder tete. ¶ Hic rogauerunt Ectorem quod non ibat ad prelium illo die. ¶ The Moder spak to hir child With herte fre & wordes my[l]d: 'Sone,' sche seyde, 'loke the be-forn! I am thi Moder that the hath born; Fourty wekes &yogh;ede I with the With paynes stronge, rewe now on me For alle that wo & al that pyne I suffred for the and brether thyne. With-say not here my beheste, My comaundement, ne my requeste! Vn-Arme the at my prayere, As thow louest me & thi wyff here!' POllexene & quene Elayne Prayed him also,—al was In vayne. When Andromede saw al that, How his Moder ther on knes sat, Vpon hir knes sore wepande, And quene Eleyne loude cryande, His sustres alle with sore chere, And [he] wolde hem not here:— ¶ Sche toke the child In her lap That was soukyng at her pap, By-fore his feet fel sche doun For sorwe & care In a ded sowne. When sche was rysen & sat on knes: 'This is thi sone that thow here ses,' Seyde Andromede, '& I thi wiff. For him that made bothe deth and lyff! Beleue at hom this day with me And go not out to this semble! ¶ And if thin [mod] be now so hard That thow of me haue no reward, Rewe opon this &yogh;onge thyng, Thi sones bothe that I here bryng! That I ne dye neuere ne thei euel ded, Ne go so pore to begge oure bred In straunge land & In exile, Saue me & hem fro deth vile! And lete vs now thin Armes of take For thi louely childer sake! And leue her-Inne this day alone That thow this day bere Armes none!' ¶ The ladies hadde gret pyne, The water ran out of here ey&yogh;ene, That it wet that louely lere; &YOGH;it wolde he not hir prayeres here. His wiff wepes with reuful chere, The teres fallen on hir lere, Off hir eyen hit rennes out, Thei wete hir chekes al a-bout, Sche ffalles offte In ded sownyng: But he &yogh;aff of hem no thyng, ¶ But Armed him & toke his stede, And lep vp sone & fro hem &yogh;ede; Toward the feld he hyed him faste Fro the ladies, that he were paste. WHen Andromede saw hir lord go, Lord god! what hir was wo! Sche skrat hir face—as sche were wod— Til it was ronnen al on blod, Sche rente hir clothes & hir heer tare; Mechel sorwe made sche thare, Sche was almost of hir wit. The lady thanne hir clothes vp knyt, ¶ Sche ran to kyng Priamus, As sche that was ful angwisus MS. ful of angwisus. . So was sche blod and al for-scrat, That kyng ne none that by him sat Wiste In erthe what sche was. When thei hir knew, thei seyde: 'alas!'— 'What ayles the, my derlyng?' To hir seyde Priamus, the kyng. Er sche my&yogh;t speke, sche swoned ther, Alle hadde reuthe aboute hir wer; ¶ Thei were alle so sore meruayled, What that louely lady ayled. When sche was rysen, sche sat on knes, Hir heer was rent & torne In pes; Sche cried loude and seide alweyes, "Sche myght for no thyng be In pes." Sche seyde: 'sir kyng, whi sittes thow here? Wol thow now lese thi sone dere? Thow scholde haue &yogh;euen to him entent! For ri&yogh;t to batayle he is went; Now is he gon & fforward reden; His stede Armed he is be-striden, Vn-to the batayle for to gange; Iff thow fro him dwelle out lange, That he fro the thedir may wende, Thow art for-done, & alle thi frende; ¶ Thow schalt him neuere se more on lyue, But thow ouertake him swythe. For be it so that he come thore, On lyue ne sese thow him no more!' The kyng anon with-oute abode To his hors that he on rode, And lepe vp sone with-outen tariyng And rod afftir him with herte sikyng: ¶ He priked his hors on the pament, That afftir his feet the fir out glent; For no thyng wolde the kyng abide, Or he sey him where he gan ride. ¶ Adhuc Magnum bellum. He rode and toke him by the rayne, And pulled his stede wrothely a-&yogh;ayne, And seyde: 'Ector, thow art to blame! I comaunde the In my goddis name,— In him that is so ful of my&yogh;t And maked bothe day & ny&yogh;t,— That thow no further go fro me, But turne a-&yogh;eyn to thi Cite! As thow art treuly my sone, In my blessyng & benysone!' ECtor offte his fader with-sayd, But he his stede to him brayd, And brou&yogh;t him thanne a-&yogh;eyns his wille, With his praieres, the Cite tille. In the paleys Ector doun lyght, But he wolde not him vndyght ¶ Off his armure & his a-tire; He lefft at home with moche ire, That he was not at that sau&yogh;t. The Gregeis with the Troyens fau&yogh;t With hardi herte and gret reddure: Ther was be-twene hem a grisly stoure, Many a kny&yogh;t on grounde ther lay, And many an hors ther wente a-way,— Her guttes trayled on the grounde,— That neuere afftir her maystres founde. ¶ Troylus woundes Gregeis and sles, And he by-holdes wel Diomedes, He hadde to him wel gret envy: He thought to do with him Maystry,— That him were leuere then gret catel,— That he myght scle him In that batel; He hated him for his lemman, Cresseida Cress , possibly by same hand, on erasure. , that fair womman. He toke a spere stalworth and strong, To bere doun Troyle a-mong the throng; But Troyle saw him come ridande And toke a stalworth spere In hande, And rode to him with my&yogh;t and mayn, [And Diomedes him a&yogh;eyn,] No gap in MS. That thei fel bothe opon the grene: And toke here stedis as kny&yogh;tes kene, ¶ And bothe her swordis out thei drow And ffau&yogh;t to-geder long y-now, Til thei were stoned hede and brayn. That on that other wolde haue sclayn, Ne hadde than comen Menelaus With al his ost opon Troylus; For he come thenne with gret meyne And made these kny&yogh;tes departye. And elles I trowe with-outen les Troyle hadde sclayn Diomedes! MEnelaus is comen doun With many kny&yogh;t and bold baroun: When his men with here Ioyned, Many a man was ther assoyned Off ther lyff ther at her mote, That neuere afftirward come to bote. ¶ When Menelaus was In that presse, He saw a kyng—het Messeres,— He smot that kyng vpon the scheld, That he fel doun opon the feld. When the Gregeis saw him falle, Thei gadered a-boute him alle: ¶ Messeres wolde defende his cors, But sicurly he hadde no fors; Thei made a serkel al a-boute, That he my&yogh;t not go with-oute. Thei toke that kyng a-mong hem a-none And with him gan a-wey gone, To lede him to here pauylouns And put him with ther other prisouns. But Troyle by-gan theder to loke And say, how thay of Grece him toke: He vowed to god, "he scholde be wo, Or thei that kyng with hem lete go." ¶ He rode thedir with-oute dwellyng And be-lan neuere of men fellyng, Til he hadde take him fro her hondis And delyuered him out of his bondis. The Gregeis saw that thei mow&yogh;t nou&yogh;t Lede him a-way, as thei hadde thou&yogh;t: Thei thoght his hede of for to strike And leue him liggand vpon the dike, ¶ But come Troyle, the dou&yogh;ti kny&yogh;t, And many of hem sclow In here fy&yogh;t And made that kyng a-way to scape For al that ost & alle that frape; Then MS. But then. were Troyens bold and Ioyus. But than come doun Thelamanyus With thre thousand of dou&yogh;ti kny&yogh;tes, To helpe Gregeis with al her my&yogh;tes; On that side come he doun ridande, Ther Polidomas was ffyghtande. ¶ Thelamanyus with a spere To Polidomas rode with were And bar him doun, er he was war, And with that Iustus he smot him sar And threw him doun ouer his hors ers, That long afftirward he was the wers. He was In poynt tho him to &yogh;elde, But then come Troyle to that felde And Thelamon my&yogh;tily assayled And so hertly on him trauayled, That on hors brou&yogh;t he Polidomas Swyfliche as he rather was. PAris hath his men araied, His baner is before disp[l]ayed, He gaderes his men aboute him nowe And biddis that thei schal him folowe: To that assaut wil he now wende, His men echon her bowes thei bende, And sette In takel long and brode; To that assaut thei with him rode And schotte Gregeis & did him skathe. But Achilles was al to rathe,— Armed wel & redi dight,— To come then with many a kny&yogh;t: With al his ost come he doun tho, The Troiens faste be-gan to sclo. ¶ He hem sles & doun hem kest, Scheldes ryued, & helmes berst; His men were euere more him ner And halp him wel at his mestier: Thei leyd on Troiens strokes large, And so thei gan hem ouer-charge With stalworth strokes of her hand, That thei my&yogh;t no lenger stand. ¶ The Troiens thanne be-gan to fle, Faste ridande to here Cite, As faste as thei myght prike; Thei spared nother doun ne dike, Til thei come at here cite &yogh;ates. Achilles folwed hem algates Ouer dales & ouer dounes With his Gregeis & Murmidounes; He sclow of hem that tyme gret won, Thei fled a-way fro him echon. This line in red paint at this very place. Hic Achilles occidit Margariton filius [ sic !] Regis Troiani. THe kynges sone Margariton Saw he come hem vpon, And sclow his men—as lyoun bestis That is for-hungred In wilde forestis;— He my&yogh;t him no lenger suffer In no wyse For al the gode that was In prise: He turned his stede vn-to him son, To fyght with him was he bon, He smot vnto him strokes thore As breme as any bore. ¶ He made Achilles leue his chace, That he no lenger mordur mace; Off his chasyng he him restayed: Many a strok ther was payed, He lent him fele and him qwyt; But Margaritoun was so hit, Er he partid fro his handes, That he fel ded vpon the sandis. The Troiens made an hidous cri, When he was ded so sodanly. The dou&yogh;ti Thelamanyus To hem of Troye was envious, He chased the Troiens & thret And many of hem to grounde bet. ¶ But Paris harde his men defendis, Many an arwe he hem sendis; But for au&yogh;t that he my&yogh;t do, And al his ost with also, Thei were put vnto fly&yogh;t, Wenkyst foule, & discomfi&yogh;t. Thei token the toun with mychel spede— ¶ Troiani fugerunt In one line in MS.; the sign in blue, the words in red paint. . To saue her lyues for thei hadde nede,— And brou&yogh;t with hem that ded body, And &yogh;ede ther-with by strete & sty, Til thei come at Ilion And leyde ther doun Margariton Vpon the grounde al bledande: Many on for him was wepande. ECtor saw his brother slayn,— And for him wepes kny&yogh;t & swayn,— His colour chaunged, his herte ros, For tene Ector he wode gos: He rolled his eyen as best ramage, As he hadde fallen In a rage; He lased his helme & toke his stede, 'Tel me,' he sayde, 'who dede that dede? ¶ What is he that my brother sclow? I schal him venge, if I mow!' Thei seide: 'it was sir Achilles That sclow him with-oute les, And put vs to discomfiture, For we my&yogh;t him not endure; A-&yogh;eyn him may we make no defence With-oute &yogh;oure help & &yogh;oure presence.' ¶ Ector thanne with wrothful herte Vpon his hors lepe vp smerte, He strok his stede so with his spores That he lepe ouer lond & forwes; He spared no ston ne cause, Til he mette with his meyne. ¶ Right at the &yogh;atis met he his men, Fleande be twelue & ten; To hem wold he speke wordis non, But to his enemys &yogh;ede he alon: His fomen were sone of him dred, And thei wex bold that furst were fled, ¶ Hic Ector ibat ad prelium. For whan thei hadde of him a syght, Thei were not ferd of kyng ne kny&yogh;t. ECtor is of Troye y-went, He brak his fader comaundement, He thoght not on his benysoun That dou&yogh;ti kny&yogh;t of gret renoun: He schal lese his lyff or euen MS. euel. -tyde, A&yogh;eyn to Troie schal he not ride. With his lyff hit rewes me sore, That he that day come thore! ¶ Allas! that day he hadde no grace To be at home, as him radde wace; But sicurly he myght not fle On no manere his destane: His ffader wist not of his wendyng, He &yogh;ede ther-fore to his endyng. He sclow Gregeis and kest hem doun And droff hem alle out of the toun; ¶ The rayn fel neuere so thike on rise As Ector sclow his enemys; Was non so stiff hem among That he ne sclow hem or doun sclong, That he my&yogh;t take or ouer-reche. Off Margaritoun toke he wreche, He venged him with dynt of sword, He sclow that day many a lord. Alle that feld was vmbesprade Off dede kny&yogh;tes that lay & bledde: For sicurly he was so wroth, That wham he hit to dethe he goth; ¶ Among Gregeis he rayked, treled, With his swerd that wel was steled, Was non so strong that him sittis The strong strokes that he hem hittis. He sclow alle tho & fellde MS. fell do. ri&yogh;t With dynt of sword that he reche my&yogh;t. ¶ Achilles then, that lordly sire, Wolde not abide him In his Ire, But euere [held] fro him alone, Euere til Ector were gone. Hadde he a-biden him In his wratthe, He scholde haue had an euel batthe, He scholde haue bathed In his blode. Was none so strong that him with-stode, That he ne lay ded vpon the sondes With stalworth strokes of his hondes. If a man hadde with him ben A-mong Troiens, and hadde sen Alle the meruayles that he wrou&yogh;t, He wolde euere haue In his thou&yogh;t Off his endyng and his myschaunce, And of his foule encombraunce As he hadde of his lyue. He sclow of hem hundres fyue And ten ther-to MS. &yogh;er to. , er he wolde sese; He droff a-&yogh;eyn-ward alle the prese, He droff hem alle a-&yogh;eyn bacward For drede of dethe her tentis toward. ECtor fightes vpon that hethe, Many a man doth he to dethe: Was non so bold that durst him mete, That he ne fel doun In the strete; He deled a-boute him euel knockis, Her armure ferde as it were frockis. Al that euere stode In his way He felde hem doun as clottis of clay, He smot a man som-tyme on-two, And som-tyme man & hors also; He sclow and wounded &yogh;ong and olde, A&yogh;eyn his strok my&yogh;t no stel holde. ¶ Hit was a wonder for to se, What men he sclow at that Iorne; To se the syght hit was delful, How euery plud of blod stode ful MS. stodeful. Off men that he ther slees & felles, The blod ran doun as water of welles. ¶ He barst her mayles and al to-tatred, The scheldis of hem he al to-clatered. Thei knewe wel sone that it was he, And fro his strokes gan [t]he[i] fle; He sclow of hem many a score. His men that were y-fled MS. yfeld. be-fore, He turned a-&yogh;eyn In that assaut, And bitterly with hem he faut. ADou&yogh;ti duke, Euripolus, An[d] an other, Hastidius, He saw how Ector scheldes roff And al that ost a-&yogh;eyn-ward droff: He ffau&yogh;t his on a-&yogh;eyn alle, He sclow her men and made hem falle, The blod of men a-boute him flowed. Vnto her goddis thei bothe a-vowed "For al his fare he scholde be b altered from h. met, And of his dedis he scholde be let." ¶ When these dukes hadde bothe y-sworn, With alle her men thei wente be-forn And layd opon him strokes faste, And al a-boute him thei be-caste. But I wot neuere, what it a-vayled? For whan he was with hem assayled, He sclow hem bothe In-myddes the ost For al here Iangelynge and her bost; And many an-other moder sone He brak of bothe the scheltrone: Thei fled a-way as thei my&yogh;t go,— For thei saw he MS. he saw thei. wolde hem MS. him. slo,— Thei durst therfore no lenger dwelle, But fled fro him—the sothe to telle. ¶ The stoure was gret and perilous, The noyse was gret & hidous: Troiens were than a-&yogh;eyn turned, That furst for drede her fomen scorned; Opon her foos &yogh;ede thei hedelynge And wounded sore bothe kny&yogh;tes & kynge. But thei of Grece Polidomas toke And faste a-weyward with him schoke, ¶ Thei wende haue had him prisoner, But thei be-fel foule encomber MS. encombranser. The scribe first wrote encombranse , and then forgot to strike out the rans , when he altered it to encomber ; cf. l. 1617. Off his takyng & his ledyng: Thei my&yogh;t him not to her tentis bryng, As thei wende to haue y-done, For Ector come to hem sone. ¶ Whan he was war of his takyng, He come to him faste schakyng; Among that hepe strok he his stede Polidomas that then wolde lede, And dalt ther strokes on eche a side To his fomen that were vnride. He bar here feet ouer thaire hede, Many of hem did he to dede; He sclow that tyme two hundred & mo With his hond for-sothe tho. POlidomas that thenne led, Thei lete him go, and fro him fled. He made a-mong hem suche debate, That thei were ferd of him & mate; Thei lete go quyte Polidomas, And seide euerychon that while 'alas!' Hem Angered sore, whan he was tan. For he was two hundred mennes ban Or it was passed myd-ouer-none; Hadde him last lyff, he hadde for-done The Gregeis alle with-oute lye, But he most nede that day dye; For destane ches his chaunce so, That he most nede that day go to, That day forsothe, or it were euen— As Andromede saw In here sweuen. ¶ Herkenes! as &yogh;e schal here, How he died & In what manere: For ther byfore long y-gon He fau&yogh;t with Gregeis many on, He fau&yogh;t somtyme with ten thousand, &YOGH;it my&yogh;t thei not his strokes with-stand; Was non so strong on Gregeis side, That durst him In his yre a-byde. Achilles met neuere with him &yogh;it, That he ne &yogh;af him an euel fit; For al his my&yogh;t & his prowes He partied neuere fro him harmles, That he ne was wounded & euel dyght For all that he was so hardy a knyght. ECtor hath quyt Polidomas And brou&yogh;t him out of al that cas, He rightes his helm & wele amendes, And to his meyne he him sendes, And askes of hem: "whether that thei slepe, Whi thei the lord no better kepe?" ¶ He turned him then to hem of Grece And hewes her bodies al to pece; Thei falle afftir him as doth the leues In wynter-tyme that growes on greues; He layde hem doun alle be-dene And made the way of hem ful clene. Ther my&yogh;t non stande that he smot; The Gregeis made a sore lot And seyde: "but god did bote, Thei were euerychon vndir his fote." ¶ Ther was o Grece an Ameral, That saw how Ector wrou&yogh;t bale A-mong Gregeis, how he hem &yogh;eled, And with his swerd he hem steked: He felde hem doun as hadde ben tres. The duk men cleped Leochynes; Him thoght for sorwe his herte bledis, Ful faste to Ector he him spedis And stroke him with al his my&yogh;t, For he him fond In suche a ply&yogh;t That he wende for-sothe certayn That he scholde him haue sclayn. ¶ But hit was noght as he supposed, Thow he were duk & kny&yogh;t a-losed, Thow he were duk & kny&yogh;t a-pert And fond him thenne at discouert: He sclow him not, but hurt him so That helm & coyfe cleue In-two, And carf of him bothe heer & hide, And &yogh;aff Ector a wounde vnride. ¶ But Ector stille on his hors sat, That he fel not to grounde with that; But whan he felte that he was smetyn,— As men fynde of him y-wreten,— He was so wroth, & wex ner wode, That he of him hadde so rau&yogh;t blode: ¶ Hic Ector occidit leochiden. ¶ Then he smot him vpon the hede, That he ete neuere afftir brede; He smot him vpon his croune, That to his hors he cleue him doune; He cleue him euen in-two amyddes— 'Go on deblis Cf. note to l. 10027, p. 296. !' he him biddes, 'Ho made the,' he sayde, 'so bold To smyte me thus, and not me told?' ¶ The duk hade of him suche houselle, On bothe the sides his hors he felle; As he hadde ben a clouen hogge, The duke hanged as a frogge. For wratthe & tene that Ector was hirt, Many ffro her lyues sterst; He made suche hepes of dede bodies Off dou&yogh;ti kny&yogh;tes that were of pris, That non durst him than a-byde Ne In his way not ones ryde. AChilles houes euere atrayn And saw what lordes he hadde sclayn, Lordes and kny&yogh;tes In his wodnesse, Mo then he coude nombre or gesse. Achilles than In his herte thoght: "But if Ector were to dethe broght Hastily with som qweyntyse, Or scleght, by som skynnes wyse, The Gregeis scholde neuere day y-se That thei of Troye schuld Maystered be; For no strengthe my&yogh;t a-vayle, For nou&yogh;t that he coude assayle." He ceste therfore In his wit, How thei my&yogh;t of him be qwit With som quayntyse that he my&yogh;t do, That he were the deth sone brou&yogh;t to. Many a sleght & many a compas Achilles In his hert cast, How he my&yogh;t Ector ful-fille His strong compas & alle his wille. Whil Achilles him be-thoght How Ector scholde to dethe be brou&yogh;t, ¶ Ector saw a duk ridande Among that prese with sword In hande, He felde Troiens In many stedes, And on her bodies rides & tredes. The duk was cleped Polynetes, He come thedir for Achilles At him his sustur for to craue, For he wolde hir to his wiff haue; ¶ He was a man of moche hauyng, Ther was non richer kny&yogh;t ne kyng A-mong hem alle In that route Then was that duk with-oute doute; Fro the ferthest side of Inde Come he thedir, so was he kynde To Achilles for his suster sake, For he wolde hir haue to his make. As he rode thus a-boute r[a]ykande, With hem of Troye thus laykande, He met Ector right In his way; That Angred him sone—I dar wel say: Ector saw how that he sclow His men of Troye wel y-now, He felde hem doun & hurt hem ofte: He spake to him nother loude ne soffte, ¶ He layd at him with gret dispite, He asked not ones what he hite, But lete a strok to him fle Opon his hed a-bouen his eye; ¶ Hic Ector occidit Polyneten. He cleue his helm & scheld eke, He cleue him doun In-to the breke. The Gregeis than be-gan to daren, When thei the duk say so faren; Ther were none armes that him with-stode,— Were thei maked neuere so gode,— A-&yogh;eyn the strok that he smot, That thei [ne brast] a-none fot hot. ¶ Thei seyde: "he was the deuel of helle, And thei were foles ther lengur to dwelle, A&yogh;eyn him fight lengur to holde; Ne were thei kny&yogh;tes neuere so bolde"— 'He cleues oure men as him-self lykes, He kylles oure men & to dethe strikes.' Thei seyde: "the deuel of helle pit! Out of here land myght thei not flit, A&yogh;eyn Ector batayle to rayse, So wele as thei were alle at ayse At home vche-on on over line, but by the same hand. In thaire contre; The deuel hem made to passe the se, To ligge ther ded vpon the sondes I-sclawe MS. I. sclawe. with the Troyens handes." THat MS. W Hat . duk was clouen In two parties, On eyther halff his hors he lyes; Hit was ruthe se how he honged, A-boute the sadel the hors him flonged, Til he him ouer his sadel cast Vndir hors feet at the last. ¶ To se that duke was it lothely; Achilles loked then wrothely Vpon Ector with-outen les, For he hadde sclayn Polynetes. He swere "he scholde venge that kny&yogh;t, If his god wolde, with al his my&yogh;t." ¶ Achilles than to Ector rennes,— As lyoun doth out of her dennes, When thei are hungred, afftir bestes That thei se walke In wilde forestes:— He wende haue smeten Ector sore; But he was hurt, or he come thore, For Ector was war of him wel, He wiste his purpos euery del, He wiste wel al that he ment. A darte to him Ector sent, And at Achilles he it threw, That he hit wele, he knew; Thorow his scheld a dart he droff, That scheld and hauberk al to-roff; Thorow his Aketoun & his hide He smot him eueli thorow his side. ¶ Achilles saw that he was hurt, Off his purpos was he lurt; He saw he hadde euere the werre, He held his hors & wolde no ferre, But rod him to his Pauyloun, And kest of helme and aketoun, And bond his hed & wel stopped; His herte for Anger ffaste hopped, That he toke of him suche dispit. He byndes his woundes & wel dit Cf. note to ll. 2303-4. , And kest vpon him newe a-tire, And rides a-&yogh;eyn In mochel Ire And thenkes that he schal Ector sclo, Thoow he ther to dethe go. AChilles now his stede be-strides, To fight a-&yogh;eyn faste he rides; His wounde is wel & wisly boundoun, He MS. To. take a spere was kyndely groundoun. The spere was tow & long, Gret, & styff, & wonder strong, Off two thousand was hit the best, For it scholde not on him berst By no manere In his strikynge, Hit was a spere at his lykynge; He thouthe to sle Ector with-al— Alas the while! for he so schal! ECtor rides & raykes a-boute, Off no man hadde he no doute, Off no mannes pride he ne thou&yogh;te, Off no mannes leuyng told he nou&yogh;t, To kyng ne kny&yogh;t &yogh;aff he no tent; That gode body ther-fore was schent, He fau&yogh;t euere-more In one, He leues stondyng be-fore him none, He is to hem an euel gest, He fightes euere with-outen rest: He sclow two thousand, er he be-lan; Thei seyde he was non erthely man. ¶ Ther was a duk of gret astate, A&yogh;eyn Ector held debate, Among Troiens faste he skayred, And hurt him sore, & euel hem payed. Ector loked toward that duke And saw his men of him rebuke, He hied him thedur with mychel hast, And quyk be-gan him for to cast: ¶ Ector him droff so with his my&yogh;t, That he defende him ne my&yogh;t, He &yogh;eld his swerd & his knyff And bad Ector saue his lyff. And Ector sayde: "he wolde him saue, But he wolde him prisoner haue." ¶ Hic Achilles occidit Ectorem. ¶ Ector was thanne faste a-boute Off that prece to haue him oute MS. sute . ; But men stode so on euery a side, That he my&yogh;t not out with him ride: To haue him out was he not ethe, He put his swerd In his schethe, He kest his scheld on his bak, To saue the kyng fro alle his pak; To other &yogh;af he no tent, But he were with-oute, as he hadde ment. AChilles held him euere a-rome, And saw that Ector &yogh;aff no gome To no man thenne but for to bryng Out of that prece that riche kyng: He hadde that tyme no spere In hand Ther-with to dere no man lyuand, His swerd was put In his skauberke, He was al bare but his hauberke On his brest & his stomak, His scheld was casten on his bak. ¶ Achilles ther-to toke good hede And thoght, "but he that tyme spede, That he scholde neuere to dethe him do, But he my&yogh;t that tyme come ther-to." He stroke his stede & helde him faste, And to[k] his spere that wel wolde laste, And rod to him, er he were war, And thorow the bodi he him bar: ¶ Thorow the bodi he him thrist, Er he were war & er he wyst; He bar him doun vpon the grounde Fro his hors with dethes wounde. ODemon saw Ector was dede, He saw his blod aboute sprede; The deth of him sore he rewed. Whan that he saw he not remeued, Whan he saw him ligge so In pees, He stale be-hynde Achilles And smot him with a pollax sore, That of his hors he fel thore: He fel ouer his sadel bowe And lay In swoun a long throwe. And Odemoun flees a-weyward faste, Many a dart thei afftir him caste; To the Troyens he gan him spede, That was his best, for he hadde nede. ¶ Thei toke Achilles of that throng, That he died not here hors a-mong, And layde him soffte vpon his scheld And lad him hom to his teld; And he my&yogh;t nother ride ne go, So was he sore smyten tho. And thei of Troye Ector out drow For drede of hors, with sorwe y-now, And lad him hom to his paleis. And thus died Ector—as Dares sais. ¶ That batayle that day thus gan to ende, Bothe the ostes hamward gan wende: Thei of Grece with Achilles, Ioyful and glad for his res; And thei of Troie with Ector the gode, Al ded In his owne blode. LOrd, the Ioye that Gregeis made! Thei ete & drank & made him glade With pipes & daunces & Iolyffte; Gret Ioye it was her murthe to se. Achilles thei dede alle glade, Mechel murthe thei him made, And dight him gode fisiciens, With leche-crafft thes surgiens; Alle the helpe that thei myght Thei it dede be day & nyght. And thonked here godis In that place That hadde sent hem som grace, To scle him that hadde hem most anoyed And her Gregeis so foule distroied. NOw is he ded, that gode kny&yogh;t, That no man my&yogh;t with-stande In fight! Now is sclay[n] that gode body That men tolde so moche by! That was so moche with alle men dred, Now liggis he ded and for-bled! In Troie was neuere so gode kny&yogh;t born, As thei of Troie hadde than for-lorn! A better kny&yogh;t of chiualrie Was neuere born In Asye! Ne neuere was, ne neuere schal be A better kny&yogh;t In armes than was he! ¶ A dethe! that thow art quaynt! Thi myght may no man speke ne playnt! So doughti a kny&yogh;t was neuere none In erthe made of flesch ne bone, That euere myght stonde of the a brayde, Whan thow thi hand on him has layde. Thow art scharp as any bristeles,— Wo is him that with the wrasteles! For sicurly he goth the with, Or thow him brekes lym or lyth, That he may not a-&yogh;eyn vp-rise For my&yogh;t ne strengthe In no wyse; For he schal dye In this world,— So did this kny&yogh;t, that &yogh;e haue herd. ¶ Lamentacio Troianorum pro morte Ectoris. Be he neuere so strong ne bold, He is for-&yogh;eten & nou&yogh;t of told, When he is ded & hennes past; In erthe is none that euere may last. ECtor is ded & brou&yogh;t to Troye, With sore wepyng & no Ioye Eche man ouer other cryed; Wiff and man to hem thei hyed, To wete what sorwe was. Euery man thanne cried 'alas!' Alle come thedir, &yogh;ong and old, That ded bodi to be-hold: Ouer-al then MS. thei. my&yogh;t men here An MS. And. hidous noyse, a delful bere, That ther was made of man & wyff, Whan thei saw him with-outen lyff. ¶ Ther was many 'weylaway,' 'Harrow,' 'alas,' and 'out ay'— "That euere were thei of moder born! For now schal thei be schent & lorn, Sithe he was ded that hem Alle saued." Thei ferde alle as thei hadde raued For dele that thei a-boute him made, Thei wepe alle and were fade: Ther was wryngynge of handes, When thei herde of that tythandes, For thei sette nou&yogh;t by here lyues. ¶ The sorwe was gret among wyues, The maydenes wepe with reuful teres, Thei rent here clothes and tar her heres; The burgeis & the Citeseyns, The gentil men of riche Troiens, Thei wepe wel sore & gredde, Many dayes suche lyff ledde. The kynges rente here clothes & tare, And cracched her hedes naked & bare; ¶ Alle the kynges that ther ware, And alle the ladies lasse & mare That were of Troye MS. of Troye of Troie. with-Inne the toun, In here Manere made processioun And brou&yogh;t him to the kynges halle And leyde him on a clothe of palle With careful herte & sore wepynge. Ther was sone a delful metynge Be-twene the fader and the sone, Whan he was brou&yogh;te to Ileone; The fader fel the sone vpon, And almost wod gan he gon. WHen Priamus saw Ector was ded And be-spred with blod so red, His visage was blak & wan, Suche a sorwe toke he him than That he lese al his my&yogh;t & fors And fel on swoun opon the cors: And lay ther ded al In a swow, Til men him fro the bodi drow; And nade thei him drawen a-way, He hadde mad ther his endyng-day. ¶ Lord! what sorwe [made] Troyle his brother, Dephebus, & alle these other, And his sistur Cassandur, And his MS. And of his. brother Alysandur! Sicurly thei hadde suche care, That thei wolde that thei dede ware. What may I say thanne by the quene, And by his suster Pollexene? By Andromede, that frely fode, Whan sche saw ded Ector the gode That was hir lord & hir husband, The du&yogh;htiest kny&yogh;t that lyued In land? No man my&yogh;t that sorwe telle, Ther-a-boute wol I not dwelle; But sicurly with-outen doute It were longe to be ther-a-boute: Ther was neuere erthely creature That my&yogh;t more sorwe endure, For sche hadde as moche wo And peynes stronge In herte tho, As herte may thenke & tonge speke, And hit made nere hir herte breke. NOw is he ded—as I tolde;— Men my&yogh;t not longe his bodi holde A-boue erthe with-oute sauour, Thoow he were man of gret honour. For &yogh;e wot wele—as alle men fynde,— Hit is thing a-&yogh;eyns man kynde A man to holde saue & sound, When he is ded & a-boue ground. But not-for-thi kyng Priamus [Thought] "wher MS. Wher. hit myght wele be thus, Where he myght saue Ector his sone Vngrauen with-oute corrupcione." ¶ He sente afftir with reuerence The maystres of alle the science, And alle that couthe of barberie Or knew vertu of spicerie; Afftir alle the grametenes, Dioletikes and Astronomynes; And asked hem wel curtesly: "Whether thei were alle so sly To saue Ector with-oute poudre, With-oute sauour or foule odoure, ¶ Qualiter faciunt Ectorem quando mortuus fuerat. That he were not grauen In the molde." Thei seyde "thei hoped that thei scholde." Thei told a-monges hem consayle, How thei my&yogh;t best this entayle. Thei Asked him "where he scholde ligge? Where thei scholde his berying bigge?" ¶ He says "he scholde ligge y-wys In the temple of Appolynys." The maystres thanne In-myddis the quere, Ryght be-fore the hey autere, A tabernacle ther thei wrou&yogh;te, A crafftly werk, when it was brou&yogh;te Til ende and to perfeccioun. Clene it was al enviroun, ¶ Ther werk was al of gold pure, Ther thei made his sepulture. But he was mad, he schold not greue a grot, He was mad so he my&yogh;t not rot, Thei held him hole & alle entere In his colour fair & clere, As he hadde ben a lyues man. Thei were wise that suche skyl can, A dede body that so gan dyght. As he lyued—til alle mennes sight— In hide, In hew, In flesch, In fel Sat Ector ther with-oute smel, As I schal say &yogh;ow blyue— But I schal furst the werk discryue. THese Maystres and these riche clerkes That witti were of craffty werkes, That this thyng schold vndirtake And that crafft-werk to make, Off brede [&] lengthe toke thei met, Or it were raysed or vp-set. Thei set it alle In foure pilers Off pure gold at foure corneres, The pilers alle of red gold From a-boue to the mold; On eche a pilere stod an ymage With louely chere & fair visage, With fair semblaunt & louely eyen, That alle were wroght of gold fyne, As euerychon hadde ben an aungel bry&yogh;t Lokande faire on euery a wyght. ¶ And certes so was alle the rove Off massi gold alle a-bove; And it was fair a-boute entent With precious stones verament, Hit stode ful of precious stones That were ther set for the nones; Alle manere stones that euere men knew, That were of force or any vertu, On that roff aboue were set,— Were thei neuere so fer y-fet: THer were stones of alle kynde, Grene, rede, blewe, and Inde; Ther stood many a riche ston That as bry&yogh;t a-boute hem schon, As doth In somer the sonne bem; A man may se to sowe a sem ¶ In the furthest of the chirche A-boute mydnyght that thanne wold wirche. Al was wrought of balewerie Opon the erthe al vpon hye, And men clombe op on greces smale That were wroght of clene cristale. The maystres that were wise & slye Thei sette an y-mage al vp on MS. vpon . hye ¶ Qualiter faciunt MS. faciut , the stroke over the u is erased. tabernaculum Ectoris. Off gold fair, of his gretnesse, Off his entayl and his liknesse, With Ector sword y-drawe In hande The Gregeis alle manassande. The ymage was maked at de-vyce: To hem of Grece he turned his vyce As he hadde stonden hem thretand With wrothely loke & fair semblaunt. ¶ Many a proude pight pynacle Stode a-boute that tabernacle; And many crafft[l]y coruen croket MS. croked . Off massi gold that were y-bet Were grauen ther with leues diuerse: Al can I not reherse,— But ther was corue & semeli schorn The leues of Oke & of hawethorn, The louely leues of the vyne, And many then I can not devyne: ¶ The vyne-braunche with alle here grapes, And many other skynnes Iapes, Many a pomel wel enbosed, Hit was wroght & wel engrosed With ffloures & leues wel en-leued. Now haue I MS. I. In . this werk discreued, Off that tabernacle that riche bothe; Now wol I telle &yogh;ow al the sothe, How it was dight wel & fair, That he myght neuere rote ne pair: WHen thei haue maked this al,— This Tabernacle that was rial,— Off gold made thei a riche cheyere And sette it In that faire celere, The tabernacle stode hit y-myd, And gode Ector ther-In thei did. Ector sat vpon that dese As he hadde lyued—with-oute les,— He sat pertly bolde vp-right As man that hadde ben In his myght; So priueli was he ther tyed, That he toward no syde wryed. He hadde vpon him his garnement That he In erthe on lyue [In] went, In his owne clothes was he clad— For Priamus the kyng so bad. BVt herkenes now her ordinaunce: What was the Maystres puruyaunce, What was her sleyght and her cure, That thei MS. thei thei . him saued with-oute blemure Off fflesch or bon, of hyde or hewe, But held him euere y-liche newe? Thei made an hole In his haterel & set MS. Y set . ther-In a fair vessel That was ful of riche bavme,— The some ther-of can I not avme;— And other thyng ther was with melled, That was noble & wel smelled. Hit ran so doun to his foreheued, That no colour him was by-reued; For thanne ran it doun to his eyen And saued the liddis and [the] brien MS. vrien , distinctly. , And so be-gan him for to lese Vnto his thrillis of his nese; And afftirward faste it sekes, Til it come doun to his chekes, And kepes his gomes & rennes so lite MS. solite . , And his tethe makes faire & white, And al the face with the her Was hole and sound, whil he sette ther. That licour ran so to his hals, To his scholdres and his brest als; ¶ Ther is no Ioynt aboute his tharmes, It rennes so doun by his Armes, And by his hond it so doun wendes, Til it come at his ffyngur endes. And gret ffusoun ther doun rides Ful wonderly by bothe his sydes, So ffaste that licour dounward droppes, That no thyng his rennyng stoppes, Til it were comen In-to his theis And so &yogh;ede doun In-to his kneis; So it ran wonder schete, Til it come doun to his fete. ¶ Another vessel thenne ther stode, Ful of baume ffresche MS. ff'resche . & gode, And kest vpward his gode reles And keped him so In flesche & gres. That on &yogh;ede vp, that other doun, Fro his ffete to the croun; When it aboue with that was met, Bothe his feet ther-Inne was set. Thei &yogh;aff In him suche odour, That he was saff with-oute sauour: Thus thei him made with here my&yogh;t And keped him bothe day & ny&yogh;t. WHen this werk was thus be-went, Thei made foure morteres þat euere brent; Thei brenned nyght, thei brenned day, With-outen sese thei brenned ay. Thei were alle mad of gold schire, On hem stode euere a flaume of fire, That neyther water of broke ne of bek Ne nothyng In erthe thei my&yogh;t slek. Thei made afftir a parclos That al a-boute that fair werk gos, With Gemewes folden on euery a side That bothe my&yogh;t spere and open wyde, That Ector schewed & seen my&yogh;t be To euery man that him wolde se. NOw of Ector lete we be, And of Achilles speke we! Off that strong knyght—as I sayde, How Gregeis In his bed him layde; His woundes greues him so sore, That al his my&yogh;t hath he for-lore; He may wel euel ete or drynke, Off merthe ne play may he non thinke. ¶ His grete woundes him greues sore, That he dredde to lyue no more. The leches him comfortes wonder wele And leues that he lyue schele, And makes him couere more & more And by her power heled his sore, So that he may somdel ete And haue sauour vnto his mete. AGamenon the Emperour Sendes Messanger & corour, That thei scholde bidde the kynges alle To MS. And . speke with him In his halle, And alle the lordes grete & smale To holde a counsel generale. ¶ The Messangeres also swythe Thei fond the lordes glad and blithe Off Ector and his myschaunce,— Thei were so fayn of his lyueraunce,— The Messageres bad alle & some: "To Agamenon thei scholde come; ¶ Hic Greci tenuerunt consilium. Schold non be-leue that corovne beres, Ne sercle of gold that on hede weres, That thei ne schul come to his hale, Kyng & duk and Amerale." AGamenoun ful hendeli Kepis hem alle ful curtaysli, And did hem sitte more and lesse, Euerychon afftir his state[l]i[ne]sse. Agamenoun the Emperour Spake to him with honour, He sette his speche fair & hende And seyde: 'lordynges, my dere frende, Wel au&yogh;t vs to glorifie Oure goddis that &yogh;euen vs the Maystrie Off oure enemy that we haue sclayn; Ther-of we ben alle fayn And gret worschepe & honour do, For elles hadde we neuere comen ther-to, ¶ Whil he hadde leued, to oure purpos. But now may we wel suppos, Sithen he is ded that hem defende, That thei haue alle theire endyng ende, And we schal lordis & maystres be Off here godis & here Cite. For whil he leued, my&yogh;t we not spede, So was he dou&yogh;ti In his dede; Vs my&yogh;t no grace for him by-falle, For he on vndid vs alle. ¶ We hadde no let but him alone, But now is he ded & from vs gone, We schal that Cite lyghtly wynne And alle that ben hit with-Inne; For thei are now of no power To kepe hem fro oure daunger, Sithen he is ded & fro hem went That vs al day so foule schent. It is to vs wel more a-vauntage That he is ded & loken In cage, Then we hadde sclayn In fight felle Halff the men that with him dwelle. ¶ For he sclow mo him-selff alone Then alle that other did euerychone, And we ben now—I vnderstande— Mo then sixti ti over the line, inserted by another hand. hundred thousande Off Mennes bodies gode and able, That ben a-pert and defendable. THe dedis of Ector ben wide y-kyd, That thei may not wel be hid: How fele kynges sclow he of oure With his my&yogh;t & his vigoure! How he sclow In his reuery The dou&yogh;ti kyng Prothesaly! ¶ Patrodus also, Achilles cosyn, In his strengthe sclow he him! ¶ How sclow he In his gret Ire Kyng Mennon, that lordly sire! We were echon of him a-dred. How sclow he the gode kyng Ced! So did he kyng Polenete. He fond no man that to him was mete. He sclow also kyng Alphynor, And so he did kyng Prouenor That was a kyng of gret genterie, Off dou&yogh;tines and chiualrie. ¶ How sclow he with his force The myghti kyng of dou&yogh;ti Corce! He died with dynt: so he gart The noble kyng Pilo&yogh;enart. ¶ He sclow also the kyng Yside. No man durst him a-byde. He did also to dethe sone The dou&yogh;ti kyng Letabone. Ne sclow he not the kyng Humere? I wist neuere man that was his pere. ¶ He sclow oure kyng Archilogus, And the kyng also Episcropus; And so he did kyng Archomene, And the hardy kyng Palymene. Ne sclow he not the kyng Antipe? And so he did kyng Sanxipe. ¶ He did vs moche sorwe and tene: He sclow the gode kyng Philoxene; He smot to dethe vndir his fete The noble kyng Polibete, Kyng Phiebete, and kyng Leankes, Alle he sclow oure gret vnthankes, He smot her bodyes euen In-two; So did he other mo also. We au&yogh;t wele his bodi wary! ¶ He sclow kyng Fume & kyng Dary, And Many duk and Amerelles; He sclow oure lordes & robbed oure halles, And bar a-wey coffre & chest. He that him sclow mot be blest! For now—I hope—he is ded That did vs schame and qued, That oure men so foule sclow, And we hem alle schal Maystre now With-Inne a while at oure wille. But herkenes now! this is my skylle: ¶ Thoow it be so that he be slayn, Hap of ffyght is no certayn; n is struck out after ma. ¶ No man wot how it schal schape, Who schal dye & who schal skape. Wherfore I say: sithe it so is That by Achilles dou&yogh;tines We are now brou&yogh;t to oure aboue, Me thinke it were to oure behoue That we In feld fight no more, Vn-til Achilles heled wore; For we ar noght alle sure & sekir With-oute him to wynne this bekir. With-oute him & his pouste In certayn hope we may not be To haue of hem the victorie, Thoow thei for Ector be sorie. ¶ Wherfore this is my menyng: That it were good, at my wetyng, That we sende by kyng or kny&yogh;t To Priamus, to aske respit, That we .viij. wekes the pees may haunte, If thei the trewes so longe wol graunte, And the dedes were enseled. By than may Achilles be heled, And we may make oure-self clene Off sore woundes that doth vs tene.' WHen Agamenoun thus hadde sayd, The lordis were alle wel a-payd: Thei held his conseyl good & lele, To haue the pees til he hadde hele; Thei held it alle wel y-do, Thei graunted echon his conseyl to; This lordes alle &yogh;aue ther assent To his counseyl & Iugement: That with-oute him and his absence Wold thei not fight in ther presence. ¶ Hic Greci pecierunt pacem Troianorum MS. Troian . per .viij. septimanas. ¶ The messageres were rapely dyght Opon her erande to wende right, Thei busked hem & maked &yogh;are Opon her erande for to fare: Riche robes on hem are done, Thei toke her hors & &yogh;ede sone— As kynges gode, kene, and wraske— The treus of hem of Troye to aske. ¶ When thei were comen to her Cite, In forme of pes thei asked entre; Thei fond no man that hem werned. To Priamus told thei that erand: "Two Monthes to haue [respit] ent[e]re MS. . . . to haue entre; entre from l. 11464. — For thei were comen as Messangere— Pees & trues, that thei my&yogh;t reste; For thei ther-of hadde gret breste, For thei my&yogh;t not the stenche sustayn Off dede bodies that were ther selayn; Thei wolde haue space ther bodyes brenne." Priamus the treus graunt thenne By assent of his consayl; Thei hadde no wil to haue batayl So sone afftir his sones ded; For he was heuyer then the led, For Ector was so sclayn him fro, That he sayde not to hem ones 'no.' THese Messageres haue sone y-sped, Off no man MS. noman. ar thei now a-dred; Thei ride hamward muri siggande MS. sigg ande. And tolde her men of this tydande: "How thei haue graunted thair grithe To be In pes two monethe." Thei were alle glad of her sawes, Thei &yogh;aff hem alle to gamen & playes. ¶ Hic Palamides Rex iratus fuit cum Imperatore The sign in blue, the words in red. . Saue the kyng Palamides— He was neuere no tyme In pes, He playned him of his Emperour That was her alther gouernour, And seyde: "he was not worthi To haue of hem suche seruageri; Ther were other better then he To haue forsothe that dignite." ¶ Vpon a day it so befel: Agamenoun—the sothe to tel— Hadde sent afftir the lordes alle "Thei scholde come In-to his halle"; And as thei sete at most spekyng "How thei scholde to ende bryng Ther purpos & her gode espleyt," Palamides be-thou&yogh;t him streyt To put him out of his office: And ther-of did he as the vn-wyse. ¶ Hit was a&yogh;eyn his genterie To haue to him so foule envye With-oute disert MS. dishert. or any mysdede; But not-for-thi so longe he &yogh;ede: At the laste was he remeued, And another mad & newed. PAlamydes as he sat there, Off his spekyng coude blynne neuere, To Agamenoun offte he flote And made to him wordes hote; He seyde: "it was a-&yogh;eyn resoun That he hadde ben alle sesoun So longe vndir his gouernayle; Ther were other that coude more a-vayle And were more profitable, For he was not—he sayde—able Suche a state to reioye." Agamenoun sat wel stille & coye, When he hadde sayd his gret gole; Agamenoun ful entempre Answered him soburly,— For he was euere wis & sly,— ¶ He seyde: 'Palamides, I haue gret wondir thow can not sese Off thi wordes & thi carpyng, Whan we be thus In oure gaderyng. Hopes thow, sire, I haue desire To be ouer &yogh;ow other lord or sire? Nay certes, I desire it not! Ne neuere with word ther-fore be-sou&yogh;t To kyng ne kny&yogh;t, sir, by my thrift!— Ne neuere ther-fore &yogh;it &yogh;aff &yogh;ift. ¶ For I hadde neuere vauntage ther-In, But gret trauayle & mychel vn-wyn, And of my body mychel vnrest To ordayne &yogh;ow wel, & kest That alle thes folk were saueli led, And how we my&yogh;t sonnest be-sped. I was chosen by comune assent, By playn counseyl In parlement Off alle the lordes that ther were, Saue &yogh;e alone that was not there. ¶ We hadde ben &yogh;it In Athenes, Hadde we not a-biden the, Palamydes; For we dwelled ther two &yogh;er and more, Or thow to vs comen wore. I hadde ther-fore not thin acord, When I was chosen &yogh;oure Aleres lord; For thow was not tho present, But afftir longe fro vs absent. ¶ But, Palamydes, thow my&yogh;t not say That euere fel vs by ny&yogh;t or day —I thanked it god—oure spedyng By myn vn-wit or mysledyng; And also I am redi now & ay, For-whi it be,—&yogh;ow to pay— Off myn office to be deposed, For I wold not &yogh;e supposed No pride In me—nother sibbe ne frende,— I wold fayn of this office wende. And chese another—where &yogh;e lyke— To haue my state—by heuene ryke!— And I wol be vndir his byddyng As other kynges of this gaderyng.' THese lordes were alle gretly dered, Ther was non that answered; But bad hem: "be In pees bothe, For thei wold not that thei were wrothe"; Thei bad hem alle: "thei scholde not greue," And ros vp alle and toke here leue; Thei wente alle hamward MS. hamward. sone, Off that was ther no more to done. But sone a&yogh;eyn euen-tyde Agamenoun wold not abyde, ¶ Thorow alle that ost he did him crye: "That eche a man,—bothe lowe and hye, Kyng & duk and amerale, And alle the lordes gret & smale, And alle that hadde tent or teld, Or any that was kny&yogh;t of any scheld,— Schuld be at morwe next folwande,— When it was day, the sonne schynande,— At Agamenoun riche tent To holde a solenne parlement, Off certayn thynges to entrete; And that thei scholde on no wise lete, For thei most nede hit alle I-here— Kyng, duk, & bachelere, And that were of that ost Bothe the leste & the most." THe day is comen, the nyght is gon; The lordes arysen euerychon, To Agamenoun Ar thei went, To wete whi he afftir hem sent. When thei were comen & set doun alle By Agamenoun In his halle, ¶ Agamenoun to hem sayde "Off Palamydes and his vpbrayde, That be-gan so vpon him playne That he was made her souerayne,"— 'And is ful wroth with my persone And for my rial eleccione, And says "that I can not &yogh;ow lede." That dignite ther-fore I bede To him or other, whan &yogh;e wol chese, For I wol fayn this honour lese. ¶ And not-for-thi, my bretheren Altered from brotheren. dere, Kynges & dukes that now be here,— Sithen we come fro Athenes, That &yogh;e &yogh;oure souerayne ther me ches, And come thenne hidur In bote & barge, Haue I among &yogh;ow born charge Off alle oure ost & oure meygne In mechel thoght—and that wot &yogh;e. ¶ Gret besynes of &yogh;oure kepyng Hath refft me many ny&yogh;t slepyng, To saue this ost fro perelle, That scathe ne harm to &yogh;ow non felle. ¶ Hic Agamenoun mutatur de officio suo. & Palamides electus est ad officium Imperatoris. And &yogh;et haue &yogh;e so wele be kept, Whether that &yogh;e woke or slept, That we ar comen to oure aboue; ¶ Suche a chaunce is fallen to oure byhoue Vndir me & my ledyng. But I wol, som other kyng, Duk, prince, whether thei wil, Haue now the charge—& that is skyl: For I haue nede to be In pes. I wol therfore this state reles And be with other an vndirlyng, To haue my reste and my likyng.' Alle that were there In the halle, Kynges & dukes and Ameralle, Drow hem out vpon a rowe By-side the tent vnder the wowe, To take her avisement: Thei haue alle &yogh;euen here Iugement, That thei wole him remewe And haue another of hem newe. ¶ The Iugement is &yogh;euen & taken: Agamenoun is for-saken, He is put out of his office; Palamydes is chosen y-wys To be here alther emperour And here alther comaundour. ¶ This conseil is fully ent, And euery lord is home went To here tentis & pauylounes. Her-of spake the Murmidones And told this tydynges to Achilles Off that newe lord Palamydes: "How he was chosen here alther lord By the lordis comune acorde." When Achilles herde this tydandis, Out of his bed sclong he his handes, As he that was euel payde Off these tythandis that him were sayde; His woundes bledde for-sothe & brake. With so gret herte Achilles spak To alle that stode aboute his bed, And seyde: "that this was euel y-red To make among hem suche a chaunge"— 'Now hope I that alle thei caunge! ¶ For of vs alle—so mot I the!— Was ther non so wys as he, Ne non that coude so lede oure ost With witt and skylle, with-outen bost. But I wol not be occasioun To vndo &yogh;oure eleccioun; Sithe he is chosen, I holde it gode.' And her eleccioun thus so stode, And he belefft here Emperour As he was chosen with honour. THe two Monthes are past, Bothe the parties dight hem fast, Bothe the Troyens and the Grues; Her day is comen out of her trues. Kyng Priamus wolde be venged fayn His sones deth that was sclayn, He seide: "he wolde him go To fight that day to venge his fo." ¶ His batayles alle him-self ordeynes, With his right hond he hem ensaynes And &yogh;euet hem leue forth to wende; He prayes hem alle to venge her frende, Her Prince that was & gouernour, That som tyme was ther sauyour. ¶ Hic Incipit bellum. Twenti thousandis kny&yogh;tis fre In his batayle than hadde he, I dar right wel & boldely say That &yogh;ede to fy&yogh;t with him that day An hundrid & ffyffti thousand Off myghti men on hors ridand. DEphebus ferst with his batayle &YOGH;ede the Grekys MS. grekys on erasure, by another hand. for to Assayle; Afftir him &yogh;ede thanne Paris, With the kyng of Perce y-wys, And alle his men that he loued wele— With-outen Iren, with-outen stele,— Bowes & arwes the Persays hadde, Thei wente forth sore a-dradde. Priamus lad him-selff the thridde With xx ti thousand kny&yogh;tis him amydde; He bad Eueas scholde lede the fourthe And leue him not for gode In erthe. ¶ The ffyffthe lad kyng Mennon; And thus were thei In-sunder gon. The sixte lad Polidomas. And other lordes, as her wille was, Ladd all that other, as he hem bad. Thei rode forth with semblaunt sad To hem of Grece that thei a&yogh;eyn stand Al redy dight with spere In hand That thanne abode and here comyng: Hit was gret at her metyng. ¶ Euerychon of hem on other renne, Thei ferde as it had ben wod menne, Thei thrilled scheldes & speres brast, Some were sclayn, & som doun cast Opon the grounde & lay flat, Thei &yogh;aff be-twene hem many a sqwat. Hic Priamus. Rex. et Palamides pugnauerunt r. PRiamus saw Palamydes The Gregeis to her newe lord ches; He rod to him with mychel strengthe And bare him ouer his speres lengthe: So Priamus bar Palamydes And bad him reste ther In pes. Among Gregeis stroke he his stede, The strongest of hem to grounde &yogh;ede That he mette with In his gret Ire. The Gregeis alle be-gan to spire What he was that him so bare, Among hem alle that made suche fare: ¶ He sclow hem so & bare hem doun, He wan that day ful gret renoun; Moche prise & mochel los Wan he that day among his fos. To eche a man his scheld he bedis, Alle men spake ther of his dedis: He bare him so at that semble That alle the los of that iourne MS. ion e. Be-lefft with him of more [&] lesse, Off his gode dedis and his prowesse. For Achilles my&yogh;t not &yogh;it ride, Therfore at home he most abide; But hadde he ben ther with-oute drede, He wolde haue tau&yogh;t him for to rede And to synge a sori sang, Hadde he ben hem among. ¶ Dephebus folwes his fader, He sclow doun Gregeis al to-gader; And then come Paris with his bowes And castes men doun and ouer-throwes, With hem of Perce and her Turkes, And schot Arwes among the Grues. But thanne come thedir sikerly The stalworthest man of Grece party, ¶ Neoptolamus was his name; Kyng Sarpedoun thoght he to lame: He &yogh;aff him certes suche a dynt That Sarpedoun his stiropes tynt, He made him bacward so stoupe That he fel ouer his hors croupe. But Sarpedoun was not sore hurt, But hastly vpward stirt, As wroghe The e on erasure. as he my&yogh;t be, And smot the kyng vpon the ye, ¶ That he cleue his nase In two pese. Then come thedur many of Grece And leyde on him on euery a side; He most nede on fote abyde, For he my&yogh;t not his hors come to For no thyng that he my&yogh;t do, He was for-sothe In gret perel, For ffele Gregeis opon him ffel. THe kyng of Perse, when he was war How Sarpedoun on fote fau&yogh;t thar, And thei of Grece stode enviroun,— With alle his men come he thanne doun, And Sarpedoun his hors did take For al that euere thei coude make. ¶ And that saw duk Athenes, And the noble kny&yogh;t Menescenes, He bad his men him folwe than, An hard werre he ther by-gan. Menelaus als aboute his hals Kest his scheld and &yogh;ede doun als, And bad that al his retenaunce Schold him sewe with spere & launce. Euery a burne him busked &yogh;are To that assaut for to fare, To that torpel MS. terpel. come alle that route And be-kest that place aboute: ¶ The kyng of Perce stode & fau&yogh;t, Thei slow him certes at that assaut, And al his men on bak thei schoff, And with force a&yogh;eyn hem droff. But Sarpedoun hem with-stode The proude Gregeis with hardi mode, ¶ Him was ful loth thenne to fle, Gret meruayle that tyme did he. But thei of Grece were so assamed, That thei of Troie no-thyng gamed: Wolde or nolde, on bak thei &yogh;ede, For sikerli thei most nede. BVt Priamus, that kyng of age, As wood was as a best sauage: When his men hadde lorn that place, The swot brast out at his face; He rod thedur with-oute dwellyng, Ther was noyse & gret &yogh;ellyng. ¶ Priamus rod to and fro, He thoght on hem to venge his wo; Off slau&yogh;ter certis neuere he blynnes, He cleues hem doun by the chynnes. But the Gregeis euere stille stode And fau&yogh;t a&yogh;eyn as thei were wode, Many of Troie that tyme thei perced, And many man to grounde reuersed. ¶ The Gregeis then aboute be-held, Ther thei fau&yogh;t In the feld; Thei saw hem fro the toun proloigned, And thei with hem so foule regroyned. ¶ Magnum Bellum. Thei toke conseil hem be-twene, How thei my&yogh;t hem traye and tene; Thei were be-thoght of sleght & art, Thei seyde: "thei wolde here folk depart Be-twene the toun & hem to wende, And so schold thei hem sonest schende." Thei rode ouer dale and doune To go be-twene hem & the toune. ¶ But Priamus fful wel perceued How thei wolde haue him disceyued, With his men sclely he turned And that way ful sone he werned. With-outen dwellyng or any abode With his ffolk he thedur rode, Ther thei wolde haue had entre Be-twene hem & her Cite. He brou&yogh;t with him gret multitude And laide vpon him strokes vnrude; He droff hem doun a-&yogh;eyns her wille, Maugre her tethe be-twene the hille. ¶ Gret defence the kyng made hath, Thei toke not of him that path; The Gregeis wolde the pase haue had. The Troiens lente hem strokes sad, The Gregeis laid on faste ynow, Many of Troye ther thei sclow. A thousand were with blode be-ronnen, For thei that pase wolde haue wonnen; Thei defende & thei assayle, Ther was be-twene hem a strong batayle. BVt Paris com thanne on trauerse With men of Armes and hem of Perse, He come thedur with his buschement, With bolde bowes redy bent Some indistinct scribblings at the foot of the page. : Thei come sidelynge & ouer-twert, The Gregeis so foule offte thei hert. But then come thedur Menelaus, With alle his folk he come thus: Gret was the sau&yogh;t ther was be-gunnen, But tho thei lakked lyght of sonne. Many dede bodies lay ther on grounde And lite went ther hole & sounde; ¶ For hadde thei had lyght of sonne, The Gregeis the pase thenne had wonne. But thei departed for faute of lyght And riden home with al her myght; The Troiens riden to the toun, And the Gregeis to ther pauyloun. THe Troiens now her sorwe reherse For the kynges deth of Perse: Ther was non that longed to Troie, Kyng ne kny&yogh;t, sqwyer ne boye, That thei [ne] made gret del & sorwe Bothe an euen and on morwe. Was non that made such wayment As did Paris verament: He sorwed day & also nyght, For he him loued with al his myght. ¶ This was ther-fore Paris rede: "To boyle him and put him In lede, And lede him hom to his contre With taper & torche & gret rialte, With gret plente of fele candeles; That he myght haue his burieles And ligge among his antecessoures, The riche kynges, his predecessoures, And be ther grauen honorably By-fore his sones that dwelles ther-by, ¶ Hic pecierunt pacem ad inuicem per magnum tempus. In his londis that kynges schal be Afftir him In gret pouste." NIght is comen, & day is gon, The[i] gon to bedde & slepen euerychon. On morwe when it was day lyght, The sonne was resen & schon bryght, Kyng Priamus sente doun his sonde To alle the Gregeis liggand on the stronde, To Aske the trues—as Dares sais— A certeyn tyme to ben In pais. But it is In his bokes wane How longe the trues were tane; How long that thei schold holde, Dites ne Dares non ther tolde. But thei haue graunt & surte founden This line on erasure, but by the same hand. , Many a rop was thanne vn-wounden, Many a cope & many an hode That were praysed worthe mechel gode, Off gold, of silk, and som of say, For then was Ector put a-way, That thei scholde holde riche festis— As I fynde In here gestes. NOw Ector Menyng-day schal be holden: In Troye bene robis riche vnfolden That were layd vp be-fore the dayes, With silke y-filed and riche arais, And other newe lordis did make For honour of that festis sake. Thorow the toun was hit done cry: "That riche & poure, lowe & hy, That euere longed In-to Troye, Off ffyftene dayes schuld make no ioye, But lyue In wepyng & gret sorwe The .xv. dayes euen & morwe, With-oute karole, with-oute daunce, In gode Ector remembraunce." ¶ In his remembraunce & his mynde Ther was that heuynesse—as I fynde— Off Priamus and of riche kynges And of other grete lordynges;— "And whan the ffyfftene dayes of wo Were fulfilled and a-go, Thei scholde make rialte, Mechel daunce & mechel gle." THe while the festes thus endured, And eueryche were to other ensured, Thei of Troye hadde here comyng To hem of Grece & here spekyng; And Gregeis come In-to the toun And where thei wolde vp & doun, Saue & sound where so hem liked; Thei fond no man that hem be-swiked. ¶ Achilles wolde that tyme gange To se her festes and here sange, He thoght algates he wolde se In Troye gret solennite. Here contenaunce & here porture, Here myght, here sorwe, & here voysure, Here doyng of there chere deuout, And how thei did Ector about. ¶ Achilles made him redi swithe, In-to the toun wente he blyue, And to the temple Apolynys &YOGH;ede he to se, what Ioye & blis Aboute Ector Troyens made: He fond ther non that was glade, But makyng dele & gret wepyng; Be-fore Ector saw he sittyng ¶ Ectuba, the semely quene, And hir dou&yogh;ter Pollexene; And fele ladies of gret genterie Here ther In that companye. Thair heer faire a-boute hem spred, On eyther halff hit was fair sched, Hit henged doun by-nethe her pappes, By-nethe here mydeles, by-nethe here lappes. ¶ Thei made gret del & sykyng, Thei were echon In euel lykyng, Mechel del & mechel mone A-boute Ector made thei echone. Ector &yogh;it sat als entere And so fair In his solere, As he was furst ther ordeyned; The baume so his body susteyned Fro al appayryng & alle sauour, And ffro chaungyng of his colour. THe tabernacle on eche a syde Was vn-done and opened wyde, That eche man, bothe &yogh;ong & old, On eche a syde Ector behold. ¶ Achilles loked on that werk faste; As he his eyen aboute him caste, So was he war of Pollexene Faste sittynge by the quene, He loked vpon the damysele And saw the teres fro hir fele. But thoow that lady fair & swete Wonder sore & hertly grete, ¶ Not-for-thi for alle hir payne Sche wex nother pale ne wayne, Sche lost not of her fayrnesse, Off hir beaute ne hir swetnesse. ¶ Hic Achilles Amat Pollexenam Filiam Regis Troiani MS. Troian. . Al hir wo ne al hir pyne Made hir not hur fayrnes tyne, The teres that so fro hur ran Made hir nother blo ne wan; Hit for-did no-thyng hir sight, Hir eyen were euere clere and bryght, For alle here wepyng were thei not dym, Ne sche not apayred In neuere MS. neuere y. a lym. Ther is no man that is on lyue, Hir fairnesse that myght discryue— For siker sche was as fair a woman As man scholde sette his eyen vpan. AChilles loked euere In on; So ffair a thyng as sche was on Saw he neuere In al his lyue— Widwe, ne mayden, ne non wyue. As he loked In hir vysage, His herte torned & his corage, Him hadde leuere than any thyng He hadde ben siker of that swetyng: Alle his herte and his delite Was to haue of hure a sight, He loked on hir as he were mad. The more lokyng to hir he had, ¶ His long lokyng hir louely sight Be-rafft him clene of his myght; But he myght not his lokyng leue, That thoght myght no man him byreue: He loked to hir the while he myght, Til the day was gon, & hit was nyght. Off alle thinges that euere was wroght Was non so mochel In his thoght; Him thoght it &yogh;ede thorow his hert, So sore sche made him ake and smert. WHen it was ny&yogh;t, the quene vp ros, And Pollexene home with here gos; Achilles loked afftir that wenche With more longyng than man may thenche, Til sche out of the temple was went. Achilles In hir loue then brent; And this was al the bygynnyng Off his sekenes and his lyggyng, That he afftir In his bed lay For loue & longyng of that may. ¶ When he myght hir no lenger se, His herte for sorwe brast on thre, He turned him hom to his tent And In his bed as-tite he went.
