Ther died many a lord & lad, Many knyght & eke baroun, And many other proude Gryffoun. ¶ Many a lord & gentil man Was ded ther, er thei be-lan, Many a kynges sone of kynde— I may not make of alle mynde. But seuen dayes with-oute les Fau&yogh;t thei to-geder with outen pes, Day be day with-oute trewes, Til thei hadde lorn many of the Grwes. ¶ Achilles euere In pes him held, That he bar neuere helme ne scheld Off al that while a-&yogh;eyn Troiens, To dere none of here Citesens. The Grewes by-gan faste to fayle, The Emperour seyde thanne: 'hylhayle! We may now sone be al for-done, But if this lord helpe vs sone; But Achilles on vs rewe, Ther schal not skape of vs a Grewe!' WHen thei hadde fou&yogh;ten seuen dayes, Agamenon Priamus prayes To graunte a trewes by othe & treuthe; For it to se hit was moche reuthe, How alle the feld lay ful of men And lay & stank In that fen. Trewes longe wolde thei haue had, For Agamenon was sore a-drad That he scholde many of his men lese With hem of Troye & of Frese, Iff thei mayntened lenger that stour; Thei asked therfore a long soiour. ¶ But the Troyens seyde: "thei scholde non haue But that thei myght her dede men graue;" Thei wold no lenger the trewes graunte, Thei held hem alle recreaunt. And that rewed Agamenon sore And alle the Gregeis that with him wore, Thei my&yogh;t no lenger the trewes haue; That rewed hem sore—so god me saue!— For thei were wounded and al to-bete, And hadde biles and bocches grete For strokes thei &yogh;aff & eke toke, Whil thei to-gedur ffau&yogh;t that woke. But &yogh;it were thei of that trewe fayn That thei my&yogh;t bery that thei hadde sclayn, Thei gadered alle the bodyes colde That lay ther ded vpon the wolde; And did alle the bodyes be brende, Or the trewes was fully ende,— Longe or the trewes was comen to ende, That thei scholde efft to batayle wende. THe trewes ar went that thei had set, The day is comen of her baret: Thei toke ther many a strok & ffylche, Thei tare her plates and her pilche, When bothe the parties to-geder were comen; Many Ane MS. Aue . his lyff was him be-nomen, When bothe parties were met thare, And to that batayle were alle &yogh;are. ¶ Sir Menelaus Paris sawe, To him he thoght for to drawe; He hadde gret wil & couetyse To se sir Paris feet a-ryse. He strok his stede & to him ran For the loue of his lemman, To grounde were thei y-bore bothe,— The kny&yogh;tes were that tyme so wrothe. ¶ Polidamas, Antenor sone, With gret envy & gret raundone For alle the men and al the pres With his swerd he smot Vlixes; But he &yogh;aff not ther-of an hawe, For he him held with swerd y-drawe. The noble vaylaunt Menescene Smot Antenor—& that was sene,— He &yogh;aff him suche a romelowe, That he wente ouer his sadil-bowe; ¶ Hic Archilogus interfecit Gryme Gwynel. He layde him as brod & flat As is a pike when he is splat. ¶ Then come ridande Philomene, A doghti kyng, a knyght Troyene: Agamenon he assayled That the blod of him doun rayled. Philomene, of so gret myght, Wolde ful euel haue him dyght,— But that him come socour sone, I trowe his dayes hadde ben done. ¶ But Thelameus to him toke hede And saw that he of help hadde nede, He toke a spere that was stalworthe, And turned his hors & rod forthe: To Agamenon he him hyed And smot Philomene that he doun syed Fro MS. ffor . his hors for his labour, For he wolde for to her Emperour. STrong was the stour, perelous, & fel; Ther was a kny&yogh;t, het Gryme Gwynel, He was on of Priamus sones— As I fynde In thes Canones— That he hadde geten In his purchase, In his murthe & his solace. Duk Nestor hadde a sone also, A doghti knyght, Archilogo; Thei mette to-geder, he & Gryme,— A gret vn-hap! a foule fortune! ¶ Archilogus bare sir Gryme thorowe, And lefft him ded In a forwe. The Troyens made gret del ther-fore, Ther died for him mo thenne foure score; For when that tale to Troyle was told, He my&yogh;t not for him fro wepyng hold, For he loued him with al his myght For that he was so doghti a knyght. Troylus eyen be-gan to slyse, The Gregeis sone he gan dispyse: Many for him he be-hedit, Echon fro other he sone schedit; Thei fled echon sir Troylus fro, Thei made him way & lete him go; He droff hem faste ouer doune & dale, Among hem wroght he suche bale. ¶ Thei were ney dreven to her Pauylons, Ne hadde thanne comen the Murondons; But the[i] styffly a&yogh;eyn him stode, But Troylus ferd as he were wode: Whan he saw hem a&yogh;eyn him stande, He rod to hem faste manassande; Vpon her hedes sette he suche dyntes, The fyr fley out as it were of fflyntes. ¶ He was so sore with hem greued, That many an hed he ther to-cleued, Here scheldes fro her scho[l]dres racched; Ful many a Gregeis he ther atacched, He bete hem so and so defouled, That thei with blod were al be-stouled, As thei were paynt with rede coloures; He made hem like tormentoures, Thei toke of him many a cloute. Tho with al the haste that thei moute ¶ Thei turned the bak and fro him &yogh;ede,— On rounsi prekand, and on stede,— Til thei were comen to her hales, To saue her lyff ther In her sales. But Troyle & his afftir hem sted, Thei sclow many of hem that fled; ¶ Hic fugerunt ad tentorias suas. To her tentis he hem droff. But ther turned thei a-&yogh;eyn & stroff, For thei of Troye her dyche wolde wynne, But thei wolde not that thei come Inne: ¶ Thei gadered alle vpon a route, To holde the Troyens tho with-oute; But Troyens doun of her hors lyght, And than be-gan the perilous fyght: For Troyens be-gan foule to fare; Than by-gan Gregeis kare, The Troyens felde hem In her dike; Tho by-gan thei sore to sike; ¶ Her my&yogh;t was nou&yogh;t a-&yogh;eyn Troiens. Troylus then, & Philomens, And kyng Mennon made thanne entre And made hem fro her men to fle; Thei flowe alle In-to her tentis, Many of the Gregeis her deth hentes: THei made of hem gret tormentry, Ther was an hidous noyse & cry, Thei sclow hem In her pauylons; Wel delful was of hem the sounes, So wonderful and meruelous That hit was dredful & hidous: Hit ferde as hit hadde thondrid, Achilles was ther-of a-wondrid ¶ Off wham he herde that delful cry, He saw men come prikande him by That flede fro that scomfiture, Makynge sorwe with-oute mesure. Thei seyde: "alas that thei come thore, For thei were lorn for euere-more!" With-out his tent smartly sterte he, To se what dele that myght be. AChilles was gretly meruayled What hem of Grece ayled. He asked hem: "whi thei so ferde? And what was the noyse that he herde?"— 'How dos oure kynges, and oure Gregeis? How bere thei hem a-&yogh;eyn the Frigais?' ¶ 'Louely lord'—sayde thei that ffledde— 'We are so hurt and so for-bledde, That we Are alle of nompower A&yogh;eyn hem to fyght any lenger. Iff &yogh;e wol off vs tydandis here, Carful tydandes may &yogh;e lere; ¶ Herkenes now of oure tythandes! Sicurly, lord, now vndirstandes: &YOGH;e schal neuere on lyue se Gryffons, Ne non of alle &yogh;oure Murimdons. We telle &yogh;ow, lord, that thei of Grece Schal sone be hewen al to pece, For thei are alle discomfit And alle haue taken the flyt; ¶ Thei are alle fled In-to her tentis, Ther many of hem the dethe hentis. Thei defended here entres, But thei felde doun bothe cordes & tres, And sclow oure Gregeis cruelly, Woundes & stikes with-oute mercy. Hem fayles now the grete socour, And this is, lord, the grete clamour Off hem that dye, that grysly bray,— That &yogh;e haue herd and &yogh;it may. ¶ Thei schal alle dye, er that thei sese; And &yogh;e that wene to stonde In pese, &YOGH;e schal se sone on &yogh;ow comande Mo then ffyue & ffyffty thousande Hic Achilles Iratus est. Off armed men & armed kny&yogh;tes That haue sclayn &yogh;oure men now rightes,— For thei haue slayn of &yogh;oure gode men, Er we come thedir, thousandes ten, ¶ And &yogh;et to scle thei not be-lyn;— And iff thai fynde the her-In In &yogh;oure tent naked stondande, Thei leue the not on lyue lyuande; For al the gold of hethen Spayne Leue &yogh;e not here vnsclayne, For thei hate &yogh;ow ouer alle thyng. For Ector deth—by heuene kyng!— That were, lord, her herte wil, Might thei, lord, thi body spil.' AChilles chaunged al his mode, He loked aboute as he were wode When he herde this tydynges: He clapped his hondes, and alle his rynges Sicurly In-sonder brast; To and fro his armes he cast, As he hadde ben a wod man; Wel harde to swete he be-gan. ¶ Achilles seyde on that wolde To him that these tydandes tolde: 'Is ou&yogh;t Troyle In that place, That makes oure men thus to chase?' He sayde: 'lord, ther he is, And alle oure men he dos amys; For his wodnesse & his deray Alle oure men ben fled a-way; ¶ For he is so strong In his myght, Ther may non a-byde him In fight.' 'Alas!' he seyde, 'that euere Moder me bar! Whi ne were I right now thar? ¶ Hic Achilles Iratus est. Alas that euere me Moder bounde Or euere In MS. Or euere me In . cradel me be-wounde! That I scholde for a wommanes sake Let my enemys suche murther make Off my Men and of my kyn, And do ther-of no medicyn!' ¶ He was so ful MS. sul . of tene & ire That he bad fecche his atire; He for-&yogh;ate ther Polexene And al that he be-het the qwene. His stede was sone j MS. . -dight With clene harneis & bridel bryght, He lepe vp anon vpon his stede And sprang forth as spark of glede. AChilles rides as a man mad, For his men was he not glad; He myght that tene no lenger thole, He brende In yre as any cole; When he herde hem so grysly grone, For hem he made moche mone: As lyoun rampyng forth he went, Wel Armed, out of his tent, To socoure his men and helpe his Danes. When he hem mette a-mong the Troyanes, He sclow hem faste as a tyraunt, Many a man made he criaunt; ¶ He slees & felles al that he metes, Thei falle thikkere than heryng fletes In-myddes the se In here scole. Alle men, thei knewe by his tole: His sword was other halff fote brode; Thorow the Troyens bodyis it glode. Thei knewe him that smot so sore, Alle were a-drad that were thore, ¶ Hic Achilles pugnauit cum Troianis. Whan thei saw that he cam. Off hem made he gret Marterdam: Euery forow Achilles filled, With dede bodies the erthe he hilled That he hadde sclayn In that stour, Sithe he was comen, In litel hour. ¶ Ther was kyng ne kny&yogh;t so gode, That thei ne fled as thei were wode; His noble sword, his bryght bronde, Was blody doun to his honde For men that he hadde ther sclawe, Off many a knyght broght he of dawe. He fferde as it were a deuel of helle, Lord! the peple that he gan qwelle! Thei flow tho ffro her tent & hale, In the diches thei hadde mochel bale. The Murimdones come anon, Now many Troyen to dethe gon; Thei sorwed & cried as thei were wode, Many walwes In his blode. THe Gregeis tho were glad & blythe And thonked her goddis offte sythe, That he was comen to that batayl. Troylus then gan him meruayl: "What deuel In helle hit my&yogh;t be That made the Troyens so to fle?" By his swerd he him ches, He wiste ther-by hit was Achilles That made his Troyens so to fle; Wod & wrothe thanne gan he be, Durste no man aske whi he were wroth, When he bare armes a&yogh;eyn his oth. ¶ As a lyoun rores, to him he cried, With hardy herte he him defied: ¶ Hic Achilles wlneratus est. 'In helle'—seyde he—'mot thow be loken! Hastow now thin owne othe broken? Thow hast euere ben a fals faytour, A losenger, a fals traytour! Were the fro me, I the defy, For if I may, thow schalt a-by!' He let his stede to him flyng Als harde as he myght slyng; And he to him with al his myght, For he at him hadde gret dispit ¶ For his wordes & his reueri Bothe of falsnes & losengeri That he on him bare; that he wolde proue: And ther-to he profered forth his gloue. Him hadde leuere than al that I can telle, That he my&yogh;t Troyle qwelle. STrong & stiff & hardi bothe Were the knyghtes that were wrothe: Eyther on other her speres poygned, Wel hard to-geder tho thei Ioyned, Her scheldis roff, here speres brast, The knyghtes bothe to grounde were cast, That nother of hem with-oute wounde Thei myght not rise nother hol ne sounde. ¶ Achilles for-sothe was euel hurt, Vpon his feet wel sone he sturt And drow his swerd as man of myght, And wolde haue sclawe that gentil knyght. But alle the Troyens on an hepe By-fore him than wel sone gan lepe, And doghti Troyle so thei defende That Achilles myght not come him hende, And ladde him home out of that place. Tho was it tyme to leue the chace, For hit was al atte nyght, And thei were weri of that fyght, That hem lust to take her rest; For that were thanne alther best. Achilles gan faste hamward gange; Many day afftir & lange Lay he seke In his bed; Off his wounde was he sore dred, For hit greued him so sore, He thoght to venge him efft ther-fore. THe Troyens thanne to MS. of . Troye &yogh;ede alle And Troylus to his fader halle, He tolde him of the deth of Brunes; Then were mad hidus tuynes Off many a gentil damysel For the deth of Gryme Gwynel. He tolde him also of the Iornay: "How thei hadde fou&yogh;ten to-gedur that day, And how Gregeis were discomfith And foule put to the fly&yogh;t; And how thei felde her Pauylons, And scholde haue sclayn alle the Gryffons ¶ Er euen-tyde at his hopyng, Hadde thei had no socoryng Off doghti sir Achilles, That foule ferde among her pres;"— 'That Ilke knyght him-selff alone Maked oure men to fle echone For any thyng that we coude do, And made vs lese oure worschepe so.' ¶ When Priamus herde these tydandis— That Achilles a&yogh;eyn couenandis That he hadde made & hem be-het At that MS. And at that . Cf. l. 14313 & note. Iorne hem hadde let And at that MS. At that . Cf. l. 14312 & note. semble sclayn his folk,— His herte for tene be-gan to bolk; Off tho tythandes was he not payde, His wiff ful foule he myssayde: 'Certis, I was'—he seyde—'ful wrecched That I scholde by the so be drecched, Vn-to thi wordes that I &yogh;aff ffayth!'— Priamus to his wiff sayth— ¶ 'This fals MS. sals . traytour has vs by-swyked, For my doghter vnto him lyked; He dede it certes for oure ille, For he of here wolde haue his wille And holde hir In lecherie With his scley&yogh;t & trecherie, And do vs alle a foule repreue As a fals for-sworen theffe. ¶ And that semes by his falshede: For MS. for . now he may not of hir spede At his wille by his dissayte; He be-thenkes him now ful strayte, How he may best schende me & myne; That myght thow se with thin eyne. And elles hadde he holde couenaunt,— But he is fals & euel thynkand And doth alle thyng with gylerye, With no manhed ne chyualrie.' HEctuba was sore aschamed Off here lord that sche was blamed, Hir Angred sore that euere spak sche Ther-of wordes two or thre; Sche cursed offte his wickednesse, His gylrie and his falsnesse. And that mayden Pollexene Ther-of was offte blo & grene, Hit Angerd hir sore & displesed, Whan that hir loue hade so MS. hade him so . spysed That he be-het hir moder & here; Gret othes he made & by god swere, That he ne scholde helpe Gregeis more The while that thei dwelled thore. ¶ Sche chaunged chere & eke corage, For sche wolde fayn the mariage. The kyng & quene were euel lykyng For that dede,—by heuene kyng! Thei sette trestles & layde bordes With litel Ioye of any wordes; When thei hadde souped, thei wente to bedde, Thei swor he scholde hir neuere wedde. THe Gregeis hem Armed, when it was day; Saue Achilles In his bed lay, For his woundes he my&yogh;t not ryse For alle the gode In that emprise. When Troyens herde the waytes horn, Thei ros vp erly on the morn; ¶ Eche man thanne his armes craues, Thei bad her &yogh;omen and her knaues Dight her hors & sadel hem faste. The MS. Thei . sadeles on hem sone were caste With double gerth as thei most nede, To make hem strong thei toke hede; Many a stede broght thei forthe That gret tresour & mechel were worthe; ¶ Her helmes were on her ventayles sperde. Thei lepe vp & forward ferde With-oute the toun vpon a renge. By dere god! hit was elenge Eche a day se hem so fare, How echon other al to-tare! ¶ Hic ibant ad prelium & pugnauerunt .vij tem . dies. When thei were met, ther was no laughter, But moche wo & gret sclaughter. THe Troyens had take the Champayn, Thei are batayled In-myddis the playn. And thei of Grece when thei beheld How thei of Troy hadde taken the feld, Thei sente to hem her vanwarde With brode baneres & hye standarde; And thei come afftir with many a kny&yogh;t, With kynges & dukes of moche my&yogh;t, With many a louely fair pensel Off gold, of Inde, of fair sandel. Thei ran to-gedir, when thei a-proched, Euery man thorow-out other broched; With speres, swerdes, & knyues Echon MS. Echon on . other al to-ryues. ¶ But I may not her dedis alle sigge, Therfore mote I my boke a-bregge; For to telle al that thei did there MS. thore . Til ende scholde I com nere. But .vij. dayes fro thei be-gan, Thei fau&yogh;t to-geder & neuere blan, Til thei my&yogh;t for wery no more,— Her bodyes & bones were so sore, And alle her bones ful sore aked, And thei were wery & for-waked; And al the feld was be-sprad With dede bodyes,—who myght be glad? Off bothe parties were many dede, The nombre of hem coude I not rede. ¶ Seuen dayes fau&yogh;t thei to-gedre, And al that while was mury wedre. For whan thei hadde fou&yogh;ten .vij. dayes With-oute rest to-gedur al-weyes, ¶ Hic Greci miserunt nuncios suos ad Troianum. ¶ Agamenoun thenne assayed, Wh[er]e that fight my&yogh;t be delayed, Vntil Achilles couered wore o altered from e . Off his sekenesse & of his sore; For th[e]i were not at no defence, But he were ther In presence. He sente to Troye his messageres, That were wel gode latymeres, That coude wele say her Message And vndirstande many langage. ¶ He bad hem wende to Priamus, To Paris, & to gode Troylus, And pray hem ffor her goddis sake: "Be-twene vs a trewe to make A six monethe & no day wane,— For dede men are oure alther bane, We may for hem be lyghtly schent, But if thei be the sonner brent. &YOGH;eue vs leue her bodies brenne, And hele the while oure seke menne,— And thei may haue the same merit Thorow the trewe & this respit." THe gode kyng Vlixes, And his felawe Diomedes, To do this erande thei ben chosed: Thei did on robes wel a-losed And furred wel with riche Ermyn, As kynges that were of gentil kyn; Thei were richly apparayled With riche gerdeles wel Anamayled, Thei drow riche hodes of ther pile That alle were sewed with riche orivile; Thei wente to Troye In gode aray,— How richeli dyght, can I not say. When thei of Troye sei hem come naked, Thei hoped a trewe scholde be maked Be-twene hem and Grece kyng; Glad were thei In here thingkyng. ¶ A&yogh;eyns the kynges was done vp the &yogh;ate, The kynges reden In ther-ate; Thei ride hem forth hand In hand With louely chere & fair semblaunt: Thei wente In-to that riche palais And grete the kyng with wordes curteis; And he &yogh;eld sone her metyng And thanked sone her wel-comyng, And sayde "thei were wel-come him to," And asked "what thei wolde haue do?" ULixes kyng & his ffelawe By-fore the kyng a gode thrawe Stode spekand & told her tale Be-fore the Troyens In that sale; He seyse: 'sir, and &yogh;oure wille were, Herkenes now vnto me here! And I schal telle, sir kyng, to &yogh;ow Whi we are comen hidur now: ¶ Agamenoun, oure Emperour, That is oure a[l]ther gouernour, Bad vs two hedur go To &yogh;ow, sir kyng, with-outen mo To aske a trewe, if &yogh;e assent With &yogh;oure consail & parlement. It is long tyme sithen we vs rest, Off medecyne haue we mechel brest; ¶ We haue fou&yogh;ten dayes many, That vnnethes of vs is any That we [n]are wounded or vnhesed, Strongly hurt or envysed, ¶ Hic pecierunt pacem per .vj. Menses. Or bitterly beten with bitter strokes; We wolde ther-fore haue help of leches To hele oure woundes, er we fau&yogh;t efft. We may wilne that it were lefft, Til we MS. he . be hole-he bad vs say,— A six moneth euery day. ¶ He wolde the trewe were be-twene vs fest, Til we were heled In the best, And &yogh;e &yogh;oure-selff to reste haue nede To hele &yogh;oure sores—so god me spede! For I trowe &yogh;e haue som part— Off spere or sword or of dart— Off som brysure or som wounde, &YOGH;e are not al hol ne sounde. I wil therfore &yogh;ow not fode, We mot be-twene vs bere euen lode: &YOGH;iff &yogh;e the trewes assente to, &YOGH;e may hele &yogh;ow, and we also.' PRiamus seyde: 'iff my consayle These couenandes wil entayle, I schal acorde to here Iugement By gode a-surte and sacrament.' He wente fro hem out of that halle And called his men abouten him alle. ¶ He seide: 'lordynges, &yogh;e ben alle here, &YOGH;e are of my counseyl al plenere, And &yogh;e haue herd what these men aske. Telles me now sone In haste: Hope &yogh;e hit be oure profite To take suche trewe & respit? What schal I say to thes lordynges, These Messageres, these riche kynges? Wol &yogh;e the trewe? what is &yogh;oure wit? Are &yogh;e wele avised &yogh;it? Avise &yogh;ow wel, ar &yogh;e hem graunt, That &yogh;e be not afftir repentaunt.' Thei seyde alle: 'sir, we be a-vysed: Thei haue the trewe wel devysed, We graunte the trewes a&yogh;eyns vs.' 'And I for me'—seyde Priamus. ¶ Priamus ran to halle a-valed, Ther these kynges to-gedur taled; He sayde: "that he and his baronage Wolde graunte the terme by gode ostage A six monethe til thei were heled, By siker dedes wel asseled." He bad hem go sauely a&yogh;eyn And holde the trewes for-sothe certayn,— ¶ "For he & his scholde by her othe Holde hem stable for leue or lothe;" And bad: "that thei scholde do so als, That thei were not founden fals; And that euery man with-oute debate Scholde gon & come erly and late With-outen robbyng or reuyng, With-oute any debate-makyng." These kynges swor bothe this— "So god &yogh;eue hem Ioye and blis." Priamus &yogh;aff hem gode conge, To wende her way and wel be. NOw ride these kynges murily, To-gedir rydande Ioyfully; Thei are ful fayn that thei haue sped, Off no-thyng now are thei adrad. Vnto her tentis are thei reden; Thei haue ther not longe abyden, Thei hied hem to her Emperour, Ther he sat vndir his couertour. In his teldis thei him fond, Thei seyde: "thei hadde ben on his sond, And that thei hadde wele done his nedis." And [he] hem blessed for her dedis; He asked: "whether thei treweus hadde A six monethe, as he hem badde?" And thei sayde: '&yogh;e, sir, sicurly! Thei schal be holden treuly ¶ The trewes stable a six monethe, On payne to lese bothe lym & lythe; And ther-to haue we hondes holden And truthis MS. thruthis . ply&yogh;t & fyngres folden.' The tydandes ran fro halle to halle, Eche man tolde other this tale: "How here kynges haue ben at Troye And brou&yogh;t tydandes of moche Ioye, How thei scholde reste a wel gode while." Eche man thanne be-gan to smyle. AGamenoun than was wel glad, And so was euery lord & lad, And euery a knyght that vndirstandis The right sothe of these tythandes. Now euery man helis his soris, Euery man his tentis restoris Off mete & drynke & other store, Wel better than thei were ore. ¶ Thei were fayn of that grace Off her trewe so long a space, Vntil Achilles were y-couered. Many a lord ouer him houered Eche day him to solace; He gan Troyle faste manace. ¶ He seyde: "when he hadde hele, That he wolde with Troy[l]e dele, He wolde not lette for al Fraunce But he tok of him vengaunce." Thei sayde: "that Troyens were dissayued, And that thei nere not persayued To graunte the trewes when thei it asked, For thei scholde now be euel a-tasted, Thei graunt the trewes In the dismole. For were it so that he were hole, He scholde scle Troyle and alle thos other, As he hadde done Ector, his brother." WEle was hem thei scholde soiorne, It was for hem a noble turne: Thei gadered grases on eche halue, And made plastres & eke salue, Thei dyght here woundes that sore gored. Off mete & drynke thei ben wel stored, Thei played at the chesse & tables, And ete & drank and tolde fables. And alle the leches that crafftly were In al the ost that tyme there, ¶ Alle that coude of surgerye, Off Plasteres and of herberye,— Hadde Achilles In that cure To hele his woundes & his visure: Thei &yogh;aff to him wel gode kepyng To brynge him to his right slepyng, Thei made him drynkes of gode licour And broght a-&yogh;eyn his fair colour; ¶ Thei &yogh;aff him drynke many skyns, And heled him vp with medycyns, That he was hole, stalworthe, & fere In his strengthe & playn power, Er euere the trewes come fully out. Then were the Gregeis bolde & stout, ¶ Hic Troiani ordinauerunt magnum Bellum. Whan he was hole & &yogh;ede on fete. For tene his herte wex grete, That Troyle did him the vilony; He hadde to him gret envy, He swore by god that dwelled In heuene He scholde him scle for odde or euene. AChilles is hol & clene In my&yogh;t, Bold and strong, semely In sy&yogh;t, For he is hol In flesch & fel, And as hole as any pykerel. Hit drawes faste vnto that day, That thei most nede leue her play And bygynne a&yogh;eyn the werre, For no man may ther-fro hem sterre; Vntil that on for ay & euere Be al for-done, thei blyn neuere. ¶ Euery man ordeynes now his gere, Sadel, & bridel, & stalworthe spere, Fresche atyre, wel gode newe helmes, And made hem gode staues of oke & elmes Ful of warres and of knottis, Piked staues with heuy bottis. Achilles thinkes day & nyghtis, How he may sle dou&yogh;ti kny&yogh;tis; He nolde it lette for non au&yogh;t That any man him &yogh;eue mau&yogh;t. WHen the trewes were alle gone, And th[e]i were heled euerychone, And day was comen thei scholde fyght, And thei were rysen & redy dight,— Eche man In his armure On gode stedis, be &yogh;e sure!— The Troyens ride to Ilyon; Kyng Philomene & Mennon, Odeman & Eueas, Antenor and Palamydas, And eche a lord &yogh;ede with his ost; And alle men houed then a-cost ¶ Aboute Ilyon, that riche palais, To here what Troyle to hem says: "How he here batayles wolde devise, In what manere and what wyse; Ho schal haue the vaunwarde, Who the myddel, and ho the rerewarde?" So were thei redi In that mornyng, Al redi dyght by sone rysyng. DOghti Troyle faste him payned That thei were wel ordeyned; When thei were ordeyned wele & clene, He bad hem go forth al be-dene, Euery lord with his Eschele, And come a&yogh;eyn with Ioye & hele. The &yogh;ate was than vndone & opone That we by-fore hadde of y-spoken, That &yogh;ate was cleped Dardanydes: Ther was of kny&yogh;tes mechel pres, ¶ At the &yogh;ates thei outward issed, As doughti Troyle hem hadde wissed; Thei ride to-gedir vpon a rase Toward Gregeis a gode pase, Til thei were comen nye here lystes. Thei houed stille at here tristes, Til thei se Gregeis oute comande With brode baneres a-boute wayvande. ¶ Troyle now rides and his Troyanes With his burgeis & Cite&yogh;aynes Out off Troye—alas the wo! For he schal dye, er he then come ffro. Alas Troye! what is thi grace? To the fel neuere gode trace, To the fel neuere gode chaunce, Ne non of alle thi retenaunce! Thoow thow be gay & glorious, Thow were euere Some letters erased between were and euere. on-gracious! Off thow hede of Cites were, Blysful hap to the fel neuere! For better men were neuere lyuand, Than were that tyme to the longand; And &yogh;it was it here alther schap, That thei died alle by myshap. ¶ Ther-fore I trowe In my thoght: A&yogh;ens godis wille so were thei MS. we. wroght. Hadde destyne ben Ector frende, Or doghti Troylus that was so hende, The Gregeis nad not hem sclayn; But destene turned hem a&yogh;eyn, Destyne was here enemy And sclow hem bothe vnhappily. And also died alle that other kynde Off gode men that were In mynde. THe Gregeis saw the Troiens come Out of Troye alle on a throme, Armed wel In her maneres, With faire penseles & brode baneres. The wannward than to hem thei sende, The Middelward MS. Mildelward. come afterhende MS. asterhende. , The rerwarde dwelled lange. But when Achilles scholde out gange, ¶ He gart his men vnto him calle; And when thei stode aboute him alle, He sayde to hem with glad chere: '&YOGH;e ar my frendes leue & dere, ¶ Hic ibant ad prelium. I wot wel &yogh;e loue me mechel With trewe herte & no-thyng fikel, And to do my byddyng are &yogh;e meke; Now for my loue I &yogh;ow be-seke: To my sawe &yogh;e &yogh;eue good tent, And beth to me obedient. ¶ &YOGH;e wot wel what affray I toke of Troyle that other day, Wiche an harm and a wounde; And how I fel vpon the grounde; Bode I neuere scuche a dispit. Now helpis me that it were qwit; But I be venged of that boy, In myn herte gete I neuere Ioy. THer-fore for my loue I &yogh;ow pray That &yogh;e do as I &yogh;ow say: That &yogh;e this day &yogh;eue no gome To kyng ne kny&yogh;t MS. knytt , but the scribe has tried to alter the first t to &yogh;. ne to grome, Man to sle ne to take, Ne non assaut to non make,— But beth besi on alle thing, How &yogh;e may him among &yogh;ow bryng! ¶ When &yogh;e thedir comen are And &yogh;e of him may be ware, Be-closes him al a-boute That he fro &yogh;ow go not oute, And stondis a-boute him on a throme That non of his may to him come Him to defende fro myn hond. Ful stille aboute &yogh;it &yogh;e stond, And lete vs two oure myght schewe; And I schal that boy al to-hewe. But loke that no man to vs come, That fro my hand that he be nome; ¶ Hic preliauerunt. I schal him ful wel qwite That his spere did on me bite, And thus may I haue my wille That foule boy for to spille. ¶ Ther-fore I pray &yogh;ow alle— For any thyng that may be-falle, And as I am &yogh;oure a[l]ther lord— That &yogh;e be alle at this acord And &yogh;if to no-thyng elles kepe.' And with that word Achilles wepe,— So wolde he fayn on him be venged. The batayles ben to-gedir renged, Thei of Troye & thei of Grece; Thei hewe here bodies al to pece, Thei did gret sorwe & mechel wo, Whan thei gan to-gedir go. THe stoure is styff & strong be-gonnen, Euery man on other is ronnen, Thei haue her speres brosten & broken, Ful ffewe wordes ther were spoken; At that tyme were many kastoun A-&yogh;eyn the grounde that al to-brastoun, Ther died many at that torpel. But then come Troyle, y-armed wel, With mechel peple of Armed kny&yogh;tes Come he thedir at that ri&yogh;tes; With scheld enbrased & spere enbossed A-mong the Gregeis he ran & pressed: That he to ran, dethe was his dome; Wel euel was he thedir wel-come. ¶ When Troyle hadde broken his spere, He toke his swerd that wel coude schere, It was trenchaund & wel poynted, With Gregeis blod it was anoynted Fro the poynt to the hilte, Ful many Gregeis hadde it spilte. He rased scheldes ffro here neckes, He teres the mayles as it were sekkes, ¶ He bare hem doun to grounde al fflat, He &yogh;aff hem many a sori sqwat MS. sq wat. ; He droff doun alle that come him by, As doth bestes that ben hungry. Thei were noght to him worth a schelle, He blan neuere to scle & felle Fro he come thedir to the mydday, That thei fro him ffled a-way; Thei fled echon by on red, And elles thei hadde ben alle ded. HIt was a litel be-fore the none, A-boute mydday, that this was done That thei of Grece ffro Troyle fled, So were thei of his strokes dred. But Achilles ne none of hese Were comen not to that purprese; But when he herde hem criande, He loked & sey hem fleande, He saw hem flee fro that purprise, He bad his men be war & wyse. He was y-armed at alle rightes, Strong & hole In alle his myghtes; ¶ He tok his swerd that was so gode, Hit wolde bite as it were wode, Ther was none suche hard ne towe; Many a Troyen ther-with he sclowe. He bad his men: "so mote thei thee"— 'Socoures now hem that now dothe fle! Helpis now, for thei haue nede!' Achilles than to hem &yogh;ede, ¶ He bad his men thenk on his spellis And attende to [no] man ellis; And thei bad him be not abayst,— "But on him he scholde trayst." He passed forth with his meyne And socoured hem that he saw fle, Thei mette the Troyens In her wyse Thei bare hem doun at the burdise. ¶ Achilles and his Murimdones Socoured alle her Gryffones; For by her help and her comyng Thei were tho lettid In her chasyng, And Gregis keuered a-&yogh;eyn the feld And made good visage with spere & scheld To her enemys ful boldely And fau&yogh;t with hem apertly t very indistinctly inserted over line. . GRegais turned and gete the place, For Troyens were let of here chace. The Murimdones for-&yogh;ete no-thyng What was her lordes faire praying: Among Troyens bothe ner & fer Thei loked aboute In euery corner Off that batayle afftir sir Troyle, Iff thei saw owqher that kny&yogh;t royle. So were Thei war where he stode Scleande Gregeis as he were wode: ¶ He was that tyme hi[m]-selff alone, Off hyse that tyme with him were none; Him faste ffyghtand alone thei founde Opon the Gregais In that stounde. Thanne wente aboute him alle that frape, That he my&yogh;t no-wayes skape, And made a scheltrone him aboute And spered him fro alle his route. ¶ Hic Achilles occidit Troylum. Off Gryffons come ther many a kny&yogh;t And halp the Murimdones with her my&yogh;t. ¶ Achilles—lord! that he was glad! Off alle the world no more he bad! He come ridande on his stede, Off sir Troyle toke he gode hede How he sclow doun right his men That thei lay dede In the fen. 'Turne the'—he seyde—'fals gadelyng! Thow schalt now dye—by heuene kyng! My dispite schaltow sore abigge! Kepe the fro me! I the sigge.' ¶ Thei drow her swerdes that were gode And hew to-gedir as thei were wode, The rede blod ran by here side, Thei made hem woundes longe & wyde: Achilles hewys In-two his mayles, The rede blod afftir rayles; He hew the helme al of his hede, His scheld sone he him be-reued. But Troyle defendis him by his my&yogh;t With al his strengthe, that gentil kny&yogh;t. BVt Achilles was so strong That he my&yogh;t not endure long,— No man myght to him come For Murimdones that stode athrome, The Gregeis also with al here myght[es] Passyng twenty thousand knyghtes. ¶ Troyle was wery y seems to be corrected from i. , he myght not sitte, He was al faynt & out of witte For the blod that he gan blede, Tho fel he doun of his stede. Achilles tho lyght glad ynow And his noble swerd out-drow ¶ Lamentacio Troianorum. And smot his hed fro the body And throw MS. drow. it away dispitously; He tyed his body at his hors tayl And drow him tho thorow the batayl. ¶ Achilles has sir Troyle sclayn, And ther-of he is wonder fayn; Michel schame & vylony Did he tho that dede body: He tied him at his hors ers And drow him ouer myre & Mers, Thorow her ost & her batayle He drow him at his hors tayle— As he hadde ben a cut-purs, Ne my&yogh;t he him haue don no wors. ¶ When it was told sir Palidomas idomas written by another hand on erasure. , Antenor, & sir Eueas,— And his brother sir Paris When he herde telle of this, He myght not speke no MS. speken o. word, but swoun, Among hem alle tho fel he doun. ¶ The Troyens than hadde sorwe y-now, When thei saw how he him drow, Thei ran on the Grues alle on a res To reue sir Troyle ffro Achilles. But thei of Grece so with-stode With egre wil & sturdy mode, That thei myght not the Gregeis twyn Ne that body fro hem wyn. A wonder stoure and a cruel Be-gan thei thanne & a mortel, For alle the Troyens ther-aboute Gadered hem vpon a route, The ded body fro him to reue; But Gregeis wolde it not leue. Achilles cleues alle her bones, For sorwe thei crye & bitterly grones. ¶ But when Mennon, that noble kyng, Off Troyle herde this tydyng, Whan he wyste that he was sclayn And thorow that ost so foule drawyn,— An hundrid sithe he seyde 'alas!' So was him wo that he ded was: "Alas!"—seyde he that tyme & tyde— "That euere scholde he that day a-byde To se so noble a doghti knyght Be so distroyed & foule dyght!' With sore herte thorow alle that prese Cried Mennon to Achilles, ¶ When he was comyn to him neye; He sayde: 'traytour, I the defye! To thi MS. his. hors tayl that knyght to bynde, In thi foule herte how myght thow fynde? And drawe him thorow bekke & broke That gentil kny&yogh;t that thow so toke, That was so gode of vasselage MS. basselage. , Off dou&yogh;tines & of corage! Ware the, traytour, now for me! By him that made leff on tre: Thow schalt him no further drawe With-oute harm for loue ne awe!' LOrd, that Achilles was wode! That alle tho chaunged his blode! That he sette him so at noght, He thoght it scholde be dere a-boght; He smot tho kyng Mennon a-&yogh;eyn With al his power & his mayn, And kyng Mennon to him with that; But Achilles In his sadel sat. But thorow his scheld & Aketoun He smot Achilles In that raundoun; ¶ Achilles was sore aschamed And of that dede foule a-gramed, Opon his swerd his hond he layde And swere by othe and seyde: "That he scholde doun for leue or lothe!"— And therto Achilles swor his othe. ¶ Achilles smot that kny&yogh;t sore, That he fel doun of his hors thore Opon the grounde In a ded swone, And of his hors he fel a-doune. The Troyens than fro him wan; But &yogh;it ther died many a man With dynt of sword In that batayle, Thei suffred ther ful mechel trauayle. THe while thei were at this fight, The Troyens with strengthe & myght Troylus body a-way thei stale As faste as thei myght hale, Til it was stolen out of that ost, Vndir a dike layde a-cost. Than gan these ostis parte atwynne, For of that fyghtyng wold thei blynne MS. thei not blynne. ; And kyng Mennon a hors was brou&yogh;t, But arst with Troyens was hit ful tou&yogh;t. ¶ But it was euen, they my&yogh;t not dwelle, Thei departed, as I &yogh;ow telle: Hit was ney the euenyng, The sonne was ney at his settyng; And bothe parties hamward drow, For thei hadde foghten long y-now. The Gregeis &yogh;ede to here tentis; And Paris vp that body hentes, And a-none hamward gan royle, And ledde with him the body of Troyle. THei haue her fyght for this day ent; And thei of Troy hamward went, The dede body with hem thei ledde, Al of blod it is be-bled. At euery temple the belles ronge, Euery man wepe, and no man songe; And ther-by wiste alle tho of Troye That some of heres were dede & foye. Philomene & kyng Mennon That body bar to Ylion, And alle the Troyens on a rowe With loude criyng and moche harrowe. ¶ When thei of Troye hadde herd that cry, Thei asked "how?"—the chesoun whi Thei cried so and wepe so sore— "And what he was that thei bare thore? Iff he were lord of gret renoun? Or any kyng of any regioun?" And thei answered & seyde a-&yogh;eyn: "That it was Troyle that ther was sclayn." ¶ When thei of Troye the sothe wiste, Ther was wrongen many a ffiste. 'Alas'—thei seide—'now he is ded, Now are we alle with-outen red!' Thei wyste tho to lese her lyues, Bothe here children & here wyues, And alle the godis euere thei aught; Off here lyues tho rou&yogh;te thei naught. ¶ The sorwe that the fadir made! Ther was no man that him myght glade. Out off sorwe was not the quene, Ne his suster Pollexene. Sche made for him sorwe y-now, For dele hir body al to-drow, Hir louely heer sche al to-rent, Sche cracched hir face & al to-schent,— That it was ruthe & gret pite So fair a lyff so dyght to se. ¶ In gret mornyng was dame Heleyn, When sche wiste sir Troyle sclayn; And his brother, sir Paris, Gret sorwe made he y-wis: He sorwed bothe day & ny&yogh;t. And so did euery lord & kny&yogh;t, And alle that euere were In the toun; For thei seide alle: "thei were a-doun,"— And al the nyght til the morwe Lyued thei In gret sorwe. ¶ But the Gregeis were wel glad; Lord, the Ioye that thei mad That her strong fo was sclayn! Lord, that thei therfore were fayn! Thei sclepe al ny&yogh;t and made blythe, And thonked her god offte sithe, And solaced Achilles thei also For that prowesse that he hadde y-do. ¶ When day was comen, and ny&yogh;t gon, Thei toke her hors euerychon chon on erasure, but by the same hand. And rod a&yogh;eyn In-to the feldis, Out of the toun & of the teldis; And be-gan a newe assaut, Til hit was fer with-Inne the naut. WHen it was day, & thei sei lyght, And thei were armed & redi dyght, Out of Troye rod the Troyanes; A-&yogh;eyn hem come alle the Danes, ¶ Hic Pugnabant per vij tem dies. Wel arayed on horse rydande, With fair scheld & spere In hande. Many a man ther strokes toke, That many of hem her lyff for-soke; Many a body was ther to-koruen, And many gode kny&yogh;t was ther storuen. ¶ And thus ferde thay til it was nyght, That thei of sonne had no syght, That thei most nede take her rest. On morwe were thei al prest That ffyght a&yogh;eyn to be-gynne; For that wolde thei neuere blynne, Vnto that on were for-done,— And that scholde now be sone. ¶ And thus ffau&yogh;t thei to-gedur samen— Alle on ernest & not on gamen— With-oute rest dayes seuene; But alle her dedis may no man neuene, For that wolde be to longe dwellyng, To moche werk of my tellyng: For who-so wolde aboute that dwelle Alle her dedis for to telle, Many bokes myght men make; I wol not now vndirtake.— ¶ But seuene dayes with-outen pes, With-oute rest—so saith Dares— Fau&yogh;t thei to-gedir day for day, Saue Achilles In his bed lay To hele the woundes that he hadde cau&yogh;t, When he & Mennon to-gedir fau&yogh;t Off that fyght that thei hadde meled. The seuenthe day whan he was heled Off his woundes wel & fyn, Off his Angwys & his pyn, ¶ Incipit bellum In die septimo. He Armed him as other did, To go & fyght the Gregeis myd. ¶ Then were the Gregeis bold & glad; Alle his men tho faire he bad Some letters erased after bad . , That when thei come to that batayle, That thei scholde alle Mennon assayle And close him alle envyroun, That him myght helpe no man; And &yogh;iff to no man elles entent, But that he were amonges hem hent, That he myght do hem wreche, And sle him for his s on erasure. last speche, And for he woundid him so sore— He swore: "he scholde do so na more MS. namore . ." ¶ And therfore he bad his men not fayle To helpe him wele In that batayle; Thei bad him holde him stille, Hit scholde be done at his wille. HIT was opon the day seuend, Achilles thoght he wolde be euend Vpon the doghti kyng Mennoun. He bad her kynges & Agamenoun: "That he scholde the Gregeis aray, To se that day qwat thei do may?"— 'For I my-selff that day schal lede The formast warde, so god me spede!' ¶ Agamenoun tho hem arayed,— With baneres brode alle displayed,— And bad echon thei scholde hem hye Forward with her companye, For thei of Troye were comen alle And with-outen her Cite walle In-to the feld, to take her stale, With many riche amerale. ¶ Kyng Mennoun the vamwarde ledis, Vnto Achilles he him spedis; When he saw him be-fore comande, He hied to him faste ridande: Rode thei to-gedir with gret envy As faste as thei myght fly, Ayther smot other In-myddes the scheld, That bothe fley on the feld Fro her horses to the grounde, That nother was with-outen wounde. ¶ But thei lepe vp & fau&yogh;t on fote, For tho was hem no more bote: But Mennon was his men with-oute, Here horses ran fro hem a-boute; Ther was no man to him &yogh;aff gome, Kyng ne sqwyer, kny&yogh;t ne grome. TRoyens mette & the Gryffons With sword & spere & gret burdons, With piked staues wel y-wrythen. Ther was a fyght strong y-&yogh;euen: On bothe parties thei died thikke, But thei schal leue non qwyk, Many a schanke brake thei In-sonder, And many lay his hors fet vnder; Ech-on other smot & quelled That thikke to grounde ded thei felled. ¶ Many an hed was al to-squat MS. alto squat . , And many ded on his hors sat; Some loste nose, & some her tonges, Som her lyuer, & som her longes. The Murimdones when thei were ware Off kyng Mennon & his fare A-&yogh;eyn her lord, thei hadde gret tene, Thei closed him tho hem by-twene ¶ Hic Achilles occidit Mennonem Regem. That no help myght he haue Off no Troiene—so god me saue! Thei holde hem oute with gret fyght And sclow the Troiens doun right. ¶ Achilles and Mennoun fau&yogh;t In-fere, The strokes myght men fer here; The knyghtes were bothe gode & strong, But her fyght myght not dure long: But Mennoun woundes Achilles sore, But Achilles did him wel more, Thei fau&yogh;t to-gedir as thei were wode, Bothe thei ran al on blode. ¶ Mennon scheld is al to-hewe, He cutte his mayles rewe on rewe, With his blod-brode bronde He hewe his scheld to his honde: Mennon was faynt for many wounde, Achilles smot him doun to grounde, He cleue his hede to his brest, He bad him lye ther & rest. MEnnoun is ded, and that is harm; He lithe ded In his blod warm. Troyens bere him a-way thore, Thei were tho agast sore. But then come doun to that semble Menelaus with his meyne; And so did duk Menescenes, And Ayax Thelamens, And Diomedes with his peres, With his gode men & comperes: And hem of of inserted by the same hand over line. Troye so schent & donge And so stoutly among hem thronge, That thei made hem the feld for-sake And to the flyght for-sothe hem take. ¶ The Troyens fledde, for thei hadde nede; Thei were echon In gret drede For tho that Gregeis ouer-toke, Afftir lyff myght thei not loke. Thei sclow the Troyens many on And wounded also gret won; But alle that hadde space to fle Flow In-to Troye, the strong Cite, And spered the &yogh;ates with keye & lokke To kepe out the Gregeis folke. ¶ The Cite &yogh;ates are sperd & stoken, That thei be not on hem broken; And thei wente alle In-to her Innes. But Hectuba, the quene, not blynnes Reuful sorwe & dele to make For doghti Troyle, her sones, sake; For &yogh;it he liggis vpon molde, I-buried In clothes of golde. PRiamus wepis and makes mone, And so do alle the lordes echone, Paris wepis for him sore, And so did his suster wel more, That faire mayden Pollexene, And Eche burgeis & Cite&yogh;ene. For eche man cares now for his lyff, For his children, & for his wiff. For Mennoun kyng were thei sori, Ther was non that he ne was drery. ¶ Now is Ector ded, and Dephebus, Troyle also the vigorous, And sir Mennoun, the doghti kyng. "Alas, Alas!" thei gan to syng, For hem is lefft none but Paris, Now of Troye is litel Prys. The rubricator forgot to paint over the small p . ¶ Hic Troiani pecierunt pacem ad sepiliendum Troyllum & Mennonem Reges One line in MS. . PRyamus calles his conseleres, And biddes hem chese two Messageres That ben witti and curtays, That may wende on Message to the Gregays; He bede hem riche robis done on And wende to kyng Agamenoun MS. Agamenon . . ¶ The Messageres to Gregays wende, The kny&yogh;tes curteys, gode, and hende, A trewe to aske—as here kyng sayde;— And thei hem graunt and are wel payde. And thei come a-&yogh;eyn ridande To telle him of her tydande, And seyde: 'the trewes are ferme & stable, Sicurly with-outen ffable.' ¶ The Troyens haue at Gregays ben, And trewe is taken hem be-twen. A precious tombe for Troyle was wroght, And his body ther-In was broght; And leyde him ther-In bischopis thre With wonder gret solempnite: Ther was for him a riche offerynges Off Erles, Dukes, and of kynges. ¶ In the MS. the next line (15254) is standing here, after this sign. And Priamus made also Another tombe Menoun vnto, And did his men ther-Inne him brynge With fair seruice & gret offrynge. And whan that seruice was al y-done, To her mete thei wente sone, Thei dight hem to her mete. But Hectuba has not for-&yogh;ete Off Troyle deth, that doughti kny&yogh;t, That sche loued with al her my&yogh;t: Many a way that lady soght And wel narwe sche hir be-thoght, ¶ Lamentacio Hectube. How sche myght venge hir on that swayn That hadde hir two sones sclayn. Sche called to hire hur sone Paris And seyde to him wepande y-wys: ¶ 'Paris'—sche seyde—'thow wost wele Off this Achilles euery dele. This wicked theff Achilles Thi bretheren hath sclayn with-oute les With his falshede & his quayntise, Ther-fore I wolde on alle wise Be venged on that wicked fode; Me were it leuer than any gode! I pray the: do thing that I bidde, That my consayl be not kidde.' HEctuba with drery mode Seide to Paris ther he stode: 'This wicked man, this losengere In al this batayle hath no pere; He wol vs alle distroye, But we the rather may him anoye. This Achilles, wham I mene, Loues thi suster Pollexene, And has offte sent his message Hir to haue In mariage; ¶ He wolde neuere of sendyng blyn, Til he of me answere my&yogh;t wyn. I wol therfore—so god me a-mende!— To-morwe erly afftir him sende And bid him derely: "come me tille, And he of hir schal haue his wille." And than wol I—so haue I blis!— In the temple of Apolynys That thow be hid with certayn kny&yogh;tis, Armed wel at alle rightes; And when he comes a-mong &yogh;ow alle, That he be sclayn,—what so be-falle!— That he no wyse passe quyk, For that were then to vs ful wik.' PAris than answered & sayde: 'Mi dere Moder, I holde me payde Off &yogh;oure biddyng & &yogh;oure consayl; Hit schal be done with-oute fayl.' On morwe erly, whan it was day, Paris thanne with-oute delay Wente to the temple, and ther him hid With twenti armed kny&yogh;tes myd That were hardy & wondir strong, To scle Achilles hem among. ¶ The sonne schon, the day was cler, Hectuba sente hir Messanger Afftir that kny&yogh;t, sir Achilles, And bad him faire: "whil it was pes, Come swithe home to hir house, And he scholde haue to his spouse Pollexene, that semely may, That he so moche loued ay." ¶ When Achilles these tydynges herde, With mochel Ioye & murthe he ferde, For he was so with hir loue bounden: Thoow he hadde of rede gold founden An hundrid thousand pounde, He hadde not ben so glad that stounde As he was thanne—I vndirstande,— When he herde this tythande. ¶ Qualiter Achilles fuit occisus. ¶ He called as sone vnto him tho Duk Nestor sone MS. Nestorsone . with-outen mo, A doghti kny&yogh;t, sir Archilogus, And seide anon to him thus: 'Archilogus, my trusti frend, I pray the now: with me thow wende; On the is now my most trayst, Ther-fore I am not a-bayst The to telle my priuete: I wol wende to that Cite, I schal haste me thedir now; Schal no man wyte but only thow. ¶ For I haue then suche tythandes had That I am bothe mury & glad: For I schal wende vn-to my wyff That I loue more than my lyff; I schal wedde that mayden clene, The kynges doghter, Pollexene, That is whitter then Blauncheflour; And I haue loued hir per amour And suffred for hir moche pyne, But now is sche on of myne. ¶ I wol therfore to hir me spede, That sche delaye no more this dede.' So sche spak & so sche glosed, That he bad men scholde him lay Somwhere In Troye In an hye way, That euery man that likyng hadde Might hem be-holden & be gladde, ¶ Whan thei saw ded that ilke body That was that mortel enemy. In Troye tho was mochel Ioye Among alle burgeis of Troye, When thei saw him ded & sclayn thore That thei be-fore hadde dred so sore. Thei sayde tho: "thei hadde no drede Off the Gregays ne of her dede, For thei scholde neuere the Cite wynne, Sithe he was ded her trust was Inne." ¶ And thus was Achilles done to ded Thorow a wicked woman red, Thorow her sleght & consayl Died the knyght with-oute fayl. And so hath many a-nother man Died thorow red of a womman: That neuere were so gode knyghtes Off ffairnes, of connyng, ne of myghtes, ¶ The beste body that euere ete bred Thorow fals wymmen haue ben ded. THese kny&yogh;tes are layd In monument, And alle these lordes hom ben went Vnto her tentis & here hales. Ther were amonges hem many tales: Some bad pul vp rope & stake, For thei wolde hamward schake; And some bad dyght schip & ore, For thei wolde dwelle ther no more. BVt Priamus with that seyde "nay," Hem thurt no more of that play; That wolde he no wyse graunte, To sende out kny&yogh;t ne sergaunte To fight with hem with-oute the walles, For no-thing that ther be-falles. With-Inne the toun whil thei dwelle stille For fferd of more perel & ille, For he was ferd his men to tyne And die him-selff with moche pyne. ¶ To fight with hem the Gregais assayed Aud therto wel offte thei prayed; But al was noght that thei coude do, For he wolde not assente ther-to, Thei dwelled so forthe In the toun, And walked vp the toun & doun, And kepte the &yogh;ates and the walles With alblasteres, bowes, & qwarelles, With many an armed knyght & man, That thei with-outen the toun not wan. Thei helde so Troye a ful .ij. monethe, That thei fau&yogh;t neuere her fomen with, But kepte the toun so al aboute For ferd of hem that were with-oute. Two Monethes the &yogh;ates were stoken That thei were neuere vnloken, Vntil a quene gentil & ffre Come hem to helpe fro fer contre. The quene was called Pantasaley, A noble womman of Chyualry, Sche was quene of Amazone; For hir was furst the &yogh;ates vndone: Sche come thedir with a thousande Off hardi maydenes wel fyghtande, To helpe Troyens, tho hir was tolde That the Gryffons proude & bolde With mechel ffolk & gret aray Aboute the toun of Troye lay And seged hem that were with-Inne, To scle the kyng, the toun to wynne. BVt herkenes now of the quene, And of hir maydenes bolde & kene! I wol &yogh;ow telle, if &yogh;e wol here, Off here lond the right manere; Where it is, and what lande, The manere schal &yogh;e vndirstande. And elles wol &yogh;e haue meruayle— That wommen scholde go to batayle, Armed as men vpon her stedes, And be so doghti In her dedes. IN the est-ende of alle the world— ¶ De Insula Amazone On the left side in MS. . As I In bokes haue I-herd— Is a lond, a louely Ilde, That wymmen dwelle In, wonder wilde, Off grete renoun and prowesse, That Amazone y-called is; Wymmen dwelle ther-Inne alone, Men with hem wol thei haue none. ¶ Off these wymmen the stori spekes And seythe: thei are strong frekes, Styff, & strong, stalworthe In werre Strokes to &yogh;eue and to berre, Armes to bere In many a stoure, To wynne hem los and gret honoure; For alle here herte & couetyse Is to be of gret empryse. ¶ Be-syde that Ile another Ile was, Long & large, brode In compas, Wonder fayr and delitable, Plenteuous and amyable,— And telles vs the right story, That men with-oute company Off womman-kynde dwelles ther-In. To telle &yogh;ow wol I begyn: What vse thei haue, & what custome, And how thei to-gedir come? THese wyse clerkes for-sothe telle, That these wommen that so alon dwelle In the lond of Amazone, Comen to the lond ther men In wone Sicurly thries In the &yogh;ere, And dwellen to-geder ther In-fere To haue her murthes & delite And do here wille day & ny&yogh;te. ¶ These clerkes say and Philo&yogh;oferus: The womman to the man hir proferus, For thei are also styff & strong That no man dar come hem among In-to her lond a&yogh;eyn here leue, For men hem schulde no-thyng greue Ne nothyng done a&yogh;eyn her wille. In her lond holde thei hem stille, Til tyme of &yogh;er that thei come doun And dwelled with hem In tour & toun, And take her solace & here play— That is In Iune, Aueril, & May MS. That is Jn. June. Aueril. & May . . ¶ Euery &yogh;er these thre Monethe Come thei to dwelle ther-In withe, And wende a&yogh;eyn than to her Il[d]e. Iff it be so thei be with childe, And it be ought of womman-kynde, Among the wymmen—thei it fynde— In her lond ther stille it dwelles Among hem euere—as my boke telles. ¶ Iff it be man, thei brynge it forth Til it be so moche worth, That it can go and be so bold That it be fully thre &yogh;er old; And whan it is of thre &yogh;er elde That it may it-selff welde, To that Ilde that is hem hende Ther men dwelle, the childer thei sende To the fader and to his kyn, To dwelle with hem the lond with-In. THat tyme—godemen!—of that prouynce ¶ De Pantasa|lia Regina On the left side in MS. . Pantasalye was quene & prince, A doghti Mayden & sterne, That loued Ector wel longe derne For his prowesse & his noblay That sche herde of him offten say. When that quene, that frely fode Off Amazone, so vndirstode That thei of Grece were passed the see And Priamus and his Cite Hadde be-seged him & his londes wasted, Pantasalye to him sche hasted And toke with here Maydenes x. hundre That echon were hir baner vndre, To helpe the kyng for Ector sake And do the Gregais mochel wrake. But sche wiste not of Ector ded, To wende to Troye tho sche toke red; Sche wiste right not, til sche come thore. When that sche wiste, sche weped wel sore; Sche hadde for him gret wo & payn, When sche wiste that he was sclayn. PAntasalye, that worthi wyght, Is comen to Troye with-oute knyght, With-outen kny&yogh;tes or any men, But fair companye of hir wymmen That are hardi as men In dede, Off lyues man haue thei no drede. But than hadde sche care In thoght, When Ector was to dethe y-brought; ¶ At hem of Grece hadde sche gret Ire, Sche prayed the kyng for the loue of hire, That he wolde then the &yogh;ates vndo That sche my&yogh;t wende the Gregais to, For sche scholde so do,—sche him be-hight,— That a mayden was worth a knyght And as strong and as &yogh;epe, When thei were met on an hepe. ¶ So longe prayed sche, he graunt hir bone; He bad a &yogh;ate scholde be vn-done, He bad opon Dardanides; But him hadde leuere haue ben In pes, For he was ferd what scholde be-tyde, When he saw hem of Troye out-ride. ¶ Hic Priamus ordinat Prelium magnum. ¶ Dardanides that &yogh;ate dos opon, Pantasalye on horse is lopon With hem of Troye and with alle hires, Armed wel In al here tyres. PRiamus his men araied As that lady him praied; Sche was that day here souerayn, Here ledere, & here cheuayntayn. Pantasalye that &yogh;ate rod oute With-outen fere fere inserted by another hand over line. & with-oute doute Off hir enemys or of hir fos, Ful hardeli to hem sche gos, With hir Maydenes ridande be-syde That wolde with hir In stour abyde. ¶ Kyng Philomene and Eueas, And afftir that Polidomas, Come with here batayles on a rowe, And thei of Perse with qwyuer & bowe— That Paris was wont to lede— Forth to ffyght with hem thai MS. that. &yogh;ede. ¶ When thei of Grece saw hem come out So proudely praunsande & so stout, Thei were echon gretly meruayled What it myght be that hem ayled That thei come out so proude & gay, And ther-byfore not many a day With-oute her &yogh;ates durst thei not passe? Thei hadde meruayle how it was? But when thei saw hem out comande, Eche man toke his harneis In hande And hyed hem that thei were clad, For of here werre werre inserted over line by another hand. were thei glad. ¶ Thei lepe on horse with moche rape And rod out vpon a frape, ¶ Hic venerunt omnes ad Bellum. With manye brode gomfanoun, As lordis of gret renoun. When thei were comen to-gedir there, A wonder noyse men my&yogh;t here Off speres that thei brak & barst, Off kny&yogh;tes that were to grounde cast. Echon on other wolde be wroken, Ther were many bones broken, Hedis corven, heeres schorne, Scheldes reven, armes torne. ¶ But herkenes now, my louely frende, Off Pantasalye, that mayden hende, And hire hardi damyseles That come with hure & with hure penseles How sche bare hir In that pres With hir Maydenes that sche ches; How sche bare that day the pris Off alle that fau&yogh;t In that [emp]ris; How sche made hem to flee, And how sche hem droff In-to the see; How sche hem felled & wounded, And scholde hem alle [haue] confounded, Ne hadde y-ben withouten les The doghti kyng Diomedes. NOw ar thei alle to-gedere on hepis, Now euery man on other lepis, Scheldis ryue, & speres crake, Eche man fightis with his make, Fotemen falle, stedis straye, Kny&yogh;tes wounded ligge & braye. The dust ros so thikke on hye, That men my&yogh;t not se the skye. ¶ Pantasalye, that dou&yogh;ti quene, Hatis Gregais—and that is sene:— ¶ Hic Pantasalia Regina pugnauit cum Regibus Grecorum. That dou&yogh;ti quene ful wel hem knowes, Sche keste hem doun & ouerthrowes; With-Inne a while so fele sche hath sclawe, That thei fro hir a-weyward drawe; Thei knewe ful sone al hir strengthe, Thei fled fro hir on brede & lengthe. MEnelaus hadde grete envy Off that quene Pantasaly, That sche the Gregais so defouled o corrected from e . ; On hir that tyme ful foule he schouled And seyde: "that he wolde to hir ride To se whether sche wolde him abyde." He rode to hir with mochel Ire, And sche was war & keped that sire And smot him euene In-myddes the scheld, That he fley out In-myddes that feld; Among her horses stille he lay, Til that he was drawen a-way. By the rayne his stede sche cau&yogh;t And to a mayden sche him be-tau&yogh;t. ¶ Diomedes, that dou&yogh;ti kyng, By-held that tyme that Iustyng, He saw the kyng falle a-doun, Vp the fete & doun the croun; His hors was lorn, & he on fote, He seyde: "ther-on he scholde do bote, That sturdy strok scholde sche abye." He rode thanne to Pantasalye With al the myght that euere he hadde, But sche was not of him a-dradde: Sche cau&yogh;t a spere, when sche was war That þat kyng to hir was war; A sterne strok was hem by-twene, But on hir hors sat the quene That bridel ne stirop sche ne tynt, But he was feld doun at that dynt; Fro his nekke toke she his scheld And toke hir mayden for to weld, And bad: "that sche scholde it bere Euery day ther In that were, In vilonye and In dispit Off him that it au&yogh;t, what so he hit." Kyng Thelaman stode euere alone And saw the dedis that sche had done, He saw hir felle that dou&yogh;ti kyng, And his scheld take with-oute lesyng Fro his nekke his vnthankes, And felde him doun at his hors schankes; And he was feld opon the grounde, And sche sat stille hol and sounde ll. 16197-8 are following ll. 16201-2 in MS., and are crossed out several times. . He herde neuere speke of suche a woman That feld In fyght so gode a man. ¶ Gret envy hadde he ther-ate, Opon hys y and s on erasure. hors ther he s seems to be erased before he . sate; He wex for tene blak as Cole, That schame myght he no lengur thole That sche hadde done the kynges two, He wolde assaye what he myght do: ¶ He toke a spere of stalworthe tre,— For he on hir wolde venged be,— And rode to hir with gret herte; And sche him kepis rapely & smerte, Sche smot him euen In-myddis the scheld That he fley out In-myddes the feld. So sore to grounde the knyght sche puttis, That he wende he hadde to-brosten his guttis; And sche gurd forth among the Grewes MS. gregais . And mochel bale among hem brewes MS. brennes . : Sche turned a-&yogh;eyn to Thelaman And sturdi strokes laid him an, Sche bete that kyng for-sothe so sore That sche of force toke him thore; With the help of Philomene Sche did to him that day gret tene, Sche toke the kyng to hir meygne To lede him to Troye Cite. ¶ But Diomedes, when he was resen, Saw Thelaman was taken to prison, Toward the toun he saw him go,— Lord god, that him was wo! He blewe his horn & samed his men, Ther come aboute him thousand ten Off doughti kny&yogh;tes swithe proude, And asked: "whi he blew so loude? What it be-mente? what it myght be?" He seyde: 'felawes, may &yogh;e not se How Thelaman, that doghti kny&yogh;t, With hem of Troye is discomfy&yogh;t? ¶ Lo! where thei lede him toward toun Ouer dale and ouer doun! But sicurly, if I may spede, Thei schal him not to Troye lede. I &yogh;ow be-seke, falawes myne alle, For any-thing that may be-falle: In this gret nede fayle me not, Til I haue him fro hem y-brou&yogh;t!' WHen he these wordes to hem hadde sayd, On his scholdur his spere he layd: He ran to hem that Thelaman ledde, And thei of him were sore a-dredde,— Some he MS. by . hurt & some by-heded, With stalworthe strokes he hem schedid. To lete him go thei were fayn, That thei of him were not sclayn. ¶ Thelaman MS. Diomedes . fro hem he toke And faste aweyward with him schoke. When the quene herde it say How he from hem was led away, For wratthe sche wax ner wode,— So sterne sche was In hir mode. That ladi thanne, Pantasalye, To hir Maydenes by-gan to crye And gadered hem vpon a route; When thei were comen hir aboute, Sche bad that thei scholde kythe here myght Bothe on kyng & eke on knyght. PAntasalye, that Damysele, When sche herde telle how it felle That Thelaman was fro hem twyght Thorow Diomedes, that gentil kny&yogh;t, Sche swor an othe ther: "for his sake Sche wolde scle that sche myght take." Hir maydenes to-geder tho samed, Sche seyde: 'are &yogh;e not aschamed That this kyng is take fro &yogh;ow? Felawes myn, I pray &yogh;ow now: For so haue I euere gode chaunce, Thei schal bye his lyueraunce.' ¶ Sche strok hir stede with hir spores, Ouer falow & ouer forwes Among the Gregais sche ther rennes— As dos the fulmard among the hennes.— Many a scheld that lady rofe, And many a basenet sche al to-drofe MS. alto drofe . , Many a bak that day sche bowed, For Thelaman was so rescowed. Sche wounded & sclow & droff doun The men that most were of renoun, Sche barst gerthes, paytrel, & pole; The gentil quene delis hir dole Here & thore as sche hem takes, Gret ma[r]tirdome of hem sche makes; Vn-til here tentis sche hem reuersed, In euery a side that ost sche persed. WAs non of hem that tyme so bolde Durst fyght with hir opon the wolde, Not Diomedes, that vigorus, Ne Ayax Thelamanyus, Ne that sturne kny&yogh;t Menescene Durst not byde hir In here tene, Ne Agamenon, here Emperour, Ne thei that were of most valour Not ones loke to hir ward MS. hirward . ; But alle thei flow aweyward, Vntil thei come to her tentis. Many a man her dethe ther hentis, ¶ For sche hem chased with swerd In hande, With loude vois hem manassande, And droff hem ouer doune & dale, And fro her tentis & fro here hale, Vntil thei come vnto the see That thei no wyse myght fer flee. Tho turned thei a&yogh;eyn and fau&yogh;t, As thei that tyme nede mau&yogh;t, Or haue ben draynt In the see. So that quene by-gan to slee, ¶ Thei hadde died tho with gret trosture, Ne hadde tho y-comen socoure: For tho come than with-oute les The noble kyng Diomedes And made of the Greces resistens A-&yogh;eyn the quene & hir defens, And mayntened the fight tho A&yogh;eyn Troyens with mochel wo, Til it was nyght & day gone. Thei departed sone anone, For hadde thei had day at wille, Many a Grew hadde thei don spille. ¶ Thei of Troye rode to the toun, And Gregais to here Pauyloun; And set hem doun In tent and hale, Wel sore & dreri, wan & pale For werinesse of that Iornay, That it myght no better be that day. To dight here mete her men thei bad, To comforte hem for nede thei had, And ete & drank as thei myght, And sone to reste thei hem dight; For werinesse off that Iornee Nede to reste tho haued hee. THat worthi wyght, that fair lady, That doghti quene, Pantasaly, With hir Maydenes is comen to Troye With mochel murthe & mochel Ioye, For gret worschepe & los sche wan Off many kny&yogh;t & many man For dedis that day that sche hadde done. The tydandes come to Priamus sone, At hure Innes that sche was lyght With hir Maydenes stalworthe & wyght. ¶ When Priamus, the kyng, herde say That the worthi gentil may Was I-comen to hir Inne,— Til he come ther wolde he not blynne, That noble quene to MS. he to . thanke & se That so hadde meyntened that melle For him al day MS. alday . to his honour; &YOGH;it hoped he to be conquerour By that quene of alle his foos. Kyng Priamus to hir vp goos With mury herte & glad chere, And thanked hir on his manere Off hir godenesse & noblay That sche for him hadde done that day. KYng Priamus to hir him profered And al his goodis to hir he offred, And &yogh;aff hir &yogh;ifftis many & fele, Many worthi riche Iuele; Many a noble riche present The kyng to hir that euenyng sent: Clothes of gold of mochel pride, And stedes stronge vpon to ride, And gode Armure of gode a-tyre Sent Priamus that nyght to hire. ¶ He was so fayn of hir prowesse, That he wende by hir doghtinesse Off al his bale to haue bote. But he was—lord!—&yogh;it vndirfote, Er that &yogh;er was al out-paste; That fair Palais was ouercaste And distroyed, and al his kyn,— Wyff, & child, & cosyn,— And alle the kynrede that he hadde; And that was ruthe, by seynt Chadde! ¶ Ther was gret Ioye & solace That euery a burgeis now hace Off that noble doghti quene And of hir Maydenes gode & kene. Thei lyued ere In sykyng sore And In gret mornyng wore, Thei make gret Ioye & melody That thei haue hir In company, On euery part In that Cite, When thei herde of hir pouste. For &yogh;it hope thei sche schal relesse Hem of that wo, and sitte In pece Thorow hir gret my&yogh;t & hir dede, Iff sche may leue & rightfully spede. ¶ Sche called styward and boteler, Sergaunt, coke, & hir sqwyer, And bad thei scholde her soper dyght, For it was wel with-Inne nyght. The bordes were layd, the clothes spred, And thei were set & richely fed. Than afftirward thei gon to rest, Eche bodi his clothes of-kest, And &yogh;ede to bedde & wele The first e altered from o . hem wrapped; When thei were layd, sone thei napped AL the ny&yogh;t, til it was morn. Than was blowen many an horn, Many an horn & many a beme,— Iff thei of Grece to hem toke &yogh;eme. Thei ride al forth with-oute the &yogh;atis, The quene by-fore rydyng algatis Opon a stede strong & store, With spere In hande & gilden spore. And thei of Grece be that were &yogh;are A&yogh;eyn Troyens for to fare, That thei se comande on a route MS. aroute . ; And not-for-thi thei were In doute To mete with hem an hundrid score For that day that was be-fore; But ther lay non other amende, But The capital B is altered from V by the same hand. nedes most thei here lyff defende. NOw thei mete with spere & scheld, Bothe parties In-mydde the feld By-twene the hales and the toun; Thei ride to-gedir with gret randoun, Euery man now hath of other envy; Ther was a carful company, When thei were to-gedre met: Echon other al to-bet, Sclow, & wounded, & thorow-bare; Non of hem wolde other spare. And thus ferde thei that neuere blonne Al that day, whil thei hadde sonne,— That thei most part fro that fyght For wantyng of that dayes lyght. ¶ And thus mette thei to-gedre efft Many a day or thei lefft, Til thei most the feld make clene Off men that were sclayn hem be-twene, And thei hem-selff so weri wore o altered from e . That thei myght fyght no more. Tho toke thei be-twene hem grithe To be In pes a two monethe, To reste her bones that were weri By assent of bothe parti. ¶ The trewes was take monethes two, That non of hem schal other mysdo Lastande the trewes a nedle worth: The relykes are y-broght forth, And thei are sworne & made ther othe, Thei schal hem hadde for leue or lothe. ¶ The Gregais alle toke consayl to wende, That thei wolde afftir Pirrus sende ¶ Hic Greci mandauerunt post Pirrum ffilium Achillis. To the kyng sir Lycomede, To help hem In that gret nede,— That was so tyff & strong In stoure. Agamenoun, here Emperoure, Bad than his brother Menelaus With his meygne wende afftir Pirrus; And he as sone wente to the see With his men & his naue, And sayled forth with mochel spede Vn-to that lord Lycomede. ¶ When he was comen In-to that hauen, He bad sqwyeres, &yogh;omen, & knauen Lede out here hors opon the sonde; And he lepe vp & rode to londe, With Lycomede til he was met: With curtais wordis he him gret And welcomed him with loueli chere, And sette hem doun to-gedir In-fere In his hye halle opon the dese. Then seyde the kyng Lycomedes: 'SIr kyng, to me welcome thow art! But me meruayles what [t]he has gart Come fro thi Grues thus fer to me? And what thow wole In this contre? What tydandes haue &yogh;e broght hidur? And what thow wol with the haue thidur? For wele I wot: with-oute skille Art thow not comen this lond tille.' ¶ Menelaus to him then sayde: 'Sir Licomede, so thow be payde! I schal the telle myn erande, whi That I come hedir sicurly: The kynges of Grece alle In-fere The gretes wele, as thow seis here, Bothe by mouthe & eke by letter, And sayn that it were moche better, Child Pirrus, that thow holdest here In vn-manhed & foule manere, To send to hem & to his kyn MS. And to hem & to his kyn. , And loos & worschipe to wyn, ¶ To venge his fader on his Enemys, When he were man of loos & pris; And be his fader fomen bane, The order of kny&yogh;t when he hadde tane, And not to ligge thus In scolcurye. Hit is, sir kyng, a vylonye To the, sir, and to him bothe, The kynges of Grece with the are wrothe; And thow him holdis as brid In cage, That he wynnes him no vasselage, But leses his time & his loos, And helpis hem not a&yogh;eyn here foos, As him by skyl au&yogh;t for to do. And thus bad thei me say the to.' LIcomede wex blo of blod, When he these wordes vndirstod; 'Off god'—sayde he—'I take witnesse, On no wise long on me non isse That he hath dwelled so longe fro &yogh;ow: For I wiste neuere whi ne how I myght him sende, ne by what man; Ne he him-selff the way ne can. ¶ But sithen the kynges for him haue sent, And thow thi-selff [art] here present, Child Pirrus, I the be-teche Thi fader deth to gete wreche. He[r] by the hand I the him bede, Ouer the see with the to lede ¶ Hic venit Pirrus ad Grecos. Vnto the lordis & kynges alle. I pray to god, that fair mot &yogh;ow falle.' MEnelaus when he herde that, He was Ioyful ther he sat; Him thoght his herte wel hesed, Whan he of him was feffed & sesed. He thoght no lenger ther to dwelle, He hadde no tale lenger to telle; He toke his leue at him to go To hem of Grece that he come fro. ¶ He bad god that made sonne & mone, Brynge hem thedir sound & sone; And thei to-gedir verament Vn-to the see thei ben y-went. When thei were comen to her schippis, Eche man afftir other In hippis; And drow vp Anker & her ropes, And caste on hem cloke & copes To saue hem fro the salt water, That it be-sprenged not her hater. ¶ Thei sayled bothe day & nyght With spede & haste that thei myght Ouer strem & ouer wawe, Vn-til thei stonde before hem sawe Off trusti Troye the hye walles, Here gaye toures, & her halles; On hem schon the sonne bem. Thei sayled forth ouer that strem, Til thei were come to here flote; Thei wente to londe tho by her bote, ¶ Thei leue her schippis & gon to londe And riden to-gedir hond In honde, Til thei come to here Pauylons Among the Grues and the Gryffons. AMong the Gregais Pirrus is lyght A fair man, hardi, & wyght; Many a lord Pirrus by-held, Whan he was broght to that teld: Thei were echon for him ful glad, Hem thoght that thei his fader had With hem a-&yogh;eyn, so was he lyche To his fader—by heuene ryche! ¶ Agamenoun, her Emperour, And alle the lordis did him honour, And did him worschepe ther he stode, And welcomed him with chere gode. The Murundones come to him than, And welcomed him, euery man; Ioyful & glad thei with him wore, That he hem was comen thore. ¶ Agamenoun as sone gan brynge Al his fader richesse & rynge: Pauelons, tentis, & his teldis, Stedis, speres, helmys, & scheldis, And al his gode fair Armure, And clothes of gold, fyne & pure, Off say, of silk, bothe red & grene,— And &yogh;aff hem Pirrus al be-dene. The morwe Afftir thei made him kny&yogh;t, Richely was he dubbed & dy&yogh;t. ¶ Ayax Thelamaneus Off hem was most glorious, He gyrd his sword aboute his swire And sayde to him: 'Pirrus, leue sire! I gird the with thi sword, take hede To venge thi fader as thow most nede. And moche Ioye haue thow of thin ordur of kny&yogh;t, As thi fader hadde that venged vs In fy&yogh;t.' Two lordes of Grece, princes, skete Set his spores on his fete, That were of gold, pure & ffyn. Then my&yogh;t men here a mechel dyn Off Trompes, pipes, & other glues Among the Gregais & the Grues. Gret was the murthe & the melody That ther was of Menstralcy; ¶ The Grues held gret feste & strong Many dayes afftir and long, And made gret Ioye & solace ce very small on erasure. In worschipe of him that newe kny&yogh;t was. PIrrus is knyght gode & gay, Off ffair porture, of gode aray, Off wel riche apparayle, Off gentil blod, of fair entayle; He prayes tho his Murundones That thei go sette here Pauylones, As thei were wont to stande The while his fader was lyuande. And thei on to-geder went And did her lordes comandement; And his tentis tho thei maked, Faste & sekirly thei hem staked In-to the erthe with lyne & cordes; And sette his tentis by other lordes. ¶ And whiles the trues last A-qwynted with the kny&yogh;tes fast, In fair manere & gode beryng He was a-qweynt with euery kyng, Er euere the trewes was fully ent; But it is ney verament, &YOGH;e that thei be-twene hem set The trewes to holde as thei be-het. THe trewes are past with-oute faile, And day is comen of here batayle: Thei buske hem faste & bowes bende, Vnto the fyght a&yogh;eyn to wende. Pirrus In his fader wede That vaunwarde that day he dos lede, ¶ He hath his batayle wel arayed Off men byfore offte assayed; He is wel dight & horsed als, His fader scheld aboute his hals And Achilles swerd also,— Many man to dethe ther-with was do,— ¶ His armes Are stronge & sicur. And he with that rides In-to that bicur, He passes forth ouer the dikes With his men that wel him likes, And takes the fel[d] brod & large Couered vndir helm MS. him . & targe. And euery a-nother kyng With alle her men In her ledyng, Knyght & sqwyer, erle & swayn, Rode & &yogh;ede vn-to that playn Ther thei were wont for to fyght, With thosandes sixti two & eyght. ¶ Ther was the duk Menescene With alle his men, & kyng Chelene, So was the kyng Menelaus, And Ayax Thelemaneus, Dux Nestor, & Vlixes, And the doghti Diomedes, Theseus kyng, & Thelamon, And the Emperour Agameon, Polinytes, & kyng Thoas: Tho rod thei forth on a pas, Euery a lord with his ost, Proudly pyght lest and most. ¶ And thei of Troye were comen out With-oute drede or any dout, Off here enemys hadde thei no drede. Bothe the parties to-gedur &yogh;ede, A wicked werre thei ther by-gan, Thei sclow ten thousand, er thei blan. NOw are thei to-gedir samen, Alle on ernest & not on gamen; Now are thei to-gedir broght, A woful day schal ther be wroght: The speremen ride, the bowemen schote, Thei fel faste ded at horses fote, The swordmen smyte & strokes &yogh;eue, Helmes breke, & scheldes cleue. ¶ Lordes & laddes lesen her lyues, Echon other rendis & ryues; A bitter bale haue thei be-gonne, Now this folk to-gedir is ronne. Ther were bowes al to-broken MS. alto broken. , Stedis stiked & thorow-stoken, Helmes holed, & heuedis houen, Knees & cropes with knyues clouen, Schonkes schyuered, schuldres schorne, Blodi burnes In bostis borne; With ferli fare tho freykes ferde, Off suche an hepe neuere I herde. ¶ Pirrus prikes aboute & praunses, Fro man to man aboute he launses Al his strengthe for to assay, He dud gret harm on hem that day; His fader Armes that day he bare. Off Palamides so was he ware A-&yogh;eyn the Gryffons fyghtyng faste, Grues & Gregais doun he caste. ¶ He turned his stede to him sone, He thoght on him to wynne his schone: He rode to him with so gret haste That al his spere In-sunder braste, That he fel doun opon the grounde And hadde a wel greuous wounde. His gode sword sone he drow, He wol him take if he mow, Or of his hand ther be sclayn; Ther-to putte he al his mayn. ¶ But that be-held kyng Philomene, He saw the fyght hem be-twene; He saw the kny&yogh;t Palamydes e seems to be altered to a . In gret perel of Pirrus was, For that newe kny&yogh;t Pirrus Was with him ful noyus, For he thoght him so mate & make, That he scholde scle him or take. But Philomene hit myght not thole: To Pirrus turned he his fole, And led with him al his meyne— Two thousandes kny&yogh;tes & hundres thre,— And put Pirrus fro his euel wille, That he ne scholde his falawe spille Ne that tyme him not dere, For no-thyng that he myght swere. PIrrus for-sothe hadde gret dispit That he fro him scholde be quyt, With Philomene was he wrothe: He leues that other and to him gothe, With tene of herte kepte he that kyng, And toke him thanne In suche a swyng That he bar him tayl ouer top, That he lay ther as a sop. ¶ Then my&yogh;t men here a wondir cry Off alle his men stode him by, For Pirrus wolde her lord haue, And thei wolde him fayn saue: Thei wol ther her lyues stende, But thei may here lord defende; Thei put hem certes In gret perel To saue her lord In that torpel. But al was not that thei coude do, For thei no-wyse myght come him to, For Murundones were so wode That thei her strengthe styffly with-stode. PAlidomas come thanne rennande, And al his ost with wepen in hande, To socoure & helpe kyng Philomene, As he did him In his gret tene; But he myght not ffor that he couthe, For al that he was kny&yogh;t In his &yogh;outhe, He myght not saue him fro her handis, That thei ne him toke & putte In bandis To lede him to Pirrus tent.
