But of her purpos were thei rent, For that louely lady fre Qwit him out of here pouste. ¶ The stour was fel & strong, The hilles of here strokes rong: Pantasalye come thedur than With many hardy kene womman, A sterne stede the quene be-strode, Among the Gregays that lady rode; Sche sclow & felde many & fele,— The sothe to say and not to hele. Hir armes were white as swannes flawe; The Grues hir dredde whan thei hir sawe, For sche on hem gret Angur did And sche to hem hir strengthe so kid. ¶ Thelamanyus Ayax was war That sche to grounde Gregais bar, In his herte hadde he gret Ire: He toke a spere & rode to hire And bar that ladi fro hur stede, Vn-warned or sche toke hede. But sche lepe vp as myghti quene, Hardi & bold, doghti & kene, Opon hir feet with-oute dwellyng, And swor that he schold that MS. bye that. fellyng In that day wel sore a-bye: Sche lete a stroke vpon him flye, ¶ Sche &yogh;aff him certis suche a pat That doun to grounde he fel flat; Sche toke hir hors & lepe vp tite— Maugre hir foos that stode be-syde— And rod hir thanne among the Grues And mechel bale amonges hem breues, Sche wroght hem wo In hir wode res, And many sche slees er sche hadde pes. PAntasalye hir stede by-strides, Among Gregais & Grues rides; Tydynges were that ladi tolde That sir Pirrus, that newe kny&yogh;t bolde, Hadde Philomene, that kyng, tan And swor that he MS. she. scholde be his ban. That bold mayden meved hir blod, When sche tho tydandes vndirstode; ¶ Sche vowes to god & alle his halowes: "He scholde not lede him ouer the ffalowes To tent ne Pauyloun that he hadde." Alle hir Maydenes than sche badde To folwe hir where sche &yogh;ede, And leue hir not for no nede. ¶ With-oute mo wordes went sche forth, With alle hir maydenes that mechel were worth, To Pirrus & to his Murundones That with the help of her Gryffones Hadde taken that kyng Philomene. Harde strokes gan sche hem lene, ¶ The Murundones sche sondres & schedes, And fele of hem sche maymes & hedes; Many a baly scho ther rittes And many a scheld sche al to-sclittes MS. alto sclittes. ; Many a kny&yogh;t les his entrayles. So harde the quene hem assayles. UHen Pirrus saw that mescheff— Sche felde his men at gret repreue, How thei were hurt and euel dyght, Wounded euele and discomfyght With that quene Pantasalye,— Opon his men be-gan he crye And sayde: 'men, for him &yogh;ow boght! What do &yogh;e? ne schame &yogh;e noght To dye so foule of feble thinges? A few wommen to dethe &yogh;ow brynges? ¶ But turnes a&yogh;eyn & folowes me, And thei schal sone discomfit be! Ther schal but fewe—so mote I thryue!— Off hem passe away on lyue!' He let thenne go kyng Philomene From him & hise qwite and clene With-oute ramsoun or any mede, For he myght him not thennes lede. PAntasalye herde his speche, On him sche thoght to take wreche: Sche drow toward him ner And seyde to him, that he myght her: 'Off thi proude wordes ne of thi sawe Ne of thi-selff I &yogh;eue not an hawe! By him that made al mydelerde! Off the am I not a-ferde, But now and euere I the dispise For thi fader cowardise, That he falsly sclow that knyght That passed al other In strengthe & myght, ¶ In doghtinesse & In valoure,— Off Chiualrie he was the floure,— The worthi kny&yogh;t Ector the gode! Alle the men of gentil blode Aught to venge his deth by skylle On the & alle that longeth the tille! And not only al gentil men, But we that are here wymmen Are comen to venge with oure myght The deth of that gentil knyght! ¶ For &yogh;it I hope that I & myne Schal venge his dethe on the & thine, For that fals traytour coward, thi sire! His soule mot brenne In helle fire!' At hir wordes Pirrus not smyled, When he herde him so reuyled: With-oute worde & mochel tene Rode sir Pirrus to the quene, To venge him if that he myght; And whan sche saw come that knyght, Sche slaked hir bridel & rayne And ran to him with al hir mayne, ¶ Hic Pirrus pugnauit cum Pantasalie Regina. And And , though the catch-word on lf. 248, bk. is Sche . kept that knyght In hir rennyng. In his grete tene and herte-brennyng ¶ Pirrus smot Pantasalye Opon the scheld so an hye, That al his spere In-sunder brast; But sche was not doun cast. But sche smot him wers than so, Sche brast hir spere on him In-two And bare him ouer the sadel y-wis, That he hadde leue the grounde to kys. But sicurli he ros vp sone, To venge that schame that sche had done Vn to him by-fore his folke, For tene his herte began to bolke: ¶ Stalworthe strokes sadde & sore Pirrus strok at hir thore, Thei made tho so gode pay That al her harneis was of blod ray; Al on blod was her harneis. But thenne come many proude Gregeis And partid hem sone a-twynne, And of her baret made hem blynne, And broght Pirrus a stede strong And horsed him hem among. PIrrus now & Pantasalie Bene partid with gret envie; Pan[ta]salye hir men relies, Philomene to hir he hyes And thanked hir of his lyueraunce, And prayes god: "&yogh;eue hir gode chaunce; For sicurly nadde sche bene, His lyff hadde ben lorn clene." ¶ Agamenoun, her Emperour, Come then doun vnto that stour, With Alle his men Diomedes; So did the duk of Athenes, And alle thes other kynges euerychone With bowe, alblaster, and flone. ¶ The quene with hir men asamed, With the Gregeis was sche gramed, And the gode kyng Philomenys Relyed a&yogh;eyn to hir al his; And then come thedir a gode pas Kyng Remus, & Eueas, To socour hem with her meyne. Sicurly then myght men se A wonder stour a-&yogh;eyn be-gynne, To se who scholde the felde wynne. ¶ When ayther of hem were so refresched, Echon on other dong & thresched, That thei fel doun as water fro yse; Many a worthi man of prise Be-twene hem tho her liff thei tynte, Off that assaut er thei wolde stynte. Pirrus rode among the Troiens, He bete doun of her Citesens And sclow right fele,—as Dares sais,— He halp wel that day Gregais. PIrrus rode to sir Glamicoun MS. . . . ou . . . son ; see note on p. 450. , A knyght that was Antenor sone MS. . . . ou . . . son ; see note on p. 450. , Palidomas was his half-brother, On lyue that tyme hadde he non other,— Off Another moder born; His lyff for-sothe has he lorn: For sir Pirrus In his wode layke, In his rydynge & In his rayke, With his sword smot he so sore, That he among hem died thore. ¶ Hic Pirrus occidit Glamiconem. ¶ Pantasalye by-fore hir eyne Saw Glamicoun die with pyne, Sche saw him die bothe blak & blo; For him sche was In herte wo, And for-fou&yogh;ten as sche was Sche come fro hir meygne a-pas And rod to him ouer-twert. And Pirrus it saw with Irus hert, And saw that quene to him ride As faste as sche my&yogh;t glide: He cau&yogh;te a spere—I the be-hete— Strong & styff, that quene to mete; ¶ He stroke his stede & mette the quene, And so did sche him, & that was sene! Ayther other so assayled, That neyther of other fayled; Thei mette so that bothe &yogh;ede doun Fro her hors opoun MS. perhaps opon . her croun. ¶ But sone & smert bothe vp ros, And ayther of hem to hors gos, And lepe vp with mochel spede; And eyther of hem to other &yogh;ede, And fau&yogh;t to-gedur harde & longe, Til thei were partid with that thronge. Or elles longe or it hadde be nyght, That on hadde be foule discomfight. POlidomas when he herde say His brother had mad his endyng-day, Wo was him whan he hit wiste: Among the Gregais he him thruste, He sclow & faste leyde to grounde, He &yogh;aff the Gregais many a wounde, And sclow hem doun as he were wood; Thei lay & sprauled In her blood. And the quene Pantasalye— Thorow hir many doth dye: So thorow here bothe myght MS. myghtes. The Gregais were sone discomfight MS. discomfightes. And fledde away & lefft her place, And thei hem folwed a long pace. ¶ But Diomedes, and sir Pirrus, And the doghti Thelamenyus, These thre thanne hur chase with-stode And thei no further bacward &yogh;ode, But turned a&yogh;eyn & lefft here fyght, For it was ner-hond the nyght: The sonne was went In-to the west, Hit was ney set & gon to rest Scribblings in the margin, but blotted and therefore indistinct. ; And thei departed with weri bones And &yogh;ede alle hom to her wones,— ¶ Some to tentis & some to toun,— Did of her Armes & set hem doun, Ete & drank and &yogh;ede to bedde, Whan thei were alle wel y-fedde,— And ros a-&yogh;eyn when thei myght se, For thei wol not lete it so be, Vn-to that on were vndirlyng, And that other lord & MS. α. kyng. NIght is went with his merke cloude, The waites blew, the Cokkes croude, The sonne is rysen & schynes bryght, And thei are vppe & redi dyght Vnto her note a&yogh;eyn to go, Ther thei the nyght be-fore come fro. Thei are horsed & Armed redi to fare, Thei are a&yogh;eyn to-gedir thare, Ther are thei to-gedir met; Iff any lefft In other det, Thei thenke hit schal be wel quyt. Thei fare as thei thei twice in MS. were out of wyt, ¶ So betis & lais echon on other Stalworth strokes as a ffother, Ryues, & rendes, and doun beres, Woundes, & slees, & al to-teres,— Fro morwe erly that thei hadde sonne Til it was nyght thei neuere blonne, And thus ferde thei with-outen les Many a day, er thei hadde pes. ¶ But by him that schope book & belle! Alle here dedis may I not telle, How thei fau&yogh;t to-geder euery day; Alle here dedis may I not say. For sicurly with-oute fayle— As was wreten of that batayle:— THei fau&yogh;t to-geder a ful foure woke That thei neuere reste ne toke, Day by day to lande & forow; And alle the fold MS. folk . thorow & thorow Lay sprad with dede bodies, As it hadde ben rattis or mys. For sicurly by-twene hem was sclayn With-Inne the dayes In that champayn ¶ —As Dares seis—thousandes ten Off men of Armes & doghti men, With-oute comune & other pedale,— That was wel mo with-oute fayle. And the quene Pantasalie Off hir Maydenes a gret partie Hadde tynt with-Inne a while & & is somewhat blotted. lorn, That lay ther ded al to-schorn. Viij & xx ti dayes plener Held thei the fight al entier MS. entrer . ¶ Hic ceperunt pacem inter e os ad sepelliendum corpora mortuorum. Day by day vpon the wold, That thei reste neuere—as I &yogh;ow told— Til al that place & al that feld, Ther the fyght [was] be-twene hem held, Was spred ful of dede bodies As thei myght ligge y-wis. And than was take another trewes Be-twix the Troyens & the Grwes, That thei my&yogh;t make clene the feld; That ligge so ded vndir her scheld, That thei with hem efft were not let, When thei were efft-sones y-met. THe trewes ar take & almost past, And sicurly these arn the last That euere schal Troyens or Grues take; For now schal thei an ende make; The next batayle schal be her ende; For than schal Troye to schame wende, And so schal alle the riche Troyens, For thei schal lese that hem mayntens. ¶ Schal neuere the kyng ne non of hise For al his noble & his vpprise A-&yogh;eyn Gregeis mayntene more stoure, For now lesen thei her mayntenoure And alle the gode that thei owe, And here houses brende on a lowe; And thei schal go to dethe vile, Euerychon with-Inne a while. ¶ But that schal be by fals tresoun; God &yogh;eue hem his malesoun That MS. And . the tresoun schope & wroght And that hit so aboute broght! That was Antenor & Eueas— God &yogh;eue hem an euel gras! Come thei neuere In heuene riche, That thei wolde so her lord be-swyke And al that gentil nacioun! Schal be put In-to dampnacioun! TErme is went out of the trewe, And that may men of Troye rewe: For if thei wiste what wolde be-tyde, Thei wolde not out of Troye ride. But now ben thei of Troye out-gon, Wel on horse is euerychone; ¶ In-to the feld are thei alle went, With scharp sword & bowe bent For to schete & smyte In haste; And thei of Grece ben comyng faste. Ful wel are thei now batayled, And echon other faste assayled With swordes & speres scharpe; Off alle her dedis may I not carpe. ¶ But Pirrus saw Pantasaly; Be-twene hem two was gret envy: He rode to hir, & sche to him, Ayther was on other brym; Pirrus smot that ladi so, That he to-barst his spere In-two And thrilled thorow-out hir scheld. But that quene hir sadel held That sche fel not with his smytyng, But sche smot him with-oute flytyng And &yogh;aff him on vn-to his mede, That hir spere In-sunder &yogh;ede; But he fel not ther-with to grounde, But sche &yogh;aff him an hidous wounde That of hir spere a gret parti Lefft stone-stille In his bodi. ¶ Hic Pirrus occidit Pantasaliam Reginam. PIrrus is smeten & euel dyght, His blod ran out with mochel myght; For him was made a gret cry Off alle the Grues that were him by; For thei were alle In mochel doute How the spere-hed scholde gon oute With-oute lesyng of his lyff. Then be-gan a delful stryff To hem of Troye ther thei stode: For alle the Grues were ney wode That sche smot him so greuously; Thei cried on hir dispitously, ¶ Thei vowed to god thei scholde hir sclo. Many a Grewe & Gregais tho &YOGH;ede aboute that dou&yogh;ti quene And did hir mochel wo & tene, Thei brak hir helm & hir hauberk And made al blod hir white scherk, Thei brast on-sonder many a mayle, The stalworthe lace of hir ventayle, Sicurly In-to her hare Thei maken hir hed naked & bare. ¶ When Pirrus saw hir hed al naked, In his body thoow he were staked With his spere-hede, to hir he soght As he of his lyff not roght; Off lyff ne deth &yogh;aff he no tale, But that he my&yogh;t brewe hir bale When he saw hir In suche a poynt: He smot hir euene In the Ioynt Be-twene the sholder & the scheld, That hir lefft arme fflow In the feld, And sche fel ded & stille lay Among hir horses as clot of MS. In. clay; And Pirrus In his greuaunce Toke on hir a foule vengaunce, For he lefft not of hir a spot That he ne hit hewe as flesch to pot. And he him-selff wex than so wan For blod that out of his wounde ran, That he amonges hem fel ther doun Fro his hors In a dede swoun; ¶ But his gode men MS. godemen. lyff[t] him on loffte And on his scheld laide him soffte And bare him hom to his tentis, And did of alle his garnementis And laide him faire vpon his bed, For he was feble and al by-bled. PAntasalie is ded & sclayn, And thei of Grece are ther-of ffayn; But hir maydenes haue sorwe y-now, Many a Grewe that tyme thei sclow. Thei were so for the quene en-yred, To dye ther thei desired: Troyens thanne & tho wymmen Sclow two thousand doghti men. ¶ But what myght that a-vayle, Whil ther were &yogh;it with-oute fayle Thre hundrid thousand of Gregais knyghtes, Off bold men & stronge In fyghtes, And of sqwyers gret multitude? And &yogh;aff thanne strokes wel vnrude, And sclow the Troyens as thei were wode, That men myght haue bathed In here blode: ¶ Dares seith "thei sclow that tyde Ten thousand men of Troians Troians by another hand on erasure. syde." Wherfore alle that myght ffle Fled away to hir Cite And spered the &yogh;ates wel and faste With many a spire that wel wolde laste, With lokke & keye, haspe & pyn; And held hem alle the toun with-In, For of the Gregais hadde thei suche doute That thei wolde no more passe oute: ¶ The Troyens wol no more out-wende, For now is broght the fight to ende; Thei &yogh;eue no tent to no-thyng elles— Non that In the toun dwelles— But her walles for to wayte, That thei with-oute with no dissayte, With no qwayntise MS. qwanytise. , ne with no wile By day ne ny&yogh;t hem t[h]o by-gyle. For thei are sicur y-now & traist, That thei ne thar no-thyng be a-baist; For thei wot wel thei are so hye, That no-thyng In erthe but foule that flye May come hem to, for out thei do ey&yogh;t, But if it were with tresoun or sle&yogh;t. THe waytes is set, the toun kept, That thei wele & sicurly slept. But thei of Grece haue hem be-cast With the sege wele & faste On euery a side ouer-al aboute, That thei may not for hem come oute. But ther-of haue thei no drede, But if thei haue of vitayles nede; ¶ For thei may leue & wele fare With-Inne the toun for euer-mare, But it be so that hem fayle Corn, or wyn, or other vytayle. The Troyens make gret del echone, Gret mornyng, & mochel mone; Alle that euere to Troye out long Maken gret dele and sorwe strong,— ¶ Kyng & kny&yogh;t,—whan thei hem thenche Off that worthi doughti wenche, That noble quene Pantasalie, That hem defended so nobly. The sorwe is gret that thei alle make For hir dethe & for hir sake, That thei may not hir bodi haue— As hem wel au&yogh;t—In erthe to graue. ¶ The Gregais wol not hir bodi grauen, But let hit ligge to roke & rauen; But sir Pirrus with that seyde: 'nay! Hit is no skyl'—he sayde—'parfay! That so dou&yogh;ti a body as sche A-bouen erthe vn-grauen be, Ne be with best ne foule y-schent! But fair be layd In monument!' ¶ But Diomedes verament With-sayde sir Pirrus Iugement, He seyde for-sothe "that hir bodi To ligge In erthe is not worthi." But ther-to come it at the laste That In a lake that quene was caste, For thei seyde "thei wolde hir not brynge To sepulcre ne to bureyng." PAntasalye liggis In a pole; The Troyens make moche dole MS. dele , but the first e seems to be corrected to o. , Thei make sorwe that sche is ded; For now are thei with-outen red, Thei haue no hope to no MS. to no so. socour; With-Inne the toun make thei soiour, For thei se wel: hem is no bote A-&yogh;eyn Gregays more to mote. Anchises, that waried wyght, That Ancien MS. Amicien ; cf. l. 17838. schrewe, that olde knyght,— And his sone, fals Eueas,— And Antenor—thes thre, alas!— And his sone Palidamas— These foure be-gan the compas: How thei myght best saue her lyues And alle her godis & here wyues: ¶ Thei toke amonges hem many consayle, What myght best to hem a-vayle? But at the laste, thus thei ent, That thei were alle at this assent: "That if thei were dryuen ther-to That thei myght no more do, Thei scholde the kyng & his be-swyke, To saue hem foure and that hem lyke, Alle here kynrede & here frende,— And Priamus & his to schende." ¶ So sayde thei be-twene hem thore: To consayle the kyng that it gode wore A fynal pees of Grues to craue, For so myght he his lyff saue; And that he wolde take a-&yogh;eyn To Menelaus the quene Eleyn, And make amendes of that Paris Hadde done to hem & heris amys, And do restore that he & hise Hadde born fro hem In any wyse. ¶ But who myght leue that any lord Off hem of Grece that wold acord? To graunte the pees to hem so sone Afftir the harm that thei hadde done, And greued hem sore & offte anoyed, And so fele lordes of hem distroyed; ¶ Qualiter Priamus & omnes alij. Troiani decepti fuerunt. And thei haue hope the toun to wynne, And alle the godis that ben ther-Inne; For In the toun so bold none was, With-oute the &yogh;ates that durst pas. But sicurly ther myght men se That it my&yogh;t not but tresoun be, Openly & discouert, And it was tresoun ri&yogh;t apert. But thei myght speke of a pees, Thei myght not elles speke with Gregais, For to telle hem of here wille, How the toun wolde thei tresoun & spille. THese traytoures that this toun wol traye, Thei are went her erande to saye To the kyng In the sale: Boldely thei telle bothe her tale Be-fore the kyng & lordes fele; But her tresoun thei wol slely hele, Thei wil not telle what thei thenke— The deuel hem mot In helle senke! ¶ When Priamus saw of pees thei touched, Off here wordes no gode he souched: Him thoght it was no gode tokenyng That thei of pes made procuryng Afftir the harm that he hadde tan Off hem that were his sones ban, Him thoght it souned to no gode That thei of pees hadde turned her mode; ¶ He saw right wele here two assent, To traye the toun that thei haue ment, And not-for-thi he held him stille And lete him speke & say here wille, For he wolde not lette hem perceyue That he saw thei wolde him disceyue. ¶ Hic Antenor & Eueas loquitur de pace In decepcione Regis. He spak to hem & seide: 'lordynges! I wil a-vise me of thes thynges; I wol not &yogh;eue her-of Iugement With-oute consayl & avisement.' ¶ Fals Eueas scornfulli be-gan Vn-to the kyng speke than, He seyde: 'and thow wol consayle take, I rede that thow oures not for-sake. If the hit like, the ne thar non other; Iff thow dost not, thow may take other.' ¶ The kyng answered with wordes meke·: 'Lordynges!'—he sais—'I &yogh;ow be-seke That with my wordes &yogh;e wrathe &yogh;ow not! For &yogh;e wot wele—by him vs bou&yogh;t!— That I haue done &yogh;oure consayl here, In al my lyff I wayved hit neuere. And &yogh;e say now: "I holde it gode." But if it were I vndirstode A-nother were more vn-to oure prow, Me thenke it scholde not greue &yogh;ow Thoow I lefft &yogh;oure & let it be, And toke that wolde helpe &yogh;ow & me.' ANtenor ros fro the des And seide: 'sir kyng! to speke of pes It is not euel—I vndirstonde,— But good to &yogh;ow and alle &yogh;oure londe; For &yogh;e wot wel what noye & care That &yogh;e & &yogh;oures now Inne are: ¶ Be-fore &yogh;oure &yogh;atis ligge ffyffty kynges That wil not parte for no thynges, Til thei may this toun ouer-throwe And alle the houses sette on a lowe, And sle, sir kyng, &yogh;ow & &yogh;oure And vs also and alle oure. Ne &yogh;e may not with-stonde her my&yogh;t, Ne &yogh;e dar not with hem fy&yogh;t, And &yogh;e ar now of nom-power, Ne vs comes no help fer ne ner. ¶ For-whi I say: better hit is Off two harmes to chose the les: Better is vs & &yogh;ow also That &yogh;e sende the Gregais to, To loke if thei wil graunt &yogh;ow grith Off a ffynal pes, lyff and lyth;— And &yogh;eue a-&yogh;eyn Eleyne, the quene, For wham fele lordis haue ded bene;— And alle the godis a-&yogh;eyn restore— And, if thei wil, &yogh;et somdel more,— That Paris In his robbery Toke fro hem In Thesaly.' AMphimacus to speke hadde haste, On of the kynges sones a-baste; He ros vp thanne with teneful herte And seide to him wordes smerte, Herynge alle that that twice in MS. set on benche: 'Thi wyles ben wicked, so ben thi wrenche!' He seide: 'gode men MS. godemen . , opon my treuthe! Thow art fals, and that is reuthe! Thi herte is turned, & so it semes, That thi kyng & vs thus demes! In the for-sothe is now no trayst, When thow these wordes vn-to vs sayst! ¶ For thi kyng scholde thow suffre mescheff, Er thow saw him falle In any repreff, And thow now procurest him vylonye! Erst scholdestow with him die! Wele may men se: thi herte is chaunged! For we are not &yogh;it so mys-kannged, That er schal twenti thousand men Die ther-to and thousandes ten.' Ful wylusly he him with-sayde, For he was no-thyng with him payde. ¶ But Eueas thanne his wordes pesed, With faire wordes his herte he sesed; He MS. Thei . seyde vnto him at the laste: 'The Gregeis haue vs vmbe-caste, That we dar no more fyght with hem, Ne open oure &yogh;ates for drede of hem; A-nother way—if we be sly— By-houes vs seke to haue vs by, And sicurly it is non other Then bye the pes, my leue brother!' FOr alle the good of hethen Spayne Myght the kyng him [not] refrayne, He was so ful of care & wo; Vnto the traytoures seide he tho: 'Certes'—he seyde—'&yogh;e are to blame! &YOGH;e were worthi to suffre schame! In &yogh;oure herte how myght &yogh;e ffynde A-&yogh;eyn me now to be vnkynde? In my gret elde to waxe vn-trewe That euere &yogh;it haue ben me drewe? ¶ And nother of &yogh;ow may certes say That I did neuere be nyght ne day Any-thyng a-&yogh;eyn Gregays In tyme of werre ne of pays That harmed hem an heryng-tayle, That it ne was by &yogh;oure consayle. And thow, Eueas, was cheff consaylour To Paris, my sone, In his labour To rawische Heleyne & lede hir away; Thow may not say ther-of "nay": Ne hadde, Eueas, thi conseyl bene, Eleyne ne hadde this toun sene. And now afftir my sones ded I se &yogh;ow two at otheres red To consail me, to lese my name And falle for euere In foule schame, That I scholde now me meke The Gregais mercy to be-seke That haue alle my sones sclayn And done me wo & mechel payn; And &yogh;it scholde I hem merci crye And pes & loue of hem bye Order in MS., 17418, 17417. ? ¶ Hit were a schame to alle my kynde That I scholde me to hem bynde,— So haue I of my bodi hele! This consayl is nother good ne lele, But waried worthe the tonge it tolde! For I drede we ben alle solde, For we ben lorn maugre oure tethe, Ryght noght it is—& that we sethe.' ¶ Eueas thanne was wonder wrothe, He ros vp & thenne gothe; He was Angred with that sawe, Off his kyng stode him none awe. Wordes fele of gret outrage,— Herande alle the baronage,— SPake he thanne vn-to the kyng, That were veleyns wordes & vn-sittyng. He gos hamward vnto his halle With-oute leue of hem alle, He wolde no leue at hem nym. But Antenor &yogh;ede home with hym; Thei are bothe hom to-gedur went. By him that made bothe Twede & Trent! ¶ Hic Priamus flebat. Iff the kyng hadde wist here consayl, It hadde ben to hem to wrother-hayl! PRyamus ryses and sore wepis That al his brest the water wetis, For he parseyued apertly That his deth for-sothe is ney; The kynges herte ful sore tendres. The kyng thanne sone sendes Afftir his soone Amphimacus, And seis ful rewfully to him thus, Sore wepyng and bitterly: 'I am thi fader, sone, witterly; We are bothe of on blod & flesche, Holde we to-gedur for hard or nesche! ¶ Lete vs with-stonde whil that we may The two traitoures, sone, I the pray! I se thei haue to-gedir spoken That thei my&yogh;t on vs be wroken; Thei thenke the Grues schal sle me And to haue this riche Cite. I wolde fayn do bote ther-In, Iff that I myght with any gyn: ¶ To-morwe next I wol thow be With priue folk of oure meygne Armed wele, when &yogh;e haue dyne; That no man wite of &yogh;oure couyne, Vn-til we haue al fully ent Oure consayl & oure parlement. And whan it is comen to euen-tyde That thei bothe schal hamwardis ride, I wol that thow & thine out-wende And bothe the traytours al to-rende.' ¶ Amphimacus seide: "it scholde be done, By him that made bothe sonne & mone!" But al this myght not hem a-vayle: I wot neuere how that here consayle Was told [anon] to Eueas, That he scholde dye for his trespas That he hadde wratthed that day the kyng And Antenor with his spekyng. ENeas N altered from U by another hand. thanne was wroth y-now: To alle his goddis he made a vow That he wolde on him be wreke, Iff that he my&yogh;t go or speke. He sente as sone his messager Afftir Antenor, his comper; And he come sone at his sonde And him al redi ther he fonde. Eneas n by another hand on erasure. told him tydande Off the kyng & his couenande, And "how he wolde sle hem bothe, So was he to hem wrothe." ¶ Thes two to-gedir swere: "That thei scholde fight to-geder there, The toun to traye and tho ther-In, And do sle hem & alle her kyn; Thei schal not lette for leue ne lothe." And ther-to haue thei sworn her othe:— 'And if so to-morwe to by another hand on erasure. it it inserted by another hand over line. be-tide Þat And crossed out at this place in the MS., þ t inserted by another hand in the margin. he wol vs at home abide, We schal come on suche parayle That if he thenke vs assayle, ¶ Off his purpos schal he be rent: He schal not do as he hath ment. I &yogh;eue right not of alle his tene, Not the value of a bene; For I wot wele: we schal be war Off him, er we come thar.' ERly on morwe whan it was tyme— I trowe a litel afftir the Prime— Priamus kyng sent his message To alle the lordes of his vilage, To Antenor & Eueas, And bad hem come an hasti pas To Ylion vn-to that kyng, That thei ne made no dwellyng; ¶ And thei bad hem a&yogh;eyn gone, For thei wolde come a-none. Thei armed hem at alle rightes And toke with hem noble knyghtes, And come for-sothe to the palais, Armed wel In her harneis. The kyng of hem was sore affrayed, For he saw thanne he was be-wrayed; The kyng thanne to his sone gos And biddis him lette of his purpos, He seyde: 'sone, leue this thyng! We ben be-wreyed—by heuene kyng!' ¶ When these lordes were comen alle, Thei sette hem doun In that halle, And thei be-gan to-geder trete. Eueas wolde his wil not lete, He stode vp thanne & boldely spak To hem of Troye, & bad hem mak Be-twene hem of Grece—iff thei moste e inserted later, but by the same hand. — A fynal pes, what-so it coste;— ¶ 'But &yogh;e done, &yogh;e bene alle lorn For defaute of wyn & corn; &YOGH;oure vitayles may not longe laste That ne som-tyme thei wil be paste, Then schal &yogh;e be wel euel at ayse MS. atayse. And dye afftir that gret myssayse. ¶ Therfore lettes for no man To make a pees—if &yogh;e can,— And come at one sone with the Grues!' But Priamus that saiyng refuces, He him with-sais In fair manere; But ther was non that wold him here, Thei seyde echon: "thei vndirstode The pees ffor hem was fair & gode At suche a plyght as thei were at." And thus sayde alle that ther sat; ¶ Saue Priamus with-seide it ay, For he was ferd thei wolde him tray. But Eueas In his wickednesse Seide to him In gret felnesse: 'Wherto, sir kyng, makestow it so? Wenes thow oure wille for-do By thi Powere & thi maystrie? Wil thow, nele thow—the pees schal be!' PRyamus tho held him stille, For he most nede suffre her wille; He seyde: 'lordynges, now &yogh;e it say That it is gode the Grues to pray That thei wol graunte vs, for of oure, A fynal pees to here honoure,— Sithen &yogh;e it say, I wol also A&yogh;eyn my wille—so haue I ro! For I am ferd hit schal vs rewe A pees to praye of any Grewe!' The Troyens then Antenor chese To do her erande to gete hem pese, Off a fynal pes if thei myght spede For siluer, gold, or any mede. THei &yogh;ede with braunches of Olyue-tre Opon the walles, that thei my&yogh;t se, ¶ Hic miserunt nuncios ad Grecos. In tokene of pees & saue condit. Whan thei of Grece hadde sen that sight, The same tokene made thei a-&yogh;eyn. The Troyens ther-of were ful fayn, Thei lete Antenor a-non doun By the wal out of the toun; And whan he was on grounde set, He &yogh;ede to Grues with-oute let. Whan he was comen to here hales, Her Emperour told he his tales: "How he was comen fro her kyng To make by-twene hem sau&yogh;tlyng." ¶ The Emperour sente afftir other kynges, To here the sothe of these tydynges; When thei were alle to-gedere thore, He saide "that thre men, if it wore, That wolde be trewe & trusti frende, To brynge this thyng to an ende." Thei chose thre men tho for hem alle: "That what-so-euere scholde ther-of be-falle, Thei scholde holde her ordinaunce With tresoun or with disceyuaunce" ¶ And ther made made twice in MS., the second one crossed out. thei alle her othes By boke & belle & holy clothes That longed to her sacrament: "Thei scholde holde her surment." THat one of hem was kyng of Grete, The Gregais all by him wel lete; That other was Diomedes, The thridde of hem was Vlixes. These thre the Gregais for hem toke That what-soeuere thei wolde loke, Thei wolde holde ferme & stable With-oute dissayte or any fable. ¶ Consilium inter Antenorem. & Reges Grecorum. ¶ Thei asked him: "what was the thynges That he to hem tydandes brynges?" He seyde: 'lordynges, I wol &yogh;ow telle: My thinges that I wol &yogh;ow of melle, I wolde that no man here but I And &yogh;e thre kynges witterly That chosen were of euery lord, To loke if we foure may a-cord. ¶ For if I tolde hit al on hye That men my&yogh;t here it openlye, Hit my&yogh;t be wist In other place, And I be schent ther-by by cace And lese my trauayle & lese my way And gete me harm ther-by parfay. I wol therfore that &yogh;e thre Come here by-syde and speke with me, That this thing may be priuay, Iff that it be vnto &yogh;oure pay.' THese thre kynges And Antenore Fro the ffolk thei &yogh;ede a-fore; Antenor thanne, that lyther schrewe, Be-gan his falshede to hem schewe: He tolde hem of his tresoun That he wolde do In schort sesoun, "How he wolde by-traye the toun And putte it al In her bandoun. . . . Thus mechel to say to this couenande, That thei alle thre holde vp her hande And swere by him In heuene was: 'Thei scholde saue him & Eueas, And alle her godis & her houses, Here kynrede & al here spouses, And her frendes that thei wolde chese That thei of of inserted over line. heres scholde not lese."' ¶ The sothe to say the kynges were glad, Whan thei of him this tydandes had That thei the toun so sone myght wynne And haue the godis that were ther-Inne, Kyng, & quene, and al his fe. The kynges swore all thre By him that made bothe erthe & heuene: "Thei scholde hem saue, thoow ther were suche seuene"; And ther-to her trewthes thei plyght. And he hem treuly be-hight That he wolde couenande holde To be-traye Troye, that Cite bolde, For-whi that thei [hit] holde priue, That non it wiste but thei & he. NOw hath this traytour be-trayed Troye,— These kynges maken moche Ioye,— For him & Eueas it is solde. God wolde it were the burgeis tolde! For he wolde his tresoun hide: He bad a kyng scholde with him ride In-to the toun out of the feld, Taltibeus, a kyng of eld; And that thei myght credence of him &yogh;eue And the more him leue. ¶ He asked eke for curtesye &YOGH;eue him the quene Pantasalye, That thei myght that cors entere. But that with-sayde alle that were there, For thei hir hated In certayn; For afftir thei graunted [hit] with MS. with him. payn. ¶ He toke his leue & went his way, And Taltibyus with him parfay; And thei of Troye opened the &yogh;atis, And thei rode In ful faire al-gatis And sente the kyng word of her come, And rod forth vn-to him home. THe morwe afftir the kyng did sende Afftir his burgeis gode & hende, Alle that euere were In the toun. When thei were come, thei sete doun; He bad Antenor by his Omage: "How he hadde sped In his message, That he scholde ther sey sey inserted by another hand over line. In presence And In here alther Audience." ¶ The fals traytour—the deuel him cheke!— To hem gan he sclely speke, He schewed to hem but flaterye, For he wolde hele his traytourie, But tolde a prologe mochel & long; He seide: 'gode men, the Grues are strong, Off gret power and wasselage, Off curtesie & gret parage Off kynges & lordes & of her men lege, Longe y-now to holde the sege, Hardy y-now to fyght & bekir, Knyghtes trewe & wondir sekir. ¶ By-holdes now a-boute & loke: Thei breke neuere trewes that euere thei toke; And we are so dryuen to noght, Al to wrecches we are broght, To care & wo & mochel sorwe, Night & day, euen & morwe. Wherfore, gode men, hit were wisdam That &yogh;e consayl amonges &yogh;ow nam: By what way that &yogh;oure wayment Might come to ende & best be ent? ¶ But therto certis schal &yogh;e not come With-oute tresor a gret somme: I rede euery man bothe more & lesse That is of my&yogh;t and of richesse, And specially vnto oure kyng, That he be helpande vn-to this thyng; For we no-wyse In pes may be. With-oute tresor gret quantite. For better is vs oure gode for-go Thanne euere to leue In noye & wo!' Lo! how slely he hem blente With his sleyght & his Argument! ¶ Then did the traytour more quayntise, For he wolde In no wyse His ffals tresoun that thei perceyue, And for he wolde hem clene disceyue; He sayde also In that throwe: 'The Gregais wil may I not knowe; I rede that Eueas with me wende To brynge this thyng better to ende.' ¶ The Troyens alle his sawe alowed, Thei seyde: "he scholde be wele aprowed By Eueas u might be n ; cf. note to l. 17489. —so haue thei reste!;— That he with &yogh;ede that was beste." Wherfore thei Iugged euerychone That thei two to Grues scholde gone. THei haue now done her parlement, And alle the lordes ben ben inserted over line by the same hand, hom crossed out before it, and repeated behind it. hom went, Priamus, the Troyane kyng, In-to his Chambre goth wepyng, He scrat his hede & tare his heer, Out of his eyen fel many a teer; He saw wele here sotilnesse, Here ffalshede, & her lithernesse, He cursed that tyme that he was born, So doghty sones as he hadde lorn! "And now to leue of her batayle, Most he &yogh;eue al his catayle That he hadde geten by olde dayes! And ende his lyff In gret affrayes";— 'Wolde god I were now certayn To haue my lyff & be not sclayn! &YOGH;et wolde I thanne haue some Ioye. But er y trowe the toun of Troye Schal be by-traied & go to pyne, And I schal dye & alle myne.' ANtenor and fals Eueas u might be n ; cf. note to 17489. — Se thei neuere god In the fas!— Thei are bothe went to hem of Grece, To saue her bodyes & here fece, And priueli to traye the toun, To brenne Ylioun & caste it doun. When thei hadde spoken a ful gode while How thei myght Troyens best by-gyle, ¶ The Gregais bad "that Vlixes And his felawe Diomedes With Antenor and his comperes To Troye scholde wende alle In-feres, To wite of hem what thei wolde &yogh;eue That thei scholde hem no lenger greue, And for to telle hem what thei craue Iff thei scholde hem let pes haue." Thei &yogh;ede alle forth here way snel To the toun with-oute dwel; ¶ To Priamus when thei were comen, He did his men as sone somen Bidde his lordis & his burgeis, To-morwe to come to his paleis. When thei were comen & al doun MS. aldoun. set And thei were alle to-gedir y-met, Vlixes stode & tolde his erande: 'This thyng may not be wernade; Iff &yogh;e wil haue the sau&yogh;tlyng, &YOGH;e most graunte her askyng.' ¶ He saide: 'the Grues asken thynges two: That on is that &yogh;e most do Out of this toun & this Ile Amphimacus vntil exile, That he come neuere a-&yogh;eyn on lyue';— And this the Troyens graunte blyue;— ¶ 'That other is that &yogh;e do fet— For to &yogh;eue hem to here profet— Off gold & corn so gret porcioun Vnto here a[l]ther reffeccioun, That euery a man haue so gode store To haue y-now for euere more.' GRet meruayle among hem alle In his spekyng fel In that halle: A wonder noyse amonges hem thore Was tho y-herd of hem that wore. What that my&yogh;t be thei were ameruayled; The kynges wende men hadde hem assayled; Some men wende the noyce thei herde Hadde ben the kynges childres so ferde For her brother Amphimacus, For her MS. his. fadir Priamus And for her MS. his. brother schulde be exiled, With Antenor that so was be-gyled. ¶ Eche man loked what hit was, But ther was non In al that plas Ne in that hye Cite That coude wete what it my&yogh;t be, Ne whethen that it come, ne how. Eueryche a lord hamward hem drow, ¶ Hic Antenor narrauit Regibus Grecorum de reliqu[i]o Palladij. And ent here consayl tho alle sone, And went home when thei hadde done. ANtenor him hamward spedde, The kynges two with him ledde In-to a wondir priue place, Ther thei to speke hadde good space. ¶ To Antenor seyde Vlixes That sat by him vpon the des: 'I haue meruayle whi thow delayes These thynges for vs so many dayes, That thow ne brynges hit to no purpos. Loke that thow vs no-thyng glos And brynge vs slely In a bek, For thow brynges hit to non affek.' ¶ Antenor swor & sayde "nay, Bothe he & Eueas ny&yogh;t and day, So helpe him god"—'we were ther-aboute';— "But on MS. no. thing broght hem In doute";— 'I wol &yogh;ow telle, what thing hit is That bryngis vs In gret gastnes: ¶ The sothe is this: that kyng Ylus,— As oure bokes telles vs,— A worthi kny&yogh;t, a kyng Troyen, Off long tyme and Ancien MS. Amycien ; cf. l. 17238. , That Ilyon did sette & dyght— And Ilyon afftir him hit hight,— — With-Inne this toun this kyng did make For her goddis Pallus sake A riche temple, fair & long, Brod & wide & wonder strong. ¶ When it was made al, aboute the roue That scholde be set the temple aboue A wonder thing out of the sky Off goddis grace fel fro an hy, That did the harde wow cleue MS. clene. & bende Ryght at the hye-auter ende; And In the wow him-selff hit sette, As faste as hit were &yogh;ette With sement or with any glewe, That no man may hit thenne remewe The second e altered to o in MS. Saue the prestes that hit kepe, Be thei wakyng or a-slepe,— And thei hit kepe & al day MS. alday. se. Men say that hit is most of tre, ¶ But "what tre" can no man knowe Off alle the kernes MS. kerues. that it owe, Ne what forme, ne what hewe; But hit is thyng of suche vertue: The while hit is the toun with-Inne, May non the toun with tresoun wynne. ¶ Palladin that thing called is Afftir Pallas—the sothe hit is;— Fro hir It come also, I wene. Now haue I told &yogh;ow al be dene— So helpe me god & my long way! That maketh al oure let & oure delay.' DIomedes thanne answered: 'Sithen we ther-with so moche are dered MS. dared. That hit one the toun may saue, That we ne may by no way haue For no thyng that may be-falle, The while hit is with-Inne the walle— ¶ Then thenkes me, sir, witterly, That we do alle a gret foly That we do noght with-oute fayle, But lese oure speche & oure trauayle.' Antenor seyde: 'by heuene kyng! Iff &yogh;e haue wonder of oure tarying, This is the cause & the resoun And alle the verray enchesoun, That &yogh;e & we are thus delayed. But al this while haue I assayed, And offte haue I be-soght the prest That kepis this thyng & hit is next, And haue by-het him gret tresour To haue certis for his labour— ¶ And so haue I the prest be-soght, That In certayn haue I him broght That he som nyght schal go with me For gret tresor & mychel fe, And then schal I sende to &yogh;ow And ende this thing to &yogh;oure prow.' And thanne thei partid & toke her leue; That god him &yogh;eue an euel preue! NOw haue thei lefft alle her tales, And the kynges gon to her sales. And Antenor anon he wente To Priamus that he hadde blente; He bad him anon sende vp & doun To alle the burgeis of the toun That were with-Inne the Cite &yogh;atis, That thei scholde come to him al-gatis. ¶ And whan thei herde of this tydandes, Is non that lenger sittis ne standes, That thei ne &yogh;ede alle or rode To his Palais with-oute abode: When thei were comen & set on rowe, Echon by other—as hem owe,— Antenor ros & seyde: 'lordyngis! I wol telle &yogh;ow of oure spekyngis, What the Grues & I haue spokyn, What thei wol haue, or elles be wroken. This is the somme that Gregays aske, That thei wole haue vnto her taske: Ten hundrid thousand pound of golde;— Ther is no man is maked of molde That may ther-of vs alegge, For thei wol not ther-of abregge;— And as moche of siluer bryghte e added afterwards. &YOGH;e mot hem &yogh;eue with-oute respite; An hundrid charge also of whete. And tho bad thei me with hem trete, ¶ For sicurly thei wol no lasse. Therfore, gode men MS. godemen. , if [be] &yogh;oure ese To haue the lyff & fle the ded, Than is this forsothe my red: That &yogh;e &yogh;eue hem this two her wage And let go caste a taylage A-mong the riche & the pore,— To pese her wratthe for euere more,— And gadir hit faste on gret hepis, For thei wol haue shippes &yogh;epis.' NOw is the taylage cast & layde, That somme was sone y-puruayde, The while it was In gaderyng. Antenor, that lyther thyng, Spake to the prest of the lawe That what with &yogh;efftis & with awe, What for drede, what for mede, That he the prest so ouer &yogh;ede, That he bad him at euen come, And he scholde haue Palladone. ¶ Antenor come thenne on a nyght, And that prest, that wicked wyght, &YOGH;aff him that relike that was so riche,— In al Assye was ther non liche; And he sende it to Vlixes, And to his felawe Diomedes. The Troyens gadered the gold & corn Erly at euen and on morn; Thei leyde that good & that fee In the temple of Menerue. ¶ Then seyde the riche Citesenes And alle these other pore Troyenes, That thei wolde make a sacrifice To her godis of gret aprice, To thanke hem of grace that thei sende That her batayle is thus at ende. THei broght tho many boles & bores, With lowyng & with loude rores; But ther be-tydde tho two miracles That were to hem gret obstacles: When be-fore the Auteres were layd the bestis,— As was that tyme that lawe hestis— That were doun come thedir, & renne To sette In fir, and do hit brenne, Thei did brynge the kiddis drye— For hit scholde brenne clere & hye,— And colis also In bollis & wyndel: Thei myght no fir make ther-on kyndel, For noght that thei coude blowe Not ones sette hit on a lowe. ¶ The Troyens were tho vn-blythe, Thei tende hire fir more than ten sithe, But it &yogh;ede out by on & on, That sacrifice myght thei make non. ¶ That other wonder, gode men, y-wis That hem be-fel that tyme, was this: Ther come fleynge that tyme an Erne Vn-to the temple, fleande sterne, And al the entrayle, as hit lay Off her bestis, bare he hit a-way; Be-twene here clauwes sche hem kyppis, And beres hem to the Gregais schippis. Alle the Troyens that ther wore, Off this two thinges abaist hem sore, For thei se by here tokenynges bothe That here godis with hem were wrothe; But whi it was, wiste thei neuere, But alle ther-of affrayed were. THe Gregais were slely by-thoght, A wonder werk hadde thei wroght: Thei did make an hors of bras, Suche a-nother neuere sene was; A thousand knyghtes myght ther-Inne; Ther-on was many a selcouthe gynne: Dores brode that opened wyde, A thousand men ther myght a-byde, But no man was of eye so bryght That myght with-oute of hem se sight. ¶ The kynges alle that comen wore To Priamus to socoure thore, When hit was done hem to vndirstonde That Priamus so foule a couenande Hadde mad to Grues to ben at one, Thei toke her leue at him echone, To wende hom to her contrese, And leffte him ther, & hem of Grece. ¶ Kyng Philomene had two thousand knyghtes That come with him, thei worthi wyghtes Ledde hem a&yogh;eyn to his lande But two hundrid & ffyffti of hem lyuande; He ledde with him Pantasalye, The worthi body of that ladye, ¶ Hic rogauit ad pacem & concordiam. And foure hundrid of damyseles That lyued afftir that turpeles, Vn-to the land of Amazone, To berye hir ther sche bar croune. HIt was a day, that lyther fende, Antenor, wolde his tresoun ende, Whan Palladin was y-stolne; And &yogh;it was hit fro Troyens holne; And thei of Grece her hors hadde ent. To sette a day was here entent, That Priamus & his Troyanes, Alle the Grues & the Danes, With-oute the toun, opoun the wolde, Be-twene hem that loueday schal holde. ¶ Priamus is comen oute, And mechel folk him aboute; And thei of Grece sicurly, Lordes & kynges ther redi. Thei did the relikes brynge, Her messe-bok that thei on synge, Here saynteuarius MS. sayntenarius. with al her gere, That bothe the parties on scholde swere. ¶ Diomedes was ffurst that swore, And made his othe vpon the flore; He swor by al here sayntwaries, And by him that al this world gyes, Off heuene & erthe al-myghti god: That he scholde neuere, for euene ne od, Breke the couenandes that he made With Antenor, so worth he glade. ¶ And so swor alle these other kynges That were of Grece gret lordynges. Off thai that toun afftir did for-lorn, &YOGH;it thei seyde thei were not for-sworn, For thei swore bothe to traye the toun With-oute mercy or any pardoun. But Priamus & alle hyes Made her othe on an-other wyes: ¶ Thei swor to holde the pees treuly, With-oute desert, parfitly; Thei were ther-with foule by-gyled And afftirward foule dispoyled, For thei wiste not of here fallas; Therfore here lyff thei lore, allas! WHan thei hadde sworn & mad surte, Kyng Priamus with herte fre Made men go afftir quene Helayne; And he &yogh;aff hem that lady a&yogh;eyne, And prayed hem for his loue sake: That sche of hem non harm scholde take, Vilony, ne no maugre, For that sche was In that contre; And thei seyde "nay" with ficul thoght. But Priamus thei hadde be-soght: "That he wol graunte hem alle a bone, That for here loue it myght be done." ¶ Thei saide: "thei hadde an hors done make For her godes Pallas sake, For that thei stale out of here chirche Palladine Or Palladium? MS. . . . in or . . . iu . , whan it was derke;"— 'And we are ferd alle for hir vengaunce; Hit is therfore oure ordinaunce, In hir cherche-&yogh;erd to do hit sette An hors of bras that we haue gette In hir honour—we telle it &yogh;ow— For that is, sir, oure alther a-vow. ¶ We praye &yogh;ow therfore: werne vs not That it may now to hir be broght.' Priamus stode as he were dased, He was for meruayle al a-mased, When he herde the Gregays say That thei that relike hadde away; He hadde meruayle how hit myght be, Who hadde done him that blynde bounte? But sicurly the blame was layde On Vlixes, for it was seyde "That he stale hit with Nigramancye, Fo[r] he was connynge of gret fayrye." PRyamus stode as stille as ston, Word to hem spake he non, He Answered not to here askyng, Better ne wors, ne non skynnes thyng. But Antenor & Eueas That bothe were ther In that plas, Thei seide: "It was wel to do, Thei did the toun a worschepe tho, It was a presaunt fair & hende Vn-to the toun with-outen ende." ¶ Priamus graunt hem tho her wille, For he saw nede he moste ther-tille. The Gregeis thanne, bothe gret & smale And alle that dwelled In tent & hale, &YOGH;ede with gret processioun And with mochel deuoc[i]oun This brasen hors for to hale Ouer doune & ouer dale; Thei drow hit ouer leye & falowe, To offer hit to that carful halowe. ¶ When thei were comen to Troye &yogh;ate, Tho wolde it not In ther-ate: Hit was so brod, gret, and hye, It myght not In ther sicurly. Tho most thei the walles breke, Iff that hors scholde ther-In reke; Thei breke ther-of a gret pece Off brede, of heyghte, that thei of Grece That her hors thei myght In-drawe; The Troyens lowe, whan thei it sawe. ¶ Thei halpe hit In with mochel sang, Sicurly tho did thei wrang To make ther-fore Ioye & play, Hem oght better sey: "waylaway! That euere it come with-Inne the diches!" But euery a Troyen now it lykes, But hit schal turne to mochel care To alle the Troyens that ther ware. THe hors is now with-Inne the toun. Ther was a knyght that het Symoun That thei of Grece hadde put ther-In, A worthi kny&yogh;t of gentil kyn; A thousand knyghtes were put with him The order in MS. is 18139, 18138. And was charged on lyff and lym That thei scholde holde hem stille & coy, That thei perceyued not of Troy; Til hit be wele with-Inne the nyght, That thei of Troye to bedde be dyght. ¶ Thei bad thanne his dores vn-do And come than out, & his also, And of stre gete him a wase And make on the walles ther-of a blase, That thei myght wele & worldly kenne By that fir that so scholde brenne, Whan thei scholde come In that euenyng, And knowe also by that tokenyng, When thei of Troye were alle on slepe That thei &yogh;aff to hem no kepe, ¶ Hic Greci receperunt pecuniam. That thei myght sle hem In her bed, That thei no wise fro hem fled. ¶ The Gregeis asked thanne her fret, The somme of corn that hem was het, The somme of siluer & of gold That thei of hem haue schold; Priamus badde MS. hadde . tho his meygne That it scholde quyk delyuered be. The Gregais toke that riche tresore And drowe it alle with-oute dore Off the temple of Menerue, And by her men sende hom that fe Vn-to her tentis & Pauylons, To dele amonges the riche Gryffons; The corn bare thei vnto the see And charged ther-with alle her nauee. And when thei hadde al this ent, To Priamus thei message sent And seyde "that thei wolde hamward wende Out of his lond vnto here frende"; He bad hem "go In godis name And god schilde hem fro schame!" THei losed bothe Anker & cordes, ¶ Hic Greci vadunt ad Mare. And drow vp tentis of kynges & lordes, Thei gone to schippes & to bote That longe hadde stonden ther In flote; Thei drow here sayles that alle myght se That were In Troye, that riche Cite. Thei were wel fayn when thei saw go That hadde done hem so mochel wo, Thei wende thei hadde ben al quyt; But hem scholde falle gret wo &yogh;it, For thei schal dye In gret affray, Twenti thousand, er hit be day. ¶ Hic Greci exierunt de Caballo & occiderunt Troianos. ¶ Pryamus wendes to Ilioun, And Gregais sayles to Thenedoun; The wynd is swyfft, the schippis dryued, At Thenadoun were thei aryued; Er the sonne was go to reste, Thei hadde souped of the beste, With mochel murthe, play, & Ioye, For thei were siker tho of Troye. HIt is forth nyghtes, the sterres ben rysen, The sely caytyues Troyens not wysen, Thei &yogh;ede to sclepe alle In bedde, Off no-thing were thei a-dredde; Thei wende thei hadde ben saue & sure, With-oute dissait or foule aventure. ¶ The knyghtes that were In that hors stopped, Thei were nother mased ne mopped; When Troyens were In bed on sclepe, Out of the hors echon thei crepe, Thei gete than a gret wase, Opon the walles thei made a blase: Alle the Gregeis tho come to toun And ther thei hadde the wal cast doun That day be-fore, a wel gret gappe, Thei come alle In to gret vn-happe. ¶ Thei brast vp dores with Iren y-bounde, Thei sclow al that thei ther founde, Man & womman & also childe, Stoute & sterne, meke and mylde, Wiff & mayden, &yogh;ong & old; On lyue wolde thei non hold. Thei hadde no mercy ne no pite Off &yogh;onge MS. &yogh;ouge . children, ne ladijs fre; Thei robbed & rafft alle that thei founde, To lede with hem In-to her londe. Mochel blod that nyght thei schedde, It was no wonder of thei dredde, To crye mercy was hem no bote, Thoow thei fellen vnto here fote; The cry was gret & fer herd Off hem that thus to dethe ferd. PRyamus herde In-to his toure That delful noyse & clamoure, He was sori & eke a-baist, He wiste wele thanne he was be-traist With Antenor and Eueas; Gret was the sorwe that he thanne mas: Out of his bed anon he ros And to his temple faste he gos By-fore his god Appolynes, Thedir he dight him faste y-wys; By-fore his god vpon the grees He sette him doun on on inserted over line. his knees, His deth bodily to a-byde; For he ne myght him fro hem hide, For he was man with-oute drede— In eche a romaunce as I rede.— ¶ Temple & chirche, boure and halle, The Gregeis dispoyled and robbed alle; The riche vessel of gold y-wroght, Off siluer also, for-&yogh;ate thei noght. Prest, ne clerk, ne sextayn Leffte the Gregais non vn-sclayn; Twenti thosand Citeseyns, Off knyghtes & lordis, gode Troiens, Were sclayn ther, er day spronge, With hidous cry & sorwe stronge. ¶ The kynges doghter, wise Cassandre, Sche nyst In erthe whedir to wandre, But at the laste alone fled sche In-to the temple of Menerue, And seide wel offte: 'alas, alas! That euere that fight be-gonne was!' ¶ Ector wyff, dame Andromede, Sche ran faste fro strete to strete With hir two children In hir armes; For drede of here gret harmes Sche nyste In erthe whedir to fare, But as scho ran, so was sche ware Where Cassandre be-fore hir &yogh;ede In-to the temple with gode spede, And sche afftir hir gan go In-to the temple with mechel wo. Mechel was the sorwe thei two made, Ther was no thyng that hem myght glade. TOward the day faste it drawes, The nyght is gon, the day dawes; Antenor and Eueas— In helle thei wone with Sathanas!— Thai ledde tho sir Pirrus To the Castel of Priamus. Whan Pirrus with the Gregais Was y-comen to that Palais, Thei brast vp dores with gret engyn, And afftirward thei wente In. ¶ Alle that thei fond doun thei sclow With-oute mercy, with sorwe y-now; Many a curtais ladi swete In that Palais to dethe thai bete That comen were of hye lynage, Off kynges blod In mariage; Thei lefft nother lowe ne hye. Thei robbed al his tresor that thei sye; ¶ Hic ffugarunt bona palacii Regis. Thei smot alle that for-set, Halle, & boure, & hye toret. ¶ Pirrus soght afftir the kyng, Fro hous to hous, In his byggyng; And afftir that to the temple he ran, And ther fond he that carful man: Pirrus tho was glad y-now, His swerd sone out he drow And al to-hewe him euery bone, ¶ Rex occi|ditur. Ryght be-fore the auter-stone, That al the Auter was al by-bled With his blod that ther was sched. HEctuba, that louely quene, And hir doghter Pollexene, Thei were so frayed & ferd, ¶ Regina That thei ran out of that &yogh;erd; ¶ ffugit. Thei were aferd the Gregais to mete, Thei ran aboute fro strete to strete. As thei ran, wiste thei not whedir, Thei mette Eueas bothe to-gedir: ¶ When Hectuba on him hath sight, Sche myssayde him anon right, Off tresoun sche him sone vmbraide: 'Fals traytour!'—to him sche sayde,— 'How myght thow, for soule synne, So ffals a tresoun to be-gynne? How myght thow In thi fals herte fynde, Fals traytour, to be so vnkynde To do thi lord suche schenschip, That hadde done alle thi worschip? ¶ He &yogh;aff the his doghter to wyue Be-ffore alle men that were on lyue, He worschepid the & loued the ay, In the was al his trust & ffay, And thow hast made him sclayn & hise For his godenesse & ffraunchise! How myght thow, man, this tresoun thenke, For ferd In helle leste thow synke? But sithen thow hast done MS. dou. al this wrake, Do on me mercy for goddis sake, That thow myght take sum merite: Saue vs two to-day fro dispite Fro alle Gregais on godis name, That thei do vs two no schame!' ¶ Eueas hadde of hir pite, He seyde: 'comes bothe & folewes me!' He ledde hem to an old place, An old tour that for-saken was Off long tyme, that hadde ben wast; He hyed hem with mechel hast For drede lest thei were y-wraied, And lefft hem there sore affrayed. ¶ As thei the toun thus a-boght soght, Ayax Thelamenyus was broght In-to the temple of Menerue, With many Gregais comen is he: Ther fond he sitte Ector wyff That was ful sori of hir lyff, And wise Cassandre that mochel was worth; He broght hem bothe to-gedir forth, The ladyes bothe with him he ledde Ful sore wepyng & sore a-dredde. Kyng Priamus is ded & sclayn, Lord & lady, knyght & swayn, And al that euere In Ilyon was, By these fals traytoures compas, By Antenor and Eueas; In helle mot be her wonyng-plas! ¶ Hic villa Troiani destruitur. ¶ When thei had sclayn al that ther wore, &YOGH;it wolde thei do malice more: Thei caste al doun thes worthi wones, Led & tyle, sclat & stones, Halles, Chamberes, & toures, Vowes, walles, & alle her boures; The glorious halle so richely dyght Thei threwe it doun In gret dispit; ¶ The Pilers pight with marbil gray Thei pulled doun & caste a-way, Thei caste doun chambres hye & base. Tho by-gan many a blase To sette fir on that Cite, That many a myle men myght hit se. The toures brennen, the reke vp ros, The toun of tounes to noght gos; The sparkes sprongen In-to the aire, Thei brenned the schireues & the mayre And eche a lordes riche tenement, Til al the toun was lorn & brent; ¶ Alle saue the traytoures mansions And alle her kynnes possessions That the toun so foule be-swyked,— For on her houses thei hadde stiked Certayn signes that wele were knowen; Thei were not therfore ouer-throwen, As couenand was be-twixen hem ent, Therfore her houses was not brent. TRoye is doune & ouer-throwen, Tour & bour, walle & wowen; Thei are alle dede & foule schent, And the toun is doune & brent. ¶ Agamenoun MS. . . . on . did do then crye, That euery a kyng scholde hem hye ¶ Hic partita sunt bona inter Reges. In-to the temple of Menerue, And euery a lord with his meyne; And brynge with hem al that thei wan With-Inne the toun of any man, To dele as best wolde by-falle In comune sight be-fore hem alle. And thei did alle as he hem bad, Thei broght with hem that thei had; And so was hit deled verament By gode resoun & Iugement To euery a lord & knyght Afftir his state & his myght. AGamenoun, here Emperour, ¶ Hic Agamenon petit Cassandram pro labore suo On the left side in MS. . By-soght hem, for his labour For to &yogh;eue him to his mede, For al his trauayle & his dele, The kynges doghter, Cassandre the wyse, That sche myght be on of hise. ¶ The tonge of no man may telle, What godis to euery lord felle; For sicur ther ne was no kyng, That he ne hadde as moche thing Off riche gold & precious stones To lede with hem to her wones, As thei wolde desire & haue Or with her tonge on any wyse craue; And so hadde dukes & eke kny&yogh;tes, Sqwyeres, &yogh;emen, & other wyghtes. ¶ Here schippes myght not lede her tresour That euery man hadde for his labour, And &yogh;it thei lefft mochel more, Gold, & siluer, & other tresore, That no man wolde hond ther-on set, Ne here schippes no more ffret, For thei hadde filled bothe schip & barge Al the while thei durst hem charge. ANtenor & Eueas Be-soght the lordes of her grace: "To graunte Heleyne hir lyff And Andromede, Ectoris wyff, For thei hadde ben al-weys To hem bothe hende & curteys;" 'And whan Paris hadde Achilles sclayn And let him ligge so foule be-sclayn In-myddes the strete to rauen & rokes,— Scholde haue to-drawen him with her crokes,— ¶ These two ffor him thei be-soght That he myght to burieles be broght. Wherfore it is worthi, That &yogh;e here lyues to hem graunty.' The kynges it graunt by comune assent, And seyde it was gode Iugement. Heleyne MS. Helenus . & Andromede Bede tho alle those lordes swete Off here mercy and thaire good wille, That thei wolde not hir children spille. ¶ The kynges hadde of hem gret ruthe, Thei swor alle by her treuthe That thei scholde hem non harm do; And thus saued thei the childryn two: And sithen was on a kyng In Grece, Off riche londes & riche fece, Off alle the londes kyng Pirrus And of the londes of kyng Pelleus. ¶ Thei ordeyned a-monges hem as blyue, That alle that were lefft on lyue Off ladyes, comen of genterye, With-oute schame or vylonye Scholde go & come & no-thing lese, Or dwelle ther stille, whether thei wolde chese. ¶ Thei ordeyned also thei wolde hom wende, Euery man vnto his frende. But that myght not that tyme be For gret tempest on the see; Thei dwelled so ther alle to-gedir A ful Monethe for that euel wedir, Thei were echon ther-of euel tened, Thei asked Calcas: "what it be-mened That thei no wyse the see myght pas In-to here londes, as here wille was?" ¶ That gret Clerk Calcas tho seyde: 'For thei of helle are with &yogh;ow euel payde; It is the wodenesse'—he sayde—'of helle That makes vs here so longe dwelle, For &yogh;e forsothe haue venged noght Achilles deth, as &yogh;e wel oght; &YOGH;it haue &yogh;e lefft on lyue & vn-tane Sche that was Achilles bane,— And yff &yogh;e wol passe of londe, Off hir &yogh;e mot make him offrande For sicur: but sche to dethe gange, &YOGH;e may dwelle here wel lange.' PIrrus was of this an-yred, Afftir Pollexene he enspired And asked what was of hir be-tyd; He seide for-sothe that sche was hid, For sche was nowher ded ne tane, And al men wiste, that sche was wane; And al that ost seyde sicurly, That sche was lyuande witterly. ¶ The kynges alle were wroth ther-fore And sent afftir sir Antenore, And asked at him: "where sche was done?" Thei bad "that he scholde telle sone, Where thei hadde hid Dame Pollexene And Hectuba, the qwene?" ¶ He swor by god & by his face: "That he ne wiste where sche wace; He wyst neuere, where thei were be-comen Sithen the tyme that thei were y-nomen." But thei bare him stiffly an hande, That he wiste where thei were dwellande. ANtenor was sore a-greued That the Gregais him not leued, He sette his wit and al his tent To wete than where the ladies lent. So longe he soght fro day to day, Strete by strete, & way be way, And sente a-boute oueral his sonde, That at the laste thei hem fonde: Bothe were In a depe bour, That was vnder an old tour. ¶ When he of hir hadde a sight, He drow out thanne that worthi wyght, And to Agamenoun The MS. has ou very distinctly here, not on . with hir he wente And made to him of hir a presente; And he sent hir to sir Pirrus, That of hir comyng was Ioyus. ¶ Pollexene is taken & founden, As a theff thei haue hir bounden: Pirrus bad "sche scholde be sent To his ffadres monument, For he wolde that sche scholde haue Hir deth vpon his fader graue." Thei ledde hir forth by the hand To hir deth, wel sore wepand. ¶ The kynges of Grece herd say "That thei hadde take that worthi may Thorow Calcas the prestes rede, And that thei haue hir to the dede"; The kynges ran hir to se, And alle that other comunalte. ¶ When thei saw hir, thei seyde: "alas! That suche a ladi as sche was Off schap, of hede, & of bewte, Scholde so vile ther ded be With-oute desert or any gilt, That suche a bodi scholde be spilt." Many a lord & many a kyng Wepe wel so[re] for that swetyng. BE-fore that tombe that mayden stondes The abbreviations here are not , but . , Wryngyng bother hir white hondes The abbreviations here are not , but . , Wel reufully that lady gretis, That al hir brest that water wetis. Sche seide: 'lordynges, by god al-myght! &YOGH;e do me scle with mochel vn-right! For—by that god that maked pes!— Off that knyghtes deth am I giltles; For I was neuere occasioun Off his dethe ne enchesoun, Ne neuere &yogh;it was at that assent That he that tyme to dethe went; ¶ But Angured me sore of his schedyng,— So helpe me god at myn endyng! Not-for-thi the In the MS. to is crossed out here, and the inserted over line. deth I ne drede, Thus carefully, so Crist me spede! For me is leuere In my contre Be sclayn In my virginite, That I falle not In &yogh;oure handis, Þan Þan inserted by another hand to the left, And being crossed out. go with &yogh;ow In-to &yogh;oure landis ¶ Hic Pirrus Interfecit Pollexenam. And be ther defouled & for-layn With &yogh;ow that haue my fader sclayn. Lette come the deth when &yogh;e wille, For I am redi now ther-tille!' ¶ Pirrus thanne his swerd out-drow And that ladi sone he sclow, And hewe to gobetis al hir flesch, And with hir blod the tombe wesch. When Hectuba, that gentil quene, Saw ded hir doghter Pollexene, And saw hir spraulen In hir blode, ¶ The quene for-sothe wex ner wode, And felde men with stones & smot, And as an hound hem gnow & bot, And tare here clothes & on hem spit,— So was sche wode & out of wit. When thei saw hir for wode so wilde, Thei did lede hir to an Ilde ¶ Hic Regina mortua est. With-oute the toun—het Aulidis,— And stoned hir to dethe y-wis. ¶ And made ther a tombe fair & hye, And leyde ther-Inne that quenes bodye; That standes &yogh;it vnto this day, As sais tho men that wenden that way; And beres that stede &yogh;it the name, That thei for hir &yogh;aff the name. THe quene is ded by these traytours fals MS. has a small cross at this place; cf. note on p. 548. , And Pollexene, hir doghter, als, And alle hir sones that oght were worth Are sclayn & dede & passed forth; And Priamus, hir lord, the kyng, Is ded also, & his hous gyng; He is ded and his kynred, And alle his frendis & his manred; Is non on lyue lyuande ffre Saue thes traytours & her meyne. ¶ And &yogh;it afftirward hit schop so That the traytoures bothe two For here ffalsnesse were afftir demed To be exiled & afftir flemed— With al here kyn & here lynage— For her wickednesse & her outrage; Afftir the Gregais were I-went, Wel foule were thei afftir schent. ¶ But al the while that thei were thare, Thei did the Cite moche care And halp the Gregeis to distroye And alle the folk foule annoye. NOw ben the Grues wonder bolde And bene alle lordes,—as I &yogh;ow tolde;— And al this is at here wille That thei wolde haue, bothe loude & stille. Agamenoun let crye Thorow alle that companye, In tour & toun, by way & strete: "That no man scholde for no man lete, That thei alle at morwe be tyme, Be-twix sonne risyng & the prime, Were al redi at here naue To passe forth ouer the see, With alle her godis & her thing That thei wole to schipe bryng The MS. has another small cross at this place; cf. note on p. 547. ." ¶ The nyght was gon, the sonne a-ros, Fro the lond the schippes gos; With alle her meyne that with hem was To schipe thei wente a gode pas, And drow vp sayl to the top; And sayled homward alle on a throp, Euery lord to his contre, With Ioye & blysse & mechel gle, And tresour I-now MS. I. now. for euere-mo: Kyngis & knyghtes, & sqwyers also, And alle other hadde gret store, Gold & siluer for euere-more. ¶ And thus was Troye dryuen doun And y-lore thorow strong tresoun, And alle the gode lordis dede,— As In this romaunce men may rede; And thus the Grues were conquerours And wel riche with here tresoures, And hadde y-now for euere-more Alle that at that batayle wore. ¶ And thus endis this strong batayle That was of Troye saunfayle, That dured ten &yogh;ere euery day,— As the romaunce ther-of doth say,— Off Troye batayle, that fair cyte. Now god that died vpon the tre, That schede ther his swete blode Opon that blisful croys, that rode, For synful mannes saluacioun, Graunt vs alle his benysoun, Gode lyff and gode endyng, A gode soule to heuene bryng, And graunte vs of his swete grace Ther-In to haue a swete place! ¶ And he that this romaunce wroght & made, Lord In heuene, thow him glade, And gode lyff In erthe to lede, And heuene blysse vnto his mede; And graunte hit mot so be! Sayeth alle Amen, for charite! On lf. 275, bk. is written by the same hand the rubric: Hic Bellum de Troye ffinit Et Greci tran|sierunt versus Patriam suam. Some scribbling follows.
